summary: Seat comfort, especially in the first two rows, is excellent. The third row's seat bottom is tilted (high front, low rear) at an angle that might bother some occupants. Space is ample in every row.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: This is a big, plush minivan with enough comfort, amenities and handy features to easily tackle all-day drives with the family.
title: Seating Comfort

make.name: Chrysler
model.name: Town and Country
style.name: Touring-L 4dr Minivan (3.6L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Though it leans toward comfort, the T&C's suspension tuning proved awkward in some situations. For instance, large road irregularities revealed inadequate bump absorption from the rear suspension.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: This is a big, plush minivan with enough comfort, amenities and handy features to easily tackle all-day drives with the family.
title: Ride Comfort

make.name: Chrysler
model.name: Town and Country
style.name: Touring-L 4dr Minivan (3.6L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Road and wind noise are at segment standards. But the T&C's occasional rattle or accessory sound aren't present in the competition. Full-throttle engine noise is more obtrusive, too.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: This is a big, plush minivan with enough comfort, amenities and handy features to easily tackle all-day drives with the family.
title: Quietness

make.name: Chrysler
model.name: Town and Country
style.name: Touring-L 4dr Minivan (3.6L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Primary controls, with the exception of the bizarre dash-mounted shifter, are all easy to use and reach. Secondary controls, too, fall readily at hand. Most storage and utility functions are intuitive.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Interior flexibility is the T&C's biggest strength. Space, utility, storage and features are excellent in this van and are, in many cases, segment leading.
title: Ergonomics

make.name: Chrysler
model.name: Town and Country
style.name: Touring-L 4dr Minivan (3.6L 6cyl 6A)
summary: The first and second rows offer average ingress/egress. Third-row access is very good thanks to second-row seats that fold, tumble and slide inward. Overall, it's hard to do better than this.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Interior flexibility is the T&C's biggest strength. Space, utility, storage and features are excellent in this van and are, in many cases, segment leading.
title: Ingress/Egress

make.name: Chrysler
model.name: Town and Country
style.name: Touring-L 4dr Minivan (3.6L 6cyl 6A)
summary: The T&C uses its space exceptionally well. Small-item storage, from the dual gloveboxes to the multiple bins, is abundant. The removable center console is also a nice feature and there's no shortage of cupholders.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Interior flexibility is the T&C's biggest strength. Space, utility, storage and features are excellent in this van and are, in many cases, segment leading.
title: Space/Room

make.name: Chrysler
model.name: Town and Country
style.name: Touring-L 4dr Minivan (3.6L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Overall visibility is good, but rear-quarter views are marginally inhibited by the third-row headrests, though they can be flipped down.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Interior flexibility is the T&C's biggest strength. Space, utility, storage and features are excellent in this van and are, in many cases, segment leading.
title: Visibility

make.name: Chrysler
model.name: Town and Country
style.name: Touring-L 4dr Minivan (3.6L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Stow 'N Go second- and third-row seats are segment leading. Power operation of the third row is nice and there's massive storage in the second-row floor. Grocery-bag hooks are abundant.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Interior flexibility is the T&C's biggest strength. Space, utility, storage and features are excellent in this van and are, in many cases, segment leading.
title: Cargo/Storage

make.name: Chrysler
model.name: Town and Country
style.name: Touring-L 4dr Minivan (3.6L 6cyl 6A)
summary: There's less attention to quality details in the T&C than in the Japanese competition. Some materials look/feel nice, but they're matched with large swaths of plastic trim. We observed some rattles.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The T&C's value proposition is mixed relative to others in the segment. Though its utility is unmatched, its quality, in some areas, could be better.
title: Build Quality (vs. $)

make.name: Chrysler
model.name: Town and Country
style.name: Touring-L 4dr Minivan (3.6L 6cyl 6A)
summary: A mix of highs and lows. The low-resolution touchscreen is dated. Our $38,000 tester lacked navigation but included heated first/second-row seats, a heated wheel and a dual-screen Blu-Ray DVD player.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The T&C's value proposition is mixed relative to others in the segment. Though its utility is unmatched, its quality, in some areas, could be better.
title: Features(vs. $)

make.name: Chrysler
model.name: Town and Country
style.name: Touring-L 4dr Minivan (3.6L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Pricing for the T&C begins at $31,760, with the Touring L tested here starting at $35,160. If utility and features are your highest priorities, it ranks well. If quality is most important, look elsewhere.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The T&C's value proposition is mixed relative to others in the segment. Though its utility is unmatched, its quality, in some areas, could be better.
title: Cost

make.name: Chrysler
model.name: Town and Country
style.name: Touring-L 4dr Minivan (3.6L 6cyl 6A)
summary: At 20 mpg Combined (17 City/25 Highway), the T&C isn't the most efficient offering in the segment. We saw 21.4 mpg on our 116-mile highway-heavy evaluation loop.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The T&C's value proposition is mixed relative to others in the segment. Though its utility is unmatched, its quality, in some areas, could be better.
title: MPG

make.name: Chrysler
model.name: Town and Country
style.name: Touring-L 4dr Minivan (3.6L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Basic warranty for 3 years/36,000 miles with the powertrain and rust coverage at 5 years/100,000 miles. With the exception of the dated Kia Sedona, this is the best powertrain warranty in the segment.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The T&C's value proposition is mixed relative to others in the segment. Though its utility is unmatched, its quality, in some areas, could be better.
title: Warranty

make.name: Chrysler
model.name: Town and Country
style.name: Touring-L 4dr Minivan (3.6L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Roadside assistance for the first 5 years/100,000 miles. Chrysler's reputation for quality, though improving, isnâ€™t stellar. And the T&C has many complicated interior systems.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The T&C's value proposition is mixed relative to others in the segment. Though its utility is unmatched, its quality, in some areas, could be better.
title: Ownership

make.name: Chrysler
model.name: Town and Country
style.name: Touring-L 4dr Minivan (3.6L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Not many aspects of the T&C's driving experience are rewarding, but that's true of all minivans. Still, this is a comfortable and highly functional van. More so than most others.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: Few minivans are truly fun to drive. Rather, the fun comes in their massive utility. The T&C has that portion of the equation covered easily.
title: Driving Experience

make.name: Chrysler
model.name: Town and Country
style.name: Touring-L 4dr Minivan (3.6L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Like a good pocket knife, the T&C is going to meet many needs with its vast swath of utility. Otherwise, it lacks the character of its competitors.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: Few minivans are truly fun to drive. Rather, the fun comes in their massive utility. The T&C has that portion of the equation covered easily.
title: Personality

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: The seats are comfortable enough but lateral support is lacking for a car with high cornering limits. The short seat bottoms may bother taller drivers and the lack of a telescoping steering wheel will be a problem for others.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: The Abarth's ride comfort is better than a Mini Cooper S and pretty similar to a Ford Fiesta ST. Overall, considering its sporting intentions, the ride quality is decent. The seats certainly aren't cushy, and the exhaust sound is either obnoxious or hilarious, depending on your viewpoint.
title: Seating Comfort

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: Surprisingly, the 500 Abarth is a reasonably comfortable car. It can get a little bouncy over cracked pavement, but that's the price you pay for small-car performance.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: The Abarth's ride comfort is better than a Mini Cooper S and pretty similar to a Ford Fiesta ST. Overall, considering its sporting intentions, the ride quality is decent. The seats certainly aren't cushy, and the exhaust sound is either obnoxious or hilarious, depending on your viewpoint.
title: Ride Comfort

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: The Abarth's exhaust is quite loud, but it adds character and doesn't drone too miserably on the freeway. Road noise is prevalent, when you can hear it over the exhaust, that is. This is not a quiet car.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: The Abarth's ride comfort is better than a Mini Cooper S and pretty similar to a Ford Fiesta ST. Overall, considering its sporting intentions, the ride quality is decent. The seats certainly aren't cushy, and the exhaust sound is either obnoxious or hilarious, depending on your viewpoint.
title: Quietness

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: Order the optional automatic climate control and there's not a single knob on the Abarth's dash, which is a big mistake. Radio controls are cryptic. Non-telescoping steering wheel and close pedals will put some drivers in a bad position.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Interior details are a bit flashy and have a decidedly retro flavor. There's a level of character here that can otherwise only be found in a Mini Cooper. But there's also a lack of functionality, which gets annoying.
title: Ergonomics

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: Wide-opening doors are a good thing, as are the high seat bottoms. The front seats are easy to get into. Rear seat access is, as expected, a huge pain for adults.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Interior details are a bit flashy and have a decidedly retro flavor. There's a level of character here that can otherwise only be found in a Mini Cooper. But there's also a lack of functionality, which gets annoying.
title: Ingress/Egress

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: Sunroof-equipped cars compromise headroom and rear seat space is extremely limited. The hard center console protrudes into the side of the driver's knee in a very uncomfortable way.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Interior details are a bit flashy and have a decidedly retro flavor. There's a level of character here that can otherwise only be found in a Mini Cooper. But there's also a lack of functionality, which gets annoying.
title: Space/Room

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: Tall, upright seats and large windows give the Abarth good outward visibility. The rear view is compromised by some thick roof pillars, but it's still easy to back up.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Interior details are a bit flashy and have a decidedly retro flavor. There's a level of character here that can otherwise only be found in a Mini Cooper. But there's also a lack of functionality, which gets annoying.
title: Visibility

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: There's room for soft bags in the 9.5 cu-ft space behind the rear seats, but anything larger will require folding the seats down. Interior storage is minimal, with shallow door pockets and cramped cupholders.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Interior details are a bit flashy and have a decidedly retro flavor. There's a level of character here that can otherwise only be found in a Mini Cooper. But there's also a lack of functionality, which gets annoying.
title: Cargo/Storage

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: With a 160-horsepower 1.4-liter turbo 4-cylinder, the Fiat's got enough power to spin the front wheels easily. Power delivery is a bit peaky, but it pulls hard. Zero-60 mph takes 7.1 seconds, versus 6.3 in the Mini Cooper S four-door.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The Abarth model is considerably quicker than lesser Fiat 500 models. It's relatively engaging to drive and remains well-behaved when driven aggressively. Still, it shows its subcompact roots when driven to (and over) its limits. The five-speed manual transmission is a bit indirect and sloppy.
title: Acceleration

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: The Abarth squirms around on its all-season tires more than we'd prefer during full-ABS stops, but it remains stable. In daily driving, the brakes are light and easy. The 123 feet it needs to stop from 60 mph is on the long side.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The Abarth model is considerably quicker than lesser Fiat 500 models. It's relatively engaging to drive and remains well-behaved when driven aggressively. Still, it shows its subcompact roots when driven to (and over) its limits. The five-speed manual transmission is a bit indirect and sloppy.
title: Braking

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: Sport mode firms up the steering, but doesn't add any more feedback. The Abarth is an easy car to throw around, but it lacks precision.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The Abarth model is considerably quicker than lesser Fiat 500 models. It's relatively engaging to drive and remains well-behaved when driven aggressively. Still, it shows its subcompact roots when driven to (and over) its limits. The five-speed manual transmission is a bit indirect and sloppy.
title: Steering

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: Good enough to hang with its primary competition in our instrumented tests, and it's pretty fun out on the road. This car likes to be pushed hard, but it lacks the finesse and grip to keep up with other sporty hatchbacks on the truly twisty bits.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The Abarth model is considerably quicker than lesser Fiat 500 models. It's relatively engaging to drive and remains well-behaved when driven aggressively. Still, it shows its subcompact roots when driven to (and over) its limits. The five-speed manual transmission is a bit indirect and sloppy.
title: Handling

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: In normal mode, throttle response is lazy. Pair that with a short clutch uptake and you've got a recipe for a jerky ride. For best gas pedal response, press the Sport button. Although the manual tranny isn't perfect, it makes better use of the power than the automatic.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The Abarth model is considerably quicker than lesser Fiat 500 models. It's relatively engaging to drive and remains well-behaved when driven aggressively. Still, it shows its subcompact roots when driven to (and over) its limits. The five-speed manual transmission is a bit indirect and sloppy.
title: Driveability

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: The Abarth doesn't look or feel like a premium car inside the way the Mini Cooper does. Hard materials abound, yet the surfaces feel flimsy and have a tendency to creak.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: With a starting price around $24,000, value is an Abarth shortcoming. In this price range, you can get either better performance or a nicer car. You'll buy the Abarth simply because you love the way it looks or sounds. Maybe both.
title: Build Quality (vs. $)

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: You'll have to pay more if you want features like 17-inch wheels, navigation, automatic climate control and Abarth badging. Standard features include power door locks, Bluetooth, cloth seats and a tilt steering wheel.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: With a starting price around $24,000, value is an Abarth shortcoming. In this price range, you can get either better performance or a nicer car. You'll buy the Abarth simply because you love the way it looks or sounds. Maybe both.
title: Features(vs. $)

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: Fully optioned, the 500 Abarth can hit nearly $30,000, which is simply too much for this little car. Especially since competitors are larger, offer more refinement and, in the case of the Ford Focus ST, cost less.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: With a starting price around $24,000, value is an Abarth shortcoming. In this price range, you can get either better performance or a nicer car. You'll buy the Abarth simply because you love the way it looks or sounds. Maybe both.
title: Cost

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: An EPA rating of 30 mpg combined (28 city/34 highway) is encouraging, but we only averaged 22 mpg while the car was with us. On our 116-mile evaluation loop we managed a respectable 31.8 mpg.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: With a starting price around $24,000, value is an Abarth shortcoming. In this price range, you can get either better performance or a nicer car. You'll buy the Abarth simply because you love the way it looks or sounds. Maybe both.
title: MPG

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: The basic and powertrain warranties cover the car for 4 years/50,000 miles, both of which are typical for cars in this class. Extended coverage is offered at additional cost.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: With a starting price around $24,000, value is an Abarth shortcoming. In this price range, you can get either better performance or a nicer car. You'll buy the Abarth simply because you love the way it looks or sounds. Maybe both.
title: Warranty

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: Roadside assistance is offered for four years with unlimited mileage, which is slightly above average. No free maintenance is available. Mini comes standard with three years free maintenance.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: With a starting price around $24,000, value is an Abarth shortcoming. In this price range, you can get either better performance or a nicer car. You'll buy the Abarth simply because you love the way it looks or sounds. Maybe both.
title: Ownership

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: If the Abarth felt quicker out on the road it would be easier to justify the raucous exhaust note. It looks and sounds the part, yes, but it doesn't deliver a great driving experience, whether on canyon roads or the daily commute.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: Being fun to drive is the Abarth's biggest selling point. The manual transmission is better than the automatic. It makes good sounds and manhandles traffic. Still, you'll probably have more fun in a Mini Cooper S or Ford Fiesta ST.
title: Driving Experience

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: There's planty of personality here. It's quirky, unusual, fun and loud in every way. Plan on being looked at in the Abarth. The exhaust note gets people's attention, while the car's visuals hold their stares afterward.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: Being fun to drive is the Abarth's biggest selling point. The manual transmission is better than the automatic. It makes good sounds and manhandles traffic. Still, you'll probably have more fun in a Mini Cooper S or Ford Fiesta ST.
title: Personality

make.name: FIAT
style.name: t Turbo 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: Front seat comfort is good, but lateral support and a passenger armrest are lacking. It's off-putting that the steering wheel is off-center. Rear seats are sized only for kids.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: The 500 T's ride comfort is far better than a Mini Cooper with the Sport package, but seating is lacking for a sporty hatch. Overall, considering its abilities, comfort is good.
title: Seating Comfort

make.name: FIAT
style.name: t Turbo 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: One of the best-riding compact cars available; never busy, bouncy, or nervous. Really. This is truly a remarkable achievement considering its stubby proportions and sporty tires.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: The 500 T's ride comfort is far better than a Mini Cooper with the Sport package, but seating is lacking for a sporty hatch. Overall, considering its abilities, comfort is good.

summary: The 500 T's growly exhaust is evident by design, adding character but not droning annoyingly on the freeway.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: The 500 T's ride comfort is far better than a Mini Cooper with the Sport package, but seating is lacking for a sporty hatch. Overall, considering its abilities, comfort is good.
title: Quietness

style.name: t Turbo 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: There's not a single knob on the Fiat's dash, not even audio volume: big mistake. Other problems include unintuitive, crowded, busy instrumentation and strange button locations.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Interior design is challenging at best with questionable ergonomics, cramped quarters, and barely enough cargo capacity for an overnighter.

summary: Wide-opening doors are a good thing unless you're in a tight parking stall, especially with a rear passenger. Passenger-side front seat does not return to original position.

ratings.summary: Interior design is challenging at best with questionable ergonomics, cramped quarters, and barely enough cargo capacity for an overnighter.

summary: One expects good visibility in compact car, yet its chunky middle roof-pillar inhibits over-the-shoulder glances and large rear roof-pillar hides cars, too.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Interior design is challenging at best with questionable ergonomics, cramped quarters, and barely enough cargo capacity for an overnighter.

summary: The 135-hp 1.4L Turbo provides brisk acceleration from low rpm, but also has an entertainingly high redline and vastly improved manual shifter from previous 500s.

summary: Plan on driving aggressively or risk being cut-off in traffic. Why? Other driver's expect it to be a slow, base 500 and don't want to get stuck behind.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: Being fun to drive is the 500 T's biggest selling point. It makes good sounds, squirts effortlessly between corners and manhandles traffic. Yes, it's fun.
title: Driving Experience

make.name: FIAT
style.name: t Turbo 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: Sadly, besides the rewarding driving experience itself, there's little evidence of this being a special 500. Cute and cuddly gets old. Abarth is the answer.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: Being fun to drive is the 500 T's biggest selling point. It makes good sounds, squirts effortlessly between corners and manhandles traffic. Yes, it's fun.
title: Personality

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: The seats are comfortable enough but lateral support is lacking for a car with high cornering limits. The short seat bottoms may bother taller drivers and the lack of a telescoping steering wheel will be a problem for others.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: The Abarth's ride comfort is better than a Mini Cooper S and pretty similar to a Ford Fiesta ST. Overall, considering its sporting intentions, the ride quality is decent. The seats certainly aren't cushy, and the exhaust sound is either obnoxious or hilarious, depending on your viewpoint.
title: Seating Comfort

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: Surprisingly, the 500 Abarth is a reasonably comfortable car. It can get a little bouncy over cracked pavement, but that's the price you pay for small-car performance.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: The Abarth's ride comfort is better than a Mini Cooper S and pretty similar to a Ford Fiesta ST. Overall, considering its sporting intentions, the ride quality is decent. The seats certainly aren't cushy, and the exhaust sound is either obnoxious or hilarious, depending on your viewpoint.
title: Ride Comfort

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: The Abarth's exhaust is quite loud, but it adds character and doesn't drone too miserably on the freeway. Road noise is prevalent, when you can hear it over the exhaust, that is. This is not a quiet car.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: The Abarth's ride comfort is better than a Mini Cooper S and pretty similar to a Ford Fiesta ST. Overall, considering its sporting intentions, the ride quality is decent. The seats certainly aren't cushy, and the exhaust sound is either obnoxious or hilarious, depending on your viewpoint.
title: Quietness

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: Order the optional automatic climate control and there's not a single knob on the Abarth's dash, which is a big mistake. Radio controls are cryptic. Non-telescoping steering wheel and close pedals will put some drivers in a bad position.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Interior details are a bit flashy and have a decidedly retro flavor. There's a level of character here that can otherwise only be found in a Mini Cooper. But there's also a lack of functionality, which gets annoying.
title: Ergonomics

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: Wide-opening doors are a good thing, as are the high seat bottoms. The front seats are easy to get into. Rear seat access is, as expected, a huge pain for adults.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Interior details are a bit flashy and have a decidedly retro flavor. There's a level of character here that can otherwise only be found in a Mini Cooper. But there's also a lack of functionality, which gets annoying.
title: Ingress/Egress

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: Sunroof-equipped cars compromise headroom and rear seat space is extremely limited. The hard center console protrudes into the side of the driver's knee in a very uncomfortable way.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Interior details are a bit flashy and have a decidedly retro flavor. There's a level of character here that can otherwise only be found in a Mini Cooper. But there's also a lack of functionality, which gets annoying.
title: Space/Room

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: Tall, upright seats and large windows give the Abarth good outward visibility. The rear view is compromised by some thick roof pillars, but it's still easy to back up.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Interior details are a bit flashy and have a decidedly retro flavor. There's a level of character here that can otherwise only be found in a Mini Cooper. But there's also a lack of functionality, which gets annoying.
title: Visibility

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: There's room for soft bags in the 9.5 cu-ft space behind the rear seats, but anything larger will require folding the seats down. Interior storage is minimal, with shallow door pockets and cramped cupholders.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Interior details are a bit flashy and have a decidedly retro flavor. There's a level of character here that can otherwise only be found in a Mini Cooper. But there's also a lack of functionality, which gets annoying.
title: Cargo/Storage

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: With a 160-horsepower 1.4-liter turbo 4-cylinder, the Fiat's got enough power to spin the front wheels easily. Power delivery is a bit peaky, but it pulls hard. Zero-60 mph takes 7.1 seconds, versus 6.3 in the Mini Cooper S four-door.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The Abarth model is considerably quicker than lesser Fiat 500 models. It's relatively engaging to drive and remains well-behaved when driven aggressively. Still, it shows its subcompact roots when driven to (and over) its limits. The five-speed manual transmission is a bit indirect and sloppy.
title: Acceleration

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: The Abarth squirms around on its all-season tires more than we'd prefer during full-ABS stops, but it remains stable. In daily driving, the brakes are light and easy. The 123 feet it needs to stop from 60 mph is on the long side.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The Abarth model is considerably quicker than lesser Fiat 500 models. It's relatively engaging to drive and remains well-behaved when driven aggressively. Still, it shows its subcompact roots when driven to (and over) its limits. The five-speed manual transmission is a bit indirect and sloppy.
title: Braking

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: Sport mode firms up the steering, but doesn't add any more feedback. The Abarth is an easy car to throw around, but it lacks precision.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The Abarth model is considerably quicker than lesser Fiat 500 models. It's relatively engaging to drive and remains well-behaved when driven aggressively. Still, it shows its subcompact roots when driven to (and over) its limits. The five-speed manual transmission is a bit indirect and sloppy.
title: Steering

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: Good enough to hang with its primary competition in our instrumented tests, and it's pretty fun out on the road. This car likes to be pushed hard, but it lacks the finesse and grip to keep up with other sporty hatchbacks on the truly twisty bits.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The Abarth model is considerably quicker than lesser Fiat 500 models. It's relatively engaging to drive and remains well-behaved when driven aggressively. Still, it shows its subcompact roots when driven to (and over) its limits. The five-speed manual transmission is a bit indirect and sloppy.
title: Handling

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: In normal mode, throttle response is lazy. Pair that with a short clutch uptake and you've got a recipe for a jerky ride. For best gas pedal response, press the Sport button. Although the manual tranny isn't perfect, it makes better use of the power than the automatic.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The Abarth model is considerably quicker than lesser Fiat 500 models. It's relatively engaging to drive and remains well-behaved when driven aggressively. Still, it shows its subcompact roots when driven to (and over) its limits. The five-speed manual transmission is a bit indirect and sloppy.
title: Driveability

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: The Abarth doesn't look or feel like a premium car inside the way the Mini Cooper does. Hard materials abound, yet the surfaces feel flimsy and have a tendency to creak.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: With a starting price around $24,000, value is an Abarth shortcoming. In this price range, you can get either better performance or a nicer car. You'll buy the Abarth simply because you love the way it looks or sounds. Maybe both.
title: Build Quality (vs. $)

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: You'll have to pay more if you want features like 17-inch wheels, navigation, automatic climate control and Abarth badging. Standard features include power door locks, Bluetooth, cloth seats and a tilt steering wheel.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: With a starting price around $24,000, value is an Abarth shortcoming. In this price range, you can get either better performance or a nicer car. You'll buy the Abarth simply because you love the way it looks or sounds. Maybe both.
title: Features(vs. $)

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: Fully optioned, the 500 Abarth can hit nearly $30,000, which is simply too much for this little car. Especially since competitors are larger, offer more refinement and, in the case of the Ford Focus ST, cost less.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: With a starting price around $24,000, value is an Abarth shortcoming. In this price range, you can get either better performance or a nicer car. You'll buy the Abarth simply because you love the way it looks or sounds. Maybe both.
title: Cost

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: An EPA rating of 30 mpg combined (28 city/34 highway) is encouraging, but we only averaged 22 mpg while the car was with us. On our 116-mile evaluation loop we managed a respectable 31.8 mpg.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: With a starting price around $24,000, value is an Abarth shortcoming. In this price range, you can get either better performance or a nicer car. You'll buy the Abarth simply because you love the way it looks or sounds. Maybe both.
title: MPG

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: The basic and powertrain warranties cover the car for 4 years/50,000 miles, both of which are typical for cars in this class. Extended coverage is offered at additional cost.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: With a starting price around $24,000, value is an Abarth shortcoming. In this price range, you can get either better performance or a nicer car. You'll buy the Abarth simply because you love the way it looks or sounds. Maybe both.
title: Warranty

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: Roadside assistance is offered for four years with unlimited mileage, which is slightly above average. No free maintenance is available. Mini comes standard with three years free maintenance.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: With a starting price around $24,000, value is an Abarth shortcoming. In this price range, you can get either better performance or a nicer car. You'll buy the Abarth simply because you love the way it looks or sounds. Maybe both.
title: Ownership

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: If the Abarth felt quicker out on the road it would be easier to justify the raucous exhaust note. It looks and sounds the part, yes, but it doesn't deliver a great driving experience, whether on canyon roads or the daily commute.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: Being fun to drive is the Abarth's biggest selling point. The manual transmission is better than the automatic. It makes good sounds and manhandles traffic. Still, you'll probably have more fun in a Mini Cooper S or Ford Fiesta ST.
title: Driving Experience

make.name: FIAT
style.name: Abarth 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: There's planty of personality here. It's quirky, unusual, fun and loud in every way. Plan on being looked at in the Abarth. The exhaust note gets people's attention, while the car's visuals hold their stares afterward.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: Being fun to drive is the Abarth's biggest selling point. The manual transmission is better than the automatic. It makes good sounds and manhandles traffic. Still, you'll probably have more fun in a Mini Cooper S or Ford Fiesta ST.
title: Personality

make.name: FIAT
style.name: t Turbo 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: Front seat comfort is good, but lateral support and a passenger armrest are lacking. It's off-putting that the steering wheel is off-center. Rear seats are sized only for kids.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: The 500 T's ride comfort is far better than a Mini Cooper with the Sport package, but seating is lacking for a sporty hatch. Overall, considering its abilities, comfort is good.
title: Seating Comfort

make.name: FIAT
style.name: t Turbo 2dr Hatchback (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: One of the best-riding compact cars available; never busy, bouncy, or nervous. Really. This is truly a remarkable achievement considering its stubby proportions and sporty tires.
ratings.title: Comfort

summary: The 500 T's growly exhaust is evident by design, adding character but not droning annoyingly on the freeway.

ratings.summary: The 500 T's ride comfort is far better than a Mini Cooper with the Sport package, but seating is lacking for a sporty hatch. Overall, considering its abilities, comfort is good.

summary: There's not a single knob on the Fiat's dash, not even audio volume: big mistake. Other problems include unintuitive, crowded, busy instrumentation and strange button locations.

ratings.summary: Interior design is challenging at best with questionable ergonomics, cramped quarters, and barely enough cargo capacity for an overnighter.

ratings.summary: Interior design is challenging at best with questionable ergonomics, cramped quarters, and barely enough cargo capacity for an overnighter.

summary: One expects good visibility in compact car, yet its chunky middle roof-pillar inhibits over-the-shoulder glances and large rear roof-pillar hides cars, too.

ratings.summary: Interior design is challenging at best with questionable ergonomics, cramped quarters, and barely enough cargo capacity for an overnighter.

summary: The 135-hp 1.4L Turbo provides brisk acceleration from low rpm, but also has an entertainingly high redline and vastly improved manual shifter from previous 500s.

make.name: FIAT
style.name: C Abarth 2dr Convertible (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: The Abarth reached 60 mph in 7.5 sec., about 1 sec. slower than the Cooper S. Considerable turbo lag from the 1.4-liter 4-cyl. leaving a stoplight is followed by a nice hit of power. Shifts from the optional 6-sp. automatic are quick.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The Abarth may look and sound the performance part, but its actions don't back up the bravado. With 157 horsepower, you can spin the front tires at full throttle. But in terms of instrumented acceleration numbers it can barely keep up with the base Mini Cooper, let alone the "S" model.
title: Acceleration

make.name: FIAT
style.name: C Abarth 2dr Convertible (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: Stopping from 60 mph required 125 feet, which is typical for cars with all-season tires. There was noticeable side-to-side wiggle during our panic-brake test, making it feel a bit unsettled.
ratings.title: Performance

ratings.title: Performance

But in terms of instrumented acceleration numbers it can barely keep up with the base Mini Cooper, let alone the "S" model.

make.name: FIAT
style.name: C Abarth 2dr Convertible (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: Compared to its rivals, the Abarth is less sporty on a curvy road. It feels top-heavy and the front tires frequently wash out and struggle to regain traction. It doesn't instill confidence like its competitors.
ratings.title: Performance

But in terms of instrumented acceleration numbers it can barely keep up with the base Mini Cooper, let alone the "S" model.

make.name: FIAT
style.name: C Abarth 2dr Convertible (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: Hesitation on initial acceleration gets frustrating; the car works better with the manual transmission. The Sport button livens things up. The massive space needed for U-turns (37.6-ft. turning circle) makes it poor for tight city driving.
