title: Driveability

make.name: FIAT
style.name: C Abarth 2dr Convertible (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: Average-size adults will find the lack of a telescoping steering wheel forces them to sit closer and more upright than preferred. The contour at the top of the seatback also created an uncomfortable pressure point for some drivers.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: Limitations to seat and steering wheel adjustability compromise comfort, plus the contouring of the front seat will bother some drivers. The lack of adequate elbow padding and the drone of the engine/exhaust further hurt comfort scores. The ride quality is decent enough.
title: Seating Comfort

make.name: FIAT
style.name: C Abarth 2dr Convertible (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: Despite its sporty intentions, the Abarth's ride quality isn't overly firm. You do feel flaws in the pavement, but the 500 rarely comes across as harsh or overly intrusive. Moderate undulations will cause some jostling, for sure.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: Limitations to seat and steering wheel adjustability compromise comfort, plus the contouring of the front seat will bother some drivers. The lack of adequate elbow padding and the drone of the engine/exhaust further hurt comfort scores. The ride quality is decent enough.
title: Ride Comfort

make.name: FIAT
style.name: C Abarth 2dr Convertible (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: Purely for the fun of it, the Abarth's exhaust is loud, with only minor reward in terms of actual power. For some, this booming baritone will seem tiresome. Others will dig it. It was hard to detect road and wind noise over the commotion.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: Limitations to seat and steering wheel adjustability compromise comfort, plus the contouring of the front seat will bother some drivers. The lack of adequate elbow padding and the drone of the engine/exhaust further hurt comfort scores. The ride quality is decent enough.
title: Quietness

make.name: FIAT
style.name: C Abarth 2dr Convertible (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: Primary controls are simple in terms of layout and operation, but they're also limited in functionality. Searching for music on external devices is difficult at best and the TomTom navigation system requires your full attention to operate.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: While the 500's minimalist interior has a certain retro design appeal, it also serves to limit the functionality of many systems. Navigation and audio systems are as primitive as they get nowadays and the limited cargo/passenger space leave it trailing rivals by a considerable margin.
title: Ergonomics

make.name: FIAT
style.name: C Abarth 2dr Convertible (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: The doors are short in length for easy access in tight spots, and they open wide. The narrow opening to the rear seat means it's near impossible for adults to crawl back there. Even if you can do it, you'll look/feel awkward.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: While the 500's minimalist interior has a certain retro design appeal, it also serves to limit the functionality of many systems. Navigation and audio systems are as primitive as they get nowadays and the limited cargo/passenger space leave it trailing rivals by a considerable margin.
title: Ingress/Egress

make.name: FIAT
style.name: C Abarth 2dr Convertible (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: Average-size adults will feel confined up front, especially width-wise if there is a front-seat passenger. The hard center console can protrude into the side of the driver's right knee. Rear seats are suitable for children only.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: While the 500's minimalist interior has a certain retro design appeal, it also serves to limit the functionality of many systems. Navigation and audio systems are as primitive as they get nowadays and the limited cargo/passenger space leave it trailing rivals by a considerable margin.
title: Space/Room

make.name: FIAT
style.name: C Abarth 2dr Convertible (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: All-around visibility is good with the top up, but no rearview camera is offered. When the top is fully retracted it severely blocks the view rearward to the point that even large city busses can be hidden from view.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: While the 500's minimalist interior has a certain retro design appeal, it also serves to limit the functionality of many systems. Navigation and audio systems are as primitive as they get nowadays and the limited cargo/passenger space leave it trailing rivals by a considerable margin.
title: Visibility

make.name: FIAT
style.name: C Abarth 2dr Convertible (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: The 5.4-cu-ft trunk is nearly half the capacity of the hatchback model, the tiny opening hampering usefulness. It's a struggle to get a carry-on suitcase to fit. Interior storage is minimal with shallow door pockets and cramped cupholders.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: While the 500's minimalist interior has a certain retro design appeal, it also serves to limit the functionality of many systems. Navigation and audio systems are as primitive as they get nowadays and the limited cargo/passenger space leave it trailing rivals by a considerable margin.
title: Cargo/Storage

make.name: FIAT
style.name: C Abarth 2dr Convertible (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: It's hard to consider the fabric roof panel a true convertible top, since it's more like a retractable panoramic sunroof. Folded back, it completely obscures the rearward view and blocks access to the trunk.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: While the 500's minimalist interior has a certain retro design appeal, it also serves to limit the functionality of many systems. Navigation and audio systems are as primitive as they get nowadays and the limited cargo/passenger space leave it trailing rivals by a considerable margin.
title: Convertible Top

make.name: FIAT
style.name: C Abarth 2dr Convertible (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: Hard plastics are more prevalent in the Fiat 500 than in its competition. The surfaces feel flimsy feel and have a tendency to creak. For the most part, the interior falls short of the standard set by the Mini Cooper.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Looking exclusively at price, the Fiat 500 Abarth may be an attractive alternative to more expensive rivals. But its deficit in performance, features and quality cannot be recovered. We're confident you'll be happier in the long run with a pricier competitor.
title: Build Quality (vs. $)

make.name: FIAT
style.name: C Abarth 2dr Convertible (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: The 500 doesn't offer a lot of options or additional safety features but is less expensive than most rivals. Standard features include rear parking sensors, tilt steering wheel, Bluetooth, height-adjustable driver seat and power mirrors.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Looking exclusively at price, the Fiat 500 Abarth may be an attractive alternative to more expensive rivals. But its deficit in performance, features and quality cannot be recovered. We're confident you'll be happier in the long run with a pricier competitor.
title: Features(vs. $)

make.name: FIAT
style.name: C Abarth 2dr Convertible (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: With the $1,350 6-sp. automatic transmission, premium audio, TomTom navigation, automatic climate control, satellite radio and upgraded wheels, the as-tested price rose to $31,795. Cheaper than some rivals but lacking their refinement.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Looking exclusively at price, the Fiat 500 Abarth may be an attractive alternative to more expensive rivals. But its deficit in performance, features and quality cannot be recovered. We're confident you'll be happier in the long run with a pricier competitor.
title: Cost

make.name: FIAT
style.name: C Abarth 2dr Convertible (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: The EPA estimates the Abarth at 27 mpg combined (24 city/32 highway) with the 6-sp. automatic. The 5-speed manual is rated at 30 mpg combined (28 city/34 highway). We only averaged 20.4 mpg overall with a best highway result of 28.9 mpg.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Looking exclusively at price, the Fiat 500 Abarth may be an attractive alternative to more expensive rivals. But its deficit in performance, features and quality cannot be recovered. We're confident you'll be happier in the long run with a pricier competitor.
title: MPG

make.name: FIAT
style.name: C Abarth 2dr Convertible (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: The basic and powertrain warranties cover the car for 4 years/50,000 miles, both of which are typical for cars in this class. Extended coverage is offered at additional cost.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Looking exclusively at price, the Fiat 500 Abarth may be an attractive alternative to more expensive rivals. But its deficit in performance, features and quality cannot be recovered. We're confident you'll be happier in the long run with a pricier competitor.
title: Warranty

make.name: FIAT
style.name: C Abarth 2dr Convertible (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: Roadside assistance is offered for four years with unlimited mileage, which is slightly above average. No free maintenance is available. Mini comes standard with three years free maintenance.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Looking exclusively at price, the Fiat 500 Abarth may be an attractive alternative to more expensive rivals. But its deficit in performance, features and quality cannot be recovered. We're confident you'll be happier in the long run with a pricier competitor.
title: Ownership

make.name: FIAT
style.name: C Abarth 2dr Convertible (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: If the Abarth were quicker, it would be easier to justify the raucous exhaust note. It looks and sounds the part, yes, but it doesn't deliver a great driving experience, whether on canyon roads or the daily commute.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: The Fiat 500 Abarth misses the performance mark set by other similarly-sized sporty cars. It fails to instill confidence when driven aggressively, and the late power delivery, while ample, makes the engine less driver-friendly than others in the class.
title: Driving Experience

make.name: FIAT
style.name: C Abarth 2dr Convertible (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 5M)
summary: The Abarth Convertible has personality, from the sporty styling to the throaty exhaust to the fabric roof. Many will enjoy -- and buy -- the car for just those reasons. Others will be disappointed by the Abarth's lack of driving dynamics.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: The Fiat 500 Abarth misses the performance mark set by other similarly-sized sporty cars. It fails to instill confidence when driven aggressively, and the late power delivery, while ample, makes the engine less driver-friendly than others in the class.
title: Personality

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500L
style.name: Lounge 4dr Wagon (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 6AM)
summary: With a 160-horsepower 1.4-liter 4-cylinder turbo, the 500L posted a 9.3-second run to 60 mph. But rather than delivering predictable, linear behavior, the engine surges oddly and the transmission often feels out of step.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: On the positive side, the Fiat 500L has direct steering. Otherwise, the engine produces only adequate power delivered in surprising surges, the transmission is indecisive, the brakes are grabby, and as a result, the overall driveability is poor.
title: Acceleration

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500L
style.name: Lounge 4dr Wagon (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 6AM)
summary: The 500L's brake pedal is hard to predict and modulate with numb feedback, lack of initial response, and then abrupt and grabby effectiveness. In a simulated panic stop from 60 mph, the 500L required 120 feet, which is average.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: On the positive side, the Fiat 500L has direct steering. Otherwise, the engine produces only adequate power delivered in surprising surges, the transmission is indecisive, the brakes are grabby, and as a result, the overall driveability is poor.
title: Braking

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500L
style.name: Lounge 4dr Wagon (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 6AM)
summary: At speed, the steering is direct and precise and offers reasonable feel for the road, though it has a bit of a springy sensation to it. Easy effort for parking and good straight stability at highway speeds.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: On the positive side, the Fiat 500L has direct steering. Otherwise, the engine produces only adequate power delivered in surprising surges, the transmission is indecisive, the brakes are grabby, and as a result, the overall driveability is poor.
title: Steering

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500L
style.name: Lounge 4dr Wagon (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 6AM)
summary: You can hustle the 500L without it being unsafe, but it isn't rewarding or quick-reacting. The limits are modest and they end in predictable understeer that the driver can't correct easily. ESC tuning is aggressive and poorly executed.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: On the positive side, the Fiat 500L has direct steering. Otherwise, the engine produces only adequate power delivered in surprising surges, the transmission is indecisive, the brakes are grabby, and as a result, the overall driveability is poor.
title: Handling

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500L
style.name: Lounge 4dr Wagon (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 6AM)
summary: Surging acceleration, occasional sluggishness, unpredictable brakes and an indecisive transmission make this a frustrating vehicle to drive during passing maneuvers, in traffic or even if you're just trying to hold a certain speed.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: On the positive side, the Fiat 500L has direct steering. Otherwise, the engine produces only adequate power delivered in surprising surges, the transmission is indecisive, the brakes are grabby, and as a result, the overall driveability is poor.
title: Driveability

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500L
style.name: Lounge 4dr Wagon (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 6AM)
summary: Front seats offer a good range of adjustability and lumbar support, but are overly firm and wide with short seat bottoms. Rear seats are rather upright, too firm for most and lack recline adjustment.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: Comfortable for short-trip, in-town use, but on the highway its firm seats, springy suspension and ever-present wind noise (and sometimes tire noise) don't provide for long-haul comfort.
title: Seating Comfort

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500L
style.name: Lounge 4dr Wagon (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 6AM)
summary: Ride comfort is highly surface- and speed-dependent: Good on perfect asphalt roads, but busy and bouncy on uneven roads at any speed. Harsh over real bumps. Steering wheel vibrates with speed of engine.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: Comfortable for short-trip, in-town use, but on the highway its firm seats, springy suspension and ever-present wind noise (and sometimes tire noise) don't provide for long-haul comfort.
title: Ride Comfort

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500L
style.name: Lounge 4dr Wagon (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 6AM)
summary: Again, speed- and surface-dependent: Engine is inconspicuous most of the time, but gets thrashy at higher rpm. Tires hum on coarse surfaces, and wind noise (mirrors and windshield) is constantly present, especially at highway speeds.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: Comfortable for short-trip, in-town use, but on the highway its firm seats, springy suspension and ever-present wind noise (and sometimes tire noise) don't provide for long-haul comfort.
title: Quietness

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500L
style.name: Lounge 4dr Wagon (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 6AM)
summary: Parking brake handle hidden beneath armrest, preventing easy use. Trip computer button at end of wiper stalk is weird, but large air-conditioning knobs, legible displays and logical placement of most controls make the 500L easy to operate.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: The 500L creates some unique problems all its own: Commanding view out the front is hampered by double A-pillars. Unconventional parking brake handle is good ergonomically, but obscured by center armrest. Rear seats fold to expand cargo, but don't offer a flat load floor.
title: Ergonomics

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500L
style.name: Lounge 4dr Wagon (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 6AM)
summary: Doors lack obvious detents but offer good access to the seats, which are at a convenient height. Door sills are wide and grab handles are provided above each door. Rear seats slide fore/aft and tumble, but curiously don't fold flat.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: The 500L creates some unique problems all its own: Commanding view out the front is hampered by double A-pillars. Unconventional parking brake handle is good ergonomically, but obscured by center armrest. Rear seats fold to expand cargo, but don't offer a flat load floor.
title: Ingress/Egress

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500L
style.name: Lounge 4dr Wagon (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 6AM)
summary: Because the ceiling is quite high (and feels infinitely so with the optional glass roof), there's a feeling of openness. Yet the 500L doesn't provide the imagined space inside promised by its boxy exterior, particularly in the rear seat.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: The 500L creates some unique problems all its own: Commanding view out the front is hampered by double A-pillars. Unconventional parking brake handle is good ergonomically, but obscured by center armrest. Rear seats fold to expand cargo, but don't offer a flat load floor.
title: Space/Room

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500L
style.name: Lounge 4dr Wagon (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 6AM)
summary: We appreciate the design idea of double A-pillars, but in practice there are four pillars where there could be two. Optional rear parking sensors and backup camera ease reversing anxiety.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: The 500L creates some unique problems all its own: Commanding view out the front is hampered by double A-pillars. Unconventional parking brake handle is good ergonomically, but obscured by center armrest. Rear seats fold to expand cargo, but don't offer a flat load floor.
title: Visibility

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500L
style.name: Lounge 4dr Wagon (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 6AM)
summary: The 500L beats its direct competitor, the Mini Cooper Countryman, in total space (68 vs 42 cubes) and behind-the-seat space (22.4 vs 16.5). Small-item storage is ok, with decent-sized cupholders, but door pockets and front bin are small.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: The 500L creates some unique problems all its own: Commanding view out the front is hampered by double A-pillars. Unconventional parking brake handle is good ergonomically, but obscured by center armrest. Rear seats fold to expand cargo, but don't offer a flat load floor.
title: Cargo/Storage

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500L
style.name: Lounge 4dr Wagon (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 6AM)
summary: The 500L felt reasonably solid, however we had non-operational air conditioning during our loan and some stalks, buttons and levers felt hollow.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Decent standard features and fuel economy are compromised by unknown ownership experience and so-so warranty coverage.
title: Build Quality (vs. $)

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500L
style.name: Lounge 4dr Wagon (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 6AM)
summary: Our test car had $3,050 in options: black roof paint, power glass roof, premium audio, compact spare, 17-inch painted aluminum wheels. The total was $28,245, which is a little hard to justify. Mini offers AWD for this price.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Decent standard features and fuel economy are compromised by unknown ownership experience and so-so warranty coverage.
title: Features(vs. $)

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500L
style.name: Lounge 4dr Wagon (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 6AM)
summary: The Lounge trim comes with dual-zone climate, heated front seats, media hub (SD, USB and Auxiliary), satellite radio, navigation, rear park sensors, rearview camera and Bluetooth for around $25,000. Fair compared to like vehicles.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Decent standard features and fuel economy are compromised by unknown ownership experience and so-so warranty coverage.
title: Cost

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500L
style.name: Lounge 4dr Wagon (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 6AM)
summary: The 500L is rated by the EPA at 27 mpg combined (24 city/33 highway). We managed 31.2 mpg on the Edmunds evaluation loop, and 24.8 mpg over the car's 512-mile stay with us.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Decent standard features and fuel economy are compromised by unknown ownership experience and so-so warranty coverage.
title: MPG

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500L
style.name: Lounge 4dr Wagon (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 6AM)
summary: Both the basic warranty and the drivetrain coverage last for 4 years/50,000 miles, which are decent for the segment. Rust coverage is for 5 years/100,000 miles.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Decent standard features and fuel economy are compromised by unknown ownership experience and so-so warranty coverage.
title: Warranty

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500L
style.name: Lounge 4dr Wagon (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 6AM)
summary: The 500L includes roadside assistance for 4 years/50,000 miles, including flat-tire repair, fuel rescue, battery jump, lockout and towing. That's a solid benefit.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Decent standard features and fuel economy are compromised by unknown ownership experience and so-so warranty coverage.
title: Ownership

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500L
style.name: Lounge 4dr Wagon (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 6AM)
summary: Unpleasant and unpredictable. From a steering wheel that vibrates with the speed of the engine, to a surging powertrain and unresponsive-then-grabby brakes, the 500L misses the mark from multiple angles.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: The Fiat 500L just isn't a rewarding car to drive. Its tall, fun-resistant chassis wasn't made for cornering. Its powertrain doesnâ€™t engage in any significant way. This is little more than a family hauler with Italian styling.
title: Driving Experience

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500L
style.name: Lounge 4dr Wagon (1.4L 4cyl Turbo 6AM)
summary: If you like the look and personality of a London taxi, but not the seating nor cargo capacity of one, the 500L could be worth a look. The car is definitely unique but there isn't a whole lot about it that makes us want to own one.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: The Fiat 500L just isn't a rewarding car to drive. Its tall, fun-resistant chassis wasn't made for cornering. Its powertrain doesnâ€™t engage in any significant way. This is little more than a family hauler with Italian styling.
title: Personality

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500X
style.name: Lounge 4dr SUV (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: Feels average around town thanks to punchy throttle response and good low-end torque. But ring it out, and it's surprisingly slow given its 180 hp. Its 0-60 time of 9 seconds is disappointing.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: With 180-horsepower (about 30-40 more than rivals), we thought the 500X would be the segment track star. It isn't. Not bad, just disappointing. Which is how we'd describe the dynamic skills of the 500X in general. The unrefined nine-speed automatic is one area that clearly needs work.
title: Acceleration

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500X
style.name: Lounge 4dr SUV (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: Firm, notably responsive pedal with good modulation and feedback. A fair bit of nose dive in a panic stop and around town. Stopped from 60 mph in 121 feet -- an average distance -- with some brake wiggle.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: With 180-horsepower (about 30-40 more than rivals), we thought the 500X would be the segment track star. It isn't. Not bad, just disappointing. Which is how we'd describe the dynamic skills of the 500X in general. The unrefined nine-speed automatic is one area that clearly needs work.
title: Braking

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500X
style.name: Lounge 4dr SUV (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: A little tight on center, especially in Sport mode (the stiffer of two effort levels), but generally precise with a decent amount of feedback. The wheel is chunky, which may bother those with smaller hands.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: With 180-horsepower (about 30-40 more than rivals), we thought the 500X would be the segment track star. It isn't. Not bad, just disappointing. Which is how we'd describe the dynamic skills of the 500X in general. The unrefined nine-speed automatic is one area that clearly needs work.
title: Steering

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500X
style.name: Lounge 4dr SUV (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: The 500X was hampered at our test track by an overly eager stability control system and a predilection for understeer. In the real world it feels more nimble -- certainly more so than most larger "compact" SUVs -- but less so than the more size-appropriate competition.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: With 180-horsepower (about 30-40 more than rivals), we thought the 500X would be the segment track star. It isn't. Not bad, just disappointing. Which is how we'd describe the dynamic skills of the 500X in general. The unrefined nine-speed automatic is one area that clearly needs work.
title: Handling

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500X
style.name: Lounge 4dr SUV (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: The nine-speed automatic doesn't hunt for gears and does a good job of staying in the right gear when driving aggressively. But, it can result in iritating jerky motions at slow speeds, especially when the system is cold.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: With 180-horsepower (about 30-40 more than rivals), we thought the 500X would be the segment track star. It isn't. Not bad, just disappointing. Which is how we'd describe the dynamic skills of the 500X in general. The unrefined nine-speed automatic is one area that clearly needs work.
title: Driveability

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500X
style.name: Lounge 4dr SUV (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: Although our test car lacked all-wheel drive, there was still a driver-selectable setting that maximizes myriad vehicle functions for inclement weather. A decent 7 inches of ground clearance with FWD, and even more (7.9) with AWD.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: With 180-horsepower (about 30-40 more than rivals), we thought the 500X would be the segment track star. It isn't. Not bad, just disappointing. Which is how we'd describe the dynamic skills of the 500X in general. The unrefined nine-speed automatic is one area that clearly needs work.
title: Off-Road

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500X
style.name: Lounge 4dr SUV (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: Enormous seat adjustment range with eight-way power driver seat. Drivers 5-feet to 6-foot-5 can fit comfortably. Impressive for a small vehicle. Seats themselves are firm, supportive, good over distance. Rear seat does not recline.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: The ride may be a bit rough for some, but it shouldn't be objectionable if you're used to a more firmly sprung car. Seat comfort is excellent and benefits from ample adjustment (including rare passenger height adjustment). Engine noise is impressively quelled.
title: Seating Comfort

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500X
style.name: Lounge 4dr SUV (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: Even on small 17-inch wheels, the ride is firm and stiff-legged. Can be harsh over potholes, but there's also not a lot of cushioning over bumps and undulations. It feels very solid, though, never jittery.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: The ride may be a bit rough for some, but it shouldn't be objectionable if you're used to a more firmly sprung car. Seat comfort is excellent and benefits from ample adjustment (including rare passenger height adjustment). Engine noise is impressively quelled.
title: Ride Comfort

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500X
style.name: Lounge 4dr SUV (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: The engine is noticeably loud on the outside, but can barely be heard inside. Sound isn't objectionable when you wring it out. Competitive wind and road noise for the segment.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: The ride may be a bit rough for some, but it shouldn't be objectionable if you're used to a more firmly sprung car. Seat comfort is excellent and benefits from ample adjustment (including rare passenger height adjustment). Engine noise is impressively quelled.
title: Quietness

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500X
style.name: Lounge 4dr SUV (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: Touchscreen is smaller version of same superior interface found in other Fiat-Chrysler vehicles. Easy to figure out and use, though it may be a bit of a reach for some. Climate controls are big, simple and easy to reach.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Once again, a Fiat-Chrylser group vehicle benefits greatly from the company's excellent touchscreen interface. Cargo and rear passenger space are limited and less than most compact hatchbacks, but that's the case for almost all its sub-compact SUV competitors.
title: Ergonomics

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500X
style.name: Lounge 4dr SUV (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: Elevated ride and seat height makes it easy to climb into the 500X's driver seat. The sloped roofline does increase the chances of hitting your head when climbing in back, but it's not what we'd call a major hindrance.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Once again, a Fiat-Chrylser group vehicle benefits greatly from the company's excellent touchscreen interface. Cargo and rear passenger space are limited and less than most compact hatchbacks, but that's the case for almost all its sub-compact SUV competitors.
title: Ingress/Egress

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500X
style.name: Lounge 4dr SUV (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: Abundance of front legroom, but rear legroom is entirely dependant on how far back the front seats are. Typical for the segment. Rear seat headroom is just OK, at least without the dual-pane sunroof.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Once again, a Fiat-Chrylser group vehicle benefits greatly from the company's excellent touchscreen interface. Cargo and rear passenger space are limited and less than most compact hatchbacks, but that's the case for almost all its sub-compact SUV competitors.
title: Space/Room

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500X
style.name: Lounge 4dr SUV (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: You feel higher up than in some rivals. There are large side windows and mirrors, but chunky C-D pillars. A rearview camera and blind-spot warning are available on most trims; lane-departure and collision warning are in pricier packages.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Once again, a Fiat-Chrylser group vehicle benefits greatly from the company's excellent touchscreen interface. Cargo and rear passenger space are limited and less than most compact hatchbacks, but that's the case for almost all its sub-compact SUV competitors.
title: Visibility

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500X
style.name: Lounge 4dr SUV (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: Tiny cargo volume, but typical for the segment. Four small, but useful bins up front with usable cup/bottle holders. Sloped roofline requires the folding of 60/40 seats to carry bulky items, but floor can be lowered for more space.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Once again, a Fiat-Chrylser group vehicle benefits greatly from the company's excellent touchscreen interface. Cargo and rear passenger space are limited and less than most compact hatchbacks, but that's the case for almost all its sub-compact SUV competitors.
title: Cargo/Storage

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500X
style.name: Lounge 4dr SUV (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: The as-tested Lounge trim had lovely leather/cloth upholstery with white-painted dash trim. Other materials are soft-touch or at least nicely textured; switchgear feels solid (other than the turn signal). Better than some bigger SUVs.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Although other Fiats have reportedly suffered from reliability issues, the 500X's other value-related elements are quite compelling. Its interior, equipment and fuel economy are either competitive or better than its competition. Its warranty is sufficient, but not exactly reassuring.
title: Build Quality (vs. $)

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500X
style.name: Lounge 4dr SUV (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: Lots of features for your money. As-tested FWD Lounge trim ($26,100) included navigation, partial leather, power driver seat, heated wheel and front seats, keyless start, climate control and touchscreen interface. AWD adds $1,900.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Although other Fiats have reportedly suffered from reliability issues, the 500X's other value-related elements are quite compelling. Its interior, equipment and fuel economy are either competitive or better than its competition. Its warranty is sufficient, but not exactly reassuring.
title: Features(vs. $)

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500X
style.name: Lounge 4dr SUV (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: A compact hatchback or lesser-equipped "compact" SUV will yield more space and perhaps more compelling performance. But as far as sub-compact SUVs go, this Fiat is very competitively priced and includes many welcome features.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Although other Fiats have reportedly suffered from reliability issues, the 500X's other value-related elements are quite compelling. Its interior, equipment and fuel economy are either competitive or better than its competition. Its warranty is sufficient, but not exactly reassuring.
title: Cost

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500X
style.name: Lounge 4dr SUV (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: EPA ratings of 25 mpg combined (22 city/31 highway) with FWD are MUCH lower than Honda HR-V and Subaru XV, but similar to the Kia Soul. Still, we achieved an impressive 32.3 mpg on our 116-mile Edmunds evaluation route.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Although other Fiats have reportedly suffered from reliability issues, the 500X's other value-related elements are quite compelling. Its interior, equipment and fuel economy are either competitive or better than its competition. Its warranty is sufficient, but not exactly reassuring.
title: MPG

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500X
style.name: Lounge 4dr SUV (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: Four-year/50,000-mile basic warranty is longer than most competitors, but same time/mileage period for powertrain coverage is unremarkable and hardly reassuring given Fiat's reportedly spotty reliability.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Although other Fiats have reportedly suffered from reliability issues, the 500X's other value-related elements are quite compelling. Its interior, equipment and fuel economy are either competitive or better than its competition. Its warranty is sufficient, but not exactly reassuring.
title: Warranty

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500X
style.name: Lounge 4dr SUV (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: Four-year/50,000-mile roadside assistance coverage, which is welcome. No included scheduled maintenance.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Although other Fiats have reportedly suffered from reliability issues, the 500X's other value-related elements are quite compelling. Its interior, equipment and fuel economy are either competitive or better than its competition. Its warranty is sufficient, but not exactly reassuring.
title: Ownership

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500X
style.name: Lounge 4dr SUV (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: For those buying the 500X simply for its style and character, the driving experience will not disappoint. It gets the job done. However, if you were hoping for some dynamic go to match the show, you'll be let down. The Mazda CX-3 bests it handily in driving dynamics.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: There is certainly more fun to be found in the Fiat 500X than in bigger, more family-friendly "compact" SUVs like a Honda CR-V. It has unique style inside and out, and its small dimensions certainly create a sense of nimbleness. Really, though, it's less fun to drive than it looks.
title: Driving Experience

make.name: FIAT
model.name: 500X
style.name: Lounge 4dr SUV (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: Many of its sub-compact competitors are spunkier than their bigger, more family-friendly brand mates, but this little Fiat nevertheless goes further with distinctive styling, materials and overall character.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: There is certainly more fun to be found in the Fiat 500X than in bigger, more family-friendly "compact" SUVs like a Honda CR-V. It has unique style inside and out, and its small dimensions certainly create a sense of nimbleness. Really, though, it's less fun to drive than it looks.
title: Personality

make.name: Ford
model.name: C-Max Energi
style.name: SEL 4dr Wagon (2.0L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: Auto mode engages engine seemlessly at full throttle; 0-60 in 7.8 seconds is quick. EV-only mode is insufficient for freeway merging (0-60 in this mode takes 14.8-seconds).
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The C-Max Energi steers and brakes with the same poise and responsiveness as other confidence-inspiring Fords. EV mode is fine around town, but Auto mode is the most versatile (the engine stays on stand-by should you need to step on it).
title: Acceleration

make.name: Ford
model.name: C-Max Energi
style.name: SEL 4dr Wagon (2.0L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: The C-Max Energi avoids the grabby pedal action of most other hybrids. Feels very natural. Its 125-foot 0-60 mph stop is average for hatchbacks/small SUVs.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The C-Max Energi steers and brakes with the same poise and responsiveness as other confidence-inspiring Fords. EV mode is fine around town, but Auto mode is the most versatile (the engine stays on stand-by should you need to step on it).
title: Braking

make.name: Ford
model.name: C-Max Energi
style.name: SEL 4dr Wagon (2.0L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: The C-Max's steering is one of the best in its class: Feels natural, precise and engaging. Quite similar to other, sporty Fords.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The C-Max Energi steers and brakes with the same poise and responsiveness as other confidence-inspiring Fords. EV mode is fine around town, but Auto mode is the most versatile (the engine stays on stand-by should you need to step on it).
title: Steering

make.name: Ford
model.name: C-Max Energi
style.name: SEL 4dr Wagon (2.0L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: Its eco-friendly tires don't afford much grip and the body leans heavily when cornering, but it is a much better handler than the Prius. Feels connected to the road.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The C-Max Energi steers and brakes with the same poise and responsiveness as other confidence-inspiring Fords. EV mode is fine around town, but Auto mode is the most versatile (the engine stays on stand-by should you need to step on it).
title: Handling

make.name: Ford
model.name: C-Max Energi
style.name: SEL 4dr Wagon (2.0L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: Normal-feeling brakes and steering, and comparatively unobtrusive engine engagement yield a hybrid that doesn't feel alien. Smooth, quiet EV acceleration is a plus.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The C-Max Energi steers and brakes with the same poise and responsiveness as other confidence-inspiring Fords. EV mode is fine around town, but Auto mode is the most versatile (the engine stays on stand-by should you need to step on it).
title: Driveability

make.name: Ford
model.name: C-Max Energi
style.name: SEL 4dr Wagon (2.0L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: The C-Max provides well-contoured and supportive front seats (optional 8-way power, heating) that are mounted high. Rear seat doesn't recline; legroom sufficient for 6-footer.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: With comfortable seating for four (five in a pinch), a compliant ride and a very quiet interior, the C-Max Energi offers a more refined, livable alternative to the numb and lifeless hybrid you might expect.
title: Seating Comfort

make.name: Ford
model.name: C-Max Energi
style.name: SEL 4dr Wagon (2.0L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: Ride comfort suffers only slightly as the result of its responsive handling. We still prefer the C-Max's sophisticated, well-damped ride over an isolated and soft suspension.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: With comfortable seating for four (five in a pinch), a compliant ride and a very quiet interior, the C-Max Energi offers a more refined, livable alternative to the numb and lifeless hybrid you might expect.
title: Ride Comfort

make.name: Ford
model.name: C-Max Energi
style.name: SEL 4dr Wagon (2.0L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: The C-Max's interior is not only uncommonly quiet for a hybrid, but also for wagons and small SUVs in general. There's little powertrain and even less wind noise than expected.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: With comfortable seating for four (five in a pinch), a compliant ride and a very quiet interior, the C-Max Energi offers a more refined, livable alternative to the numb and lifeless hybrid you might expect.
title: Quietness

make.name: Ford
model.name: C-Max Energi
style.name: SEL 4dr Wagon (2.0L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: Controls are logically placed and shifter is of a traditional design. Feels less alien than other hybrids. MyFordTouch interface is improving but still complicated.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Expansive visibility and superb ease of entry/exit make C-Max Energi a great choice for older drivers. Tiny trunk is major drawback. Better than hybrid sedans like Fusion Energi, but much worse than vehicles of similar size and type.
title: Ergonomics

make.name: Ford
model.name: C-Max Energi
style.name: SEL 4dr Wagon (2.0L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: Large doors, high-mounted seats and very low sill make it extremely easy to get in and out. A great choice for seniors or those with mobility issues.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Expansive visibility and superb ease of entry/exit make C-Max Energi a great choice for older drivers. Tiny trunk is major drawback. Better than hybrid sedans like Fusion Energi, but much worse than vehicles of similar size and type.
title: Ingress/Egress

make.name: Ford
model.name: C-Max Energi
style.name: SEL 4dr Wagon (2.0L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: Palatial headroom everywhere. Abundant legroom up front with 8-way power seats; merely sufficient in the rear. No rear seat recline.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Expansive visibility and superb ease of entry/exit make C-Max Energi a great choice for older drivers. Tiny trunk is major drawback. Better than hybrid sedans like Fusion Energi, but much worse than vehicles of similar size and type.
title: Space/Room

make.name: Ford
model.name: C-Max Energi
style.name: SEL 4dr Wagon (2.0L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: Wide-open, greenhouse-like views forward and to the side, with mostly unencumbered rear view as well. Our tester included optional backup camera.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Expansive visibility and superb ease of entry/exit make C-Max Energi a great choice for older drivers. Tiny trunk is major drawback. Better than hybrid sedans like Fusion Energi, but much worse than vehicles of similar size and type.
title: Visibility

make.name: Ford
model.name: C-Max Energi
style.name: SEL 4dr Wagon (2.0L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: Pathetic trunk size given its passenger space. Battery halves the trunk height and creates an odd shelf above the folded backseat. OK for groceries. Two suitcases fit length-wise.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Expansive visibility and superb ease of entry/exit make C-Max Energi a great choice for older drivers. Tiny trunk is major drawback. Better than hybrid sedans like Fusion Energi, but much worse than vehicles of similar size and type.
title: Cargo/Storage

make.name: Ford
model.name: C-Max Energi
style.name: SEL 4dr Wagon (2.0L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: Like other modern Fords, it's built to a high standard. But the elevated price of the plug-in hybrid system makes it only acceptable for a $36,355 car.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: It's hard to do math that makes a plug-in hybrid pay for itself. But if you're determined to own a PHEV, the C-Max Energi presents a solid blend of features, space, build quality and driving experience relative to its competition.
title: Build Quality (vs. $)

make.name: Ford
model.name: C-Max Energi
style.name: SEL 4dr Wagon (2.0L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: Most of your money goes into the hybrid bits, but as-tested features are strong with heated leather and power seats, power liftgate, backup camera, keyless start, navigation, Sony audio.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: It's hard to do math that makes a plug-in hybrid pay for itself. But if you're determined to own a PHEV, the C-Max Energi presents a solid blend of features, space, build quality and driving experience relative to its competition.
title: Features(vs. $)

make.name: Ford
model.name: C-Max Energi
style.name: SEL 4dr Wagon (2.0L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: About $4,500 more than a C-Max Hybrid and has a smaller trunk. You'd be hard-pressed to recoup that money in fuel savings. Reasonably priced for a plug-in hybrid, though.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: It's hard to do math that makes a plug-in hybrid pay for itself. But if you're determined to own a PHEV, the C-Max Energi presents a solid blend of features, space, build quality and driving experience relative to its competition.
title: Cost

make.name: Ford
model.name: C-Max Energi
style.name: SEL 4dr Wagon (2.0L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: EPA estimates 100 mpg-e and 43 mpg combined. With a full battery, we got 41.4 mpg on our highway-heavy evaluation loop with 16.7 miles of EV range (mixed city and highway driving).
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: It's hard to do math that makes a plug-in hybrid pay for itself. But if you're determined to own a PHEV, the C-Max Energi presents a solid blend of features, space, build quality and driving experience relative to its competition.
title: MPG

make.name: Ford
model.name: C-Max Energi
style.name: SEL 4dr Wagon (2.0L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: 3-year/36,000-mile bumper-to-bumper, 5-year/60,000-mile powertrain, 8-year/100,000-mile hybrid component warranties.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: It's hard to do math that makes a plug-in hybrid pay for itself. But if you're determined to own a PHEV, the C-Max Energi presents a solid blend of features, space, build quality and driving experience relative to its competition.
title: Warranty

make.name: Ford
model.name: C-Max Energi
style.name: SEL 4dr Wagon (2.0L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: A special 240-volt charger is not strictly necessary as the battery charges in 5-6 hours through a standard 120V outlet. And it is eligible for HOV lane access in certain states.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: It's hard to do math that makes a plug-in hybrid pay for itself. But if you're determined to own a PHEV, the C-Max Energi presents a solid blend of features, space, build quality and driving experience relative to its competition.
title: Ownership

make.name: Ford
model.name: C-Max Energi
style.name: SEL 4dr Wagon (2.0L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: The C-Max Energi drives like a well-sorted tall hatchback. The plug-in EV mode is quiet and serene, though, and the engine doesn't draw untoward attention to itself.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: Fun? Not by most traditional definitions, but certainly moreso than a Prius V. Still, its built-in efficiency coaching system is engaging and rewarding if you're inclined to play along.
title: Driving Experience

make.name: Ford
model.name: C-Max Energi
style.name: SEL 4dr Wagon (2.0L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: Hybrid funky styling -- some will flock to it, others will run away. Cabin is stylish either way. It certainly has more personality to drive than many other hybrids.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: Fun? Not by most traditional definitions, but certainly moreso than a Prius V. Still, its built-in efficiency coaching system is engaging and rewarding if you're inclined to play along.
title: Personality

make.name: Ford
model.name: Escape
style.name: SE 4dr SUV (1.6L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: The 1.6-liter, 173-horsepower Ecoboost engine is acceptably powerful and merely matches its competitors in this regard. Engine can feel strained.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The smaller turbo four-cylinder gives the Escape adequate acceleration. Like competitors, it sometimes lacks power. The transmission is a smooth operator, and the manual mode gives easy-to-access engine braking and rev-matched downshifts.
title: Acceleration

make.name: Ford
model.name: Escape
style.name: SE 4dr SUV (1.6L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: Solid, consistent brake performance. The Escape was very stable during our panic-simulation ABS stops. In everyday driving, the brakes offer linear response and feel.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The smaller turbo four-cylinder gives the Escape adequate acceleration. Like competitors, it sometimes lacks power. The transmission is a smooth operator, and the manual mode gives easy-to-access engine braking and rev-matched downshifts.
title: Braking

make.name: Ford
model.name: Escape
style.name: SE 4dr SUV (1.6L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: Typical electric-assist, artificial steering feel, which is the norm these days. Still, there's enough information here to make prudent decisions.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The smaller turbo four-cylinder gives the Escape adequate acceleration. Like competitors, it sometimes lacks power. The transmission is a smooth operator, and the manual mode gives easy-to-access engine braking and rev-matched downshifts.
title: Steering

make.name: Ford
model.name: Escape
style.name: SE 4dr SUV (1.6L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: FWD Escapes match their AWD counterparts in terms of handling prowess. The Escape is capable and confident and the stability-control system doesn't hurt ultimate grip or poise.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The smaller turbo four-cylinder gives the Escape adequate acceleration. Like competitors, it sometimes lacks power. The transmission is a smooth operator, and the manual mode gives easy-to-access engine braking and rev-matched downshifts.
title: Handling

make.name: Ford
model.name: Escape
style.name: SE 4dr SUV (1.6L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: No problems here. Smooth acceleration, relatively supple automatic transmission. Intuitive and lacking any obvious deficiencies.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The smaller turbo four-cylinder gives the Escape adequate acceleration. Like competitors, it sometimes lacks power. The transmission is a smooth operator, and the manual mode gives easy-to-access engine braking and rev-matched downshifts.
title: Driveability

make.name: Ford
model.name: Escape
style.name: SE 4dr SUV (1.6L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: We like the Escape's seats, as they provide all-day comfort. Heating (optional on some trim levels) is a nice touch.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: Overall comfort is good in the Escape. Its ride is amply compliant even though it's one of the better-handling SUVs in the segment.
title: Seating Comfort

make.name: Ford
model.name: Escape
style.name: SE 4dr SUV (1.6L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: The Escape has a surprisingly comfy ride. Surprising because it trades off very little in the way of ride quality in return for its excellent handling.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: Overall comfort is good in the Escape. Its ride is amply compliant even though it's one of the better-handling SUVs in the segment.
title: Ride Comfort

make.name: Ford
model.name: Escape
style.name: SE 4dr SUV (1.6L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: The Escape's turbo four-cylinder is much quieter than some competitors, especially at wide-open throttle.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: Overall comfort is good in the Escape. Its ride is amply compliant even though it's one of the better-handling SUVs in the segment.
title: Quietness

make.name: Ford
model.name: Escape
style.name: SE 4dr SUV (1.6L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: Commonly used controls are in reach and intuitive. Optional MyFord Touch infotainment and navigation interfaces are less successful.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: For the most part the interior makes sense and is easy to use. It's loaded with features (on the Titanium trim level). Good material and assembly quality.
title: Ergonomics

make.name: Ford
model.name: Escape
style.name: SE 4dr SUV (1.6L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: The seat height in the Escape is just right. Like most minivans, there's no bending down to get in, even though the Escape is a small crossover.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: For the most part the interior makes sense and is easy to use. It's loaded with features (on the Titanium trim level). Good material and assembly quality.
title: Ingress/Egress

make.name: Ford
model.name: Escape
style.name: SE 4dr SUV (1.6L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: We had no fitment problems within either the front or back seats, but there isn't a sense of spaciousness in the Escape like there is in the roomier Honda CR-V.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: For the most part the interior makes sense and is easy to use. It's loaded with features (on the Titanium trim level). Good material and assembly quality.
title: Space/Room

make.name: Ford
model.name: Escape
style.name: SE 4dr SUV (1.6L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: Front and rear visibility are only average, parking sensors are optional. The Escape is definitely not as airy or as easy to see out of as some of its competitors.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: For the most part the interior makes sense and is easy to use. It's loaded with features (on the Titanium trim level). Good material and assembly quality.
title: Visibility

make.name: Ford
model.name: Escape
style.name: SE 4dr SUV (1.6L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: The fold-flat 60/40-split rear seats and optional foot-activated power liftgate enhance cargo area. But the Escape doesn't have a cargo-mounted seatback release.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: For the most part the interior makes sense and is easy to use. It's loaded with features (on the Titanium trim level). Good material and assembly quality.
title: Cargo/Storage

make.name: Ford
model.name: Escape
style.name: SE 4dr SUV (1.6L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: Build quality is as good as one can expect in a vehicle in this price range. Materials appear durable and well put together.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Fully loaded, the EcoBoost escape is over $30,000, but is packed with features you'd expect at that price like a power liftgate, keyless entry, dual-zone climate control, Bluetooth and USB inputs.
title: Build Quality (vs. $)

make.name: Ford
model.name: Escape
style.name: SE 4dr SUV (1.6L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: You'll pay for them, but safety and technology features are available and abundant on the new Escape.
ratings.title: Value

model.name: Escape
style.name: SE 4dr SUV (1.6L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: Be careful when checking option boxes on the Escape. You can quickly run up the bill. Still, it's a lot of (small) SUV for the money.

model.name: Escape
style.name: SE 4dr SUV (1.6L 4cyl Turbo 6A)

summary: Quick enough, grippy, well-mannered and reasonably practical.

ratings.summary: The only compact crossover that's more fun-to-drive than this one is a more powerful, all-wheel-drive version Ford also sells. As is, the FWD 1.6L SE provides modest power, a real transmission, and good handling.

summary: The Escape's turbo four-cylinder is much quieter than some competitors, especially at wide-open throttle.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: Overall comfort is good in the Escape. Its ride is amply compliant even though it's one of the better-handling SUVs in the segment.
title: Quietness

make.name: Ford
model.name: Escape
style.name: SE 4dr SUV (1.6L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: Commonly used controls are in reach and intuitive. Optional MyFord Touch infotainment and navigation interfaces are less successful.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: For the most part the interior makes sense and is easy to use. It's loaded with features (on the Titanium trim level). Good material and assembly quality.
title: Ergonomics

make.name: Ford
model.name: Escape
style.name: SE 4dr SUV (1.6L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: The seat height in the Escape is just right. Like most minivans, there's no bending down to get in, even though the Escape is a small crossover.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: For the most part the interior makes sense and is easy to use. It's loaded with features (on the Titanium trim level). Good material and assembly quality.
title: Ingress/Egress

make.name: Ford
model.name: Escape
style.name: SE 4dr SUV (1.6L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: We had no fitment problems within either the front or back seats, but there isn't a sense of spaciousness in the Escape like there is in the roomier Honda CR-V.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: For the most part the interior makes sense and is easy to use. It's loaded with features (on the Titanium trim level). Good material and assembly quality.
title: Space/Room

make.name: Ford
model.name: Escape
style.name: SE 4dr SUV (1.6L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: Front and rear visibility are only average, parking sensors are optional. The Escape is definitely not as airy or as easy to see out of as some of its competitors.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: For the most part the interior makes sense and is easy to use. It's loaded with features (on the Titanium trim level). Good material and assembly quality.
title: Visibility

make.name: Ford
model.name: Escape
style.name: SE 4dr SUV (1.6L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: The fold-flat 60/40-split rear seats and optional foot-activated power liftgate enhance the cargo area to 68 cubic feet -- only marginally less than the class leader.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: For the most part the interior makes sense and is easy to use. It's loaded with features (on the Titanium trim level). Good material and assembly quality.
title: Cargo/Storage

make.name: Ford
model.name: Escape
style.name: SE 4dr SUV (1.6L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: Build quality is as good as one can expect in a vehicle in this price range. Materials appear durable and well put together.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Fully loaded, the EcoBoost escape is over $30,000, but is packed with the features -- and AWD -- you'd expect at that price.
title: Build Quality (vs. $)

make.name: Ford
model.name: Escape
style.name: SE 4dr SUV (1.6L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: You'll pay for them, but rear parking sensors and a blind-spot warning system are trim-specific options. The self-parking feature will serve those who hate parallel-parking.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Fully loaded, the EcoBoost escape is over $30,000, but is packed with the features -- and AWD -- you'd expect at that price.
title: Features(vs. $)

make.name: Ford
model.name: Escape
style.name: SE 4dr SUV (1.6L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: Be careful when checking option boxes on the Escape. You can quickly run up the bill. Still, it's a lot of (small) SUV for the money. Entry-level pricing is easily competitive.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Fully loaded, the EcoBoost escape is over $30,000, but is packed with the features -- and AWD -- you'd expect at that price.
title: Cost

make.name: Ford
model.name: Escape
style.name: SE 4dr SUV (1.6L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: The 1.6-liter FWD Escape is rated by the EPA at 26 mpg combined (23 city/32 highway). We measured 23.9 mpg in combined driving over 620 miles and witnessed 27.2 mpg on our 116-mile highway-heavy test loop.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Fully loaded, the EcoBoost escape is over $30,000, but is packed with the features -- and AWD -- you'd expect at that price.
title: MPG

make.name: Ford
model.name: Escape
style.name: SE 4dr SUV (1.6L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: The Escape offers average warranty coverage: 3 years/36,000 miles basic, 5 years/60,000 miles powertrain.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Fully loaded, the EcoBoost escape is over $30,000, but is packed with the features -- and AWD -- you'd expect at that price.
title: Warranty

make.name: Ford
model.name: Escape
style.name: SE 4dr SUV (1.6L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: Owners will appreciate the roadside assistance coverage of 5 years/60,000 miles.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Fully loaded, the EcoBoost escape is over $30,000, but is packed with the features -- and AWD -- you'd expect at that price.
title: Ownership

make.name: Ford
model.name: Escape
style.name: SE 4dr SUV (1.6L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: Quick enough, grippy, well-mannered and reasonably practical.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: The only compact crossover that's more fun-to-drive than this one is Mazda's CX-5. Still, the FWD 1.6L SE provides modest power, a real transmission and good handling.
title: Driving Experience

make.name: Ford
model.name: Escape
style.name: SE 4dr SUV (1.6L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: Attractive styling, adequate cargo capabilities, and more practical than a family car. There are lots of reasons to like the new Escape.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: The only compact crossover that's more fun-to-drive than this one is Mazda's CX-5. Still, the FWD 1.6L SE provides modest power, a real transmission and good handling.
title: Personality

make.name: Ford
model.name: Explorer
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV AWD (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Mid-pack acceleration (0-60 mph in 8.4 sec.) with the 290-hp V6 AWD.  The 240-hp turbo 4-cyl. is one second slower.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Acceleration is just so-so with the V6 or turbocharged 4-cylinder, while the 365-hp twin-turbo V6 offers V8-like thrust. Handling and braking, though dependant on tire selection, are confident. Steering and towing are strong suits.
title: Acceleration

make.name: Ford
model.name: Explorer
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV AWD (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Confident and firm pedal with intuitive responses, but emergency stops are highly dependent on tire selection. We recorded a panic stop of 118 feet from 60 mph with this V6 test model.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Acceleration is just so-so with the V6 or turbocharged 4-cylinder, while the 365-hp twin-turbo V6 offers V8-like thrust. Handling and braking, though dependant on tire selection, are confident. Steering and towing are strong suits.
title: Braking

make.name: Ford
model.name: Explorer
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV AWD (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Isolated on-center feel going down the highway but good response and precision when cornering. Nice and light in parking situations.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Acceleration is just so-so with the V6 or turbocharged 4-cylinder, while the 365-hp twin-turbo V6 offers V8-like thrust. Handling and braking, though dependant on tire selection, are confident. Steering and towing are strong suits.
title: Steering

make.name: Ford
model.name: Explorer
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV AWD (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: As with braking, grip varies with tire selection and so does confidence in corners. We found the Limited AWD model to be reassuring and capable for its size.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Acceleration is just so-so with the V6 or turbocharged 4-cylinder, while the 365-hp twin-turbo V6 offers V8-like thrust. Handling and braking, though dependant on tire selection, are confident. Steering and towing are strong suits.
title: Handling

make.name: Ford
model.name: Explorer
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV AWD (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Despite good individual qualities, the Explorer somehow manages to feel large and distant from its driver. It's hard to know where the corners are, which makes it difficult to park.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Acceleration is just so-so with the V6 or turbocharged 4-cylinder, while the 365-hp twin-turbo V6 offers V8-like thrust. Handling and braking, though dependant on tire selection, are confident. Steering and towing are strong suits.
title: Driveability

make.name: Ford
model.name: Explorer
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV AWD (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Properly equipped V6s can tow up to 5,000 pounds, enough for a boat or off-road vehicle. Electronic trailer-sway control is a worthwhile differentiating feature.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Acceleration is just so-so with the V6 or turbocharged 4-cylinder, while the 365-hp twin-turbo V6 offers V8-like thrust. Handling and braking, though dependant on tire selection, are confident. Steering and towing are strong suits.
title: Towing

make.name: Ford
model.name: Explorer
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV AWD (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: The AWD models feature a knob (and 4 terrain settings) that uses brakes to route power to the most effective wheel, but it's not true 4WD with low gearing. Modest ground clearance.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Acceleration is just so-so with the V6 or turbocharged 4-cylinder, while the 365-hp twin-turbo V6 offers V8-like thrust. Handling and braking, though dependant on tire selection, are confident. Steering and towing are strong suits.
title: Off-Road

make.name: Ford
model.name: Explorer
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV AWD (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: The Limited's heated front seats are large and offer plenty of adjustability. The second row (also heated on Ltd.) has similar qualities, but the third row has severely cramped leg room.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: Adequate seating for the first two rows, but things fall well short back in the third row. Ride comfort and quietness, however, are quite good for its class, though still below segment leaders.
title: Seating Comfort

make.name: Ford
model.name: Explorer
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV AWD (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: In most situations the Explorer's ride is perfectly comfy, better than most. We did notice some tire thumping on abrupt seams and occasional freeway "busy-ness."
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: Adequate seating for the first two rows, but things fall well short back in the third row. Ride comfort and quietness, however, are quite good for its class, though still below segment leaders.
title: Ride Comfort

make.name: Ford
model.name: Explorer
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV AWD (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: A standout quality of the Explorer is how hushed the cabin is. All of the engines are remarkably quiet (even while accelerating) and wind/road noise are well muted.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: Adequate seating for the first two rows, but things fall well short back in the third row. Ride comfort and quietness, however, are quite good for its class, though still below segment leaders.
title: Quietness

make.name: Ford
model.name: Explorer
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV AWD (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Recent improvements to the MyFord Touch infotainment system and the center stack's virtual "buttons" have greatly improved response time. However, rotary knobs would still work better.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Because of difficult access to its cramped third row, modest cargo room in any configuration and problematic visibility, the Explorer falls short in many of the categories people shopping for a 3-row SUV care about.
title: Ergonomics

make.name: Ford
model.name: Explorer
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV AWD (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: First and second rows are easily accessed with wide doors, reasonable step-in and seat height, but access to the third row is particularly arduous and challenging, even for kids.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Because of difficult access to its cramped third row, modest cargo room in any configuration and problematic visibility, the Explorer falls short in many of the categories people shopping for a 3-row SUV care about.
title: Ingress/Egress

make.name: Ford
model.name: Explorer
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV AWD (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: There's an unusual abundance of room in the front row that decreases noticeably with each successive row behind.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Because of difficult access to its cramped third row, modest cargo room in any configuration and problematic visibility, the Explorer falls short in many of the categories people shopping for a 3-row SUV care about.
title: Space/Room

make.name: Ford
model.name: Explorer
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV AWD (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Despite optional aids (rear camera, automated parking, blind-spot and cross-traffic alerts, etc.), the Explorer is quite large and it's difficult to judge where its borders are.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Because of difficult access to its cramped third row, modest cargo room in any configuration and problematic visibility, the Explorer falls short in many of the categories people shopping for a 3-row SUV care about.
title: Visibility

make.name: Ford
model.name: Explorer
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV AWD (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: At 21 cu-ft with all seats occupied, luggage room is mid-pack within the class. Seats-folded max cargo grows to 81 cu-ft, which is much smaller than the competition.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Because of difficult access to its cramped third row, modest cargo room in any configuration and problematic visibility, the Explorer falls short in many of the categories people shopping for a 3-row SUV care about.
title: Cargo/Storage

make.name: Ford
model.name: Explorer
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV AWD (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Ford vehicles often feel more European in terms of build quality and  material choices, and the Explorer follows this trend. Solid, substantial, with good attention to detail.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The Explorer spans a price range of $30K-$42K. Our one-option Limited cost $46,420. Impressive interior quality and high-tech features only go so far to offset mediocre fuel economy and warranty terms.
title: Build Quality (vs. $)

make.name: Ford
model.name: Explorer
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV AWD (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: The Explorer matches similarly priced competition item for item (Bluetooth, parking aids, leather, etc.), but has pricey packages for navgation, power liftgate and blind-spot monitor.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The Explorer spans a price range of $30K-$42K. Our one-option Limited cost $46,420. Impressive interior quality and high-tech features only go so far to offset mediocre fuel economy and warranty terms.
title: Features(vs. $)

make.name: Ford
model.name: Explorer
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV AWD (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: The Explorer is priced fairly. Within its range, there are some larger and/or V8 powered SUVs, and also some smaller, sportier imports.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The Explorer spans a price range of $30K-$42K. Our one-option Limited cost $46,420. Impressive interior quality and high-tech features only go so far to offset mediocre fuel economy and warranty terms.
title: Cost

make.name: Ford
model.name: Explorer
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV AWD (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: On our test loop, we managed to squeak out slightly better than 20 mpg, beating the EPA's 19 mpg Combined (17 City/23 Highway) estimate.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The Explorer spans a price range of $30K-$42K. Our one-option Limited cost $46,420. Impressive interior quality and high-tech features only go so far to offset mediocre fuel economy and warranty terms.
title: MPG

make.name: Ford
model.name: Explorer
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV AWD (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Like its competition, the Explorer offers a 3-year/36,000-mile basic warranty, but only a 5-year/60,000-mile powertrain warranty (others go up to 100,000 miles).
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The Explorer spans a price range of $30K-$42K. Our one-option Limited cost $46,420. Impressive interior quality and high-tech features only go so far to offset mediocre fuel economy and warranty terms.
title: Warranty

make.name: Ford
model.name: Explorer
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV AWD (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Ford doesn't currently offer a free scheduled maintenance program for the Explorer, though you get roadside assistance for 5 years/60,000 miles.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The Explorer spans a price range of $30K-$42K. Our one-option Limited cost $46,420. Impressive interior quality and high-tech features only go so far to offset mediocre fuel economy and warranty terms.
title: Ownership

make.name: Ford
model.name: Explorer
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV AWD (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Unlike some other large SUVs that drive smaller than they are, the Explorer feels, in fact, even larger than it is. Never a good trait. Parking can be a challenge.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: Feeling every inch of width and height, both while driving and parking, the Explorer isn't what we'd call fun to drive. It beckons the minivan-averse crowd, yet fails to achieve anywhere near the utility of the sliding-door types.
title: Driving Experience

make.name: Ford
model.name: Explorer
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV AWD (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Like some other minivans disguised as SUVs, the Explorer looks the part and largely succeeds, although it falls short in terms of cargo and people-carrying capabilities.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: Feeling every inch of width and height, both while driving and parking, the Explorer isn't what we'd call fun to drive. It beckons the minivan-averse crowd, yet fails to achieve anywhere near the utility of the sliding-door types.
title: Personality

make.name: Ford
model.name: F-150
style.name: XLT 4dr SuperCab 6.5 ft. SB (3.7L 6cyl 6A)
summary: The 3.7-liter V6 moves out adequately and makes decent power, but it is held back by overly-broad gear spacing. Gets to 60 mph in 8.2 seconds, a few ticks behind the Ram.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Ford's 3.7-liter V6 is strong, but you know it's working. Turns out a 6-speed transmission is fine for a V8, but the lower torque of a V6 demands more gears. Handling and steering are solid, but unremarkable.
title: Acceleration

make.name: Ford
model.name: F-150
style.name: XLT 4dr SuperCab 6.5 ft. SB (3.7L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Stops from 60 mph in 130 feet, just a couple feet more than most passenger cars. Pedal feels dependable, with decent feedback.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Ford's 3.7-liter V6 is strong, but you know it's working. Turns out a 6-speed transmission is fine for a V8, but the lower torque of a V6 demands more gears. Handling and steering are solid, but unremarkable.
title: Braking

make.name: Ford
model.name: F-150
style.name: XLT 4dr SuperCab 6.5 ft. SB (3.7L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Goes where it's pointed and stays on the intended path, but feedback is a bit numb and response is somewhat slow.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Ford's 3.7-liter V6 is strong, but you know it's working. Turns out a 6-speed transmission is fine for a V8, but the lower torque of a V6 demands more gears. Handling and steering are solid, but unremarkable.
title: Steering

make.name: Ford
model.name: F-150
style.name: XLT 4dr SuperCab 6.5 ft. SB (3.7L 6cyl 6A)
summary: For some reason this truck feels longer than it looks when cornering. Otherwise, it feels stable and secure when empty.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Ford's 3.7-liter V6 is strong, but you know it's working. Turns out a 6-speed transmission is fine for a V8, but the lower torque of a V6 demands more gears. Handling and steering are solid, but unremarkable.
title: Handling

make.name: Ford
model.name: F-150
style.name: XLT 4dr SuperCab 6.5 ft. SB (3.7L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Gear spacing too wide for the V6 engine. Gear hunting occurs on a variety of slopes (empty or loaded), and the downshift rpm jump is stark. Ram has it right with their 8-speed V6 combo.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Ford's 3.7-liter V6 is strong, but you know it's working. Turns out a 6-speed transmission is fine for a V8, but the lower torque of a V6 demands more gears. Handling and steering are solid, but unremarkable.
title: Driveability

make.name: Ford
model.name: F-150
style.name: XLT 4dr SuperCab 6.5 ft. SB (3.7L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Ford raised this truck's tow rating from 5,800 to 6,400 pounds. We don't see it. After testing, the first number seems right. 6-speed transmission hunts relentlessly on grades.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Ford's 3.7-liter V6 is strong, but you know it's working. Turns out a 6-speed transmission is fine for a V8, but the lower torque of a V6 demands more gears. Handling and steering are solid, but unremarkable.
title: Towing

make.name: Ford
model.name: F-150
style.name: XLT 4dr SuperCab 6.5 ft. SB (3.7L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Optional buckets are nicely supportive in a sit-down sense, but are barely adequate laterally on twisty roads.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: Sitting there with the engine off, our Ford F-150 XLT is indeed comfortable. Start driving it down the road and the picture changes somewhat.
title: Seating Comfort

make.name: Ford
model.name: F-150
style.name: XLT 4dr SuperCab 6.5 ft. SB (3.7L 6cyl 6A)
summary: The ride isn't hard, but the aftershake from small ripples (seen and unseen) and cracks makes for near-constant low-grade jiggle. Typical leaf spring truck behavior.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: Sitting there with the engine off, our Ford F-150 XLT is indeed comfortable. Start driving it down the road and the picture changes somewhat.
title: Ride Comfort

make.name: Ford
model.name: F-150
style.name: XLT 4dr SuperCab 6.5 ft. SB (3.7L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Tire and wind noise are moderate, but you'd better like engine sound. The cabin doesn't mask it much under load and there are large rpm spikes when the 6-speed transmission kicks down.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: Sitting there with the engine off, our Ford F-150 XLT is indeed comfortable. Start driving it down the road and the picture changes somewhat.
title: Quietness

make.name: Ford
model.name: F-150
style.name: XLT 4dr SuperCab 6.5 ft. SB (3.7L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Driving position is good, but the the mid-level audio system and climate control layout is a festival of look-alike buttons. Manual selector on column shift lever isn't ideal.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: This truck feels dated inside, and it's not just the styling. Certain controls feel outmoded, and it turns out reverse-hinged doors were never that great of an idea to begin with. Now that GM canned them, Ford is alone here.
title: Ergonomics

make.name: Ford
model.name: F-150
style.name: XLT 4dr SuperCab 6.5 ft. SB (3.7L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Front seat access is fine. But reverse-hinged rear doors need to go away. Rear seat ingress OK, but there's no place for a grab handle and the front passenger must let you out.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: This truck feels dated inside, and it's not just the styling. Certain controls feel outmoded, and it turns out reverse-hinged doors were never that great of an idea to begin with. Now that GM canned them, Ford is alone here.
