ratings.summary: There's a lot of car for the money here, and not just in terms of feature count. The Fit's inherent value is in its ability to be many cars in one, thanks to its versatile cabin. It also manages to deliver significantly better fuel economy than before.
title: Cost

make.name: Honda
model.name: Fit
style.name: EX-L w/Navigation 4dr Hatchback (1.5L 4cyl CVT)
summary: An all-new engine and transmission have boosted the EPA ratings to 35 mpg Combined (32 City/38 Highway), better than most of its rivals. On our evaluation loop the Fit achieved 36.2 mpg. Overall it earned 29.9 mpg in its time with us.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: There's a lot of car for the money here, and not just in terms of feature count. The Fit's inherent value is in its ability to be many cars in one, thanks to its versatile cabin. It also manages to deliver significantly better fuel economy than before.
title: MPG

make.name: Honda
model.name: Fit
style.name: EX-L w/Navigation 4dr Hatchback (1.5L 4cyl CVT)
summary: The Fit's warranty coverage is 3 years/36,000 miles bumper-to-bumper, 5 years/60,000 miles powertrain and 5 years/unlimited miles for corrosion. This is typical.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: There's a lot of car for the money here, and not just in terms of feature count. The Fit's inherent value is in its ability to be many cars in one, thanks to its versatile cabin. It also manages to deliver significantly better fuel economy than before.
title: Warranty

make.name: Honda
model.name: Fit
style.name: EX-L w/Navigation 4dr Hatchback (1.5L 4cyl CVT)
summary: Roadside assistance and free scheduled maintenance are not part of the deal. The lack of free scheduled maintenance is typical for the segment, but some rivals come with roadside assistance.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: There's a lot of car for the money here, and not just in terms of feature count. The Fit's inherent value is in its ability to be many cars in one, thanks to its versatile cabin. It also manages to deliver significantly better fuel economy than before.
title: Ownership

make.name: Honda
model.name: Fit
style.name: EX-L w/Navigation 4dr Hatchback (1.5L 4cyl CVT)
summary: Control efforts are universally light and quick. Its overall limits are low, so the Fit is best when you drive it precisely. It's not a hot hatch, but its inherent lightness has rewards when driven enthusiastically.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: The Fit feels less substantial than, say, a Mazda3, but it's whippy and eager nonetheless. It's an easy car to drive for nearly anyone, owing to its tidy dimensions and user-friendly controls. It's not fast, but it is responsive.
title: Driving Experience

make.name: Honda
model.name: Fit
style.name: EX-L w/Navigation 4dr Hatchback (1.5L 4cyl CVT)
summary: The Fit is a car that's eager to please. Sure, its engine doesn't sound great when you drive it enthusiastically, but its handling is reasonably sharp and the car changes direction well. You can have fun with it at low speeds.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: The Fit feels less substantial than, say, a Mazda3, but it's whippy and eager nonetheless. It's an easy car to drive for nearly anyone, owing to its tidy dimensions and user-friendly controls. It's not fast, but it is responsive.
title: Personality

make.name: Honda
model.name: HR-V
style.name: EX-L w/Navigation 4dr SUV AWD (1.8L 4cyl CVT)
summary: The HR-V is one of the slowest in the segment, with 0-60 mph in 9.7 seconds. After lurching off the line abruptly, the HR-V feels weak, even in regular driving. The CVT is decent, but the lack of power lends to rubber-banding on climbs.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: With only 138 horsepower from its 1.8-liter four-cylinder mated to a continuously variable transmission (CVT), there's meager power here. Worse, this combo is loud, with vibrations felt through the steering wheel. On the bright side, handling is surprisingly decent with sharp steering.
title: Acceleration

make.name: Honda
model.name: HR-V
style.name: EX-L w/Navigation 4dr SUV AWD (1.8L 4cyl CVT)
summary: Brakes feel just barely adequate power-wise, but they give a decent feel, making it easy to modulate when coming to a stop. Linear action, never touchy. Stopped from 60 mph in 124 feet, a bit below average, with some moderate instability.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: With only 138 horsepower from its 1.8-liter four-cylinder mated to a continuously variable transmission (CVT), there's meager power here. Worse, this combo is loud, with vibrations felt through the steering wheel. On the bright side, handling is surprisingly decent with sharp steering.
title: Braking

make.name: Honda
model.name: HR-V
style.name: EX-L w/Navigation 4dr SUV AWD (1.8L 4cyl CVT)
summary: Nice steering with a natural level of assist plus some good feedback through the steering wheel to the driver. Gives confidence as you steer the car into corners. Fun on curvy roads, yet perfectly easy around town and in parking lots.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: With only 138 horsepower from its 1.8-liter four-cylinder mated to a continuously variable transmission (CVT), there's meager power here. Worse, this combo is loud, with vibrations felt through the steering wheel. On the bright side, handling is surprisingly decent with sharp steering.
title: Steering

make.name: Honda
model.name: HR-V
style.name: EX-L w/Navigation 4dr SUV AWD (1.8L 4cyl CVT)
summary: A fun little handler, thanks to the steering's quick turn-in and well-tuned suspension that works with the driver. Backing out of the throttle mid-turn allows the front to regain traction nicely. ESC system rarely intervenes on public roads.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: With only 138 horsepower from its 1.8-liter four-cylinder mated to a continuously variable transmission (CVT), there's meager power here. Worse, this combo is loud, with vibrations felt through the steering wheel. On the bright side, handling is surprisingly decent with sharp steering.
title: Handling

make.name: Honda
model.name: HR-V
style.name: EX-L w/Navigation 4dr SUV AWD (1.8L 4cyl CVT)
summary: Full-throttle brings vibrations through the steering wheel and gas pedal, especially above 5,000 rpm. Gas pedal delivery is abrupt to try and mask the engine's limited power. Cruise control overshot by as much as 10 mph on a downhill.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: With only 138 horsepower from its 1.8-liter four-cylinder mated to a continuously variable transmission (CVT), there's meager power here. Worse, this combo is loud, with vibrations felt through the steering wheel. On the bright side, handling is surprisingly decent with sharp steering.
title: Driveability

make.name: Honda
model.name: HR-V
style.name: EX-L w/Navigation 4dr SUV AWD (1.8L 4cyl CVT)
summary: The HR-V comes standard with front-wheel drive, but all three trim levels are available with all-wheel drive, as on our test vehicle. This is not a true off-road system though, intended more for improved traction during inclement driving.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: With only 138 horsepower from its 1.8-liter four-cylinder mated to a continuously variable transmission (CVT), there's meager power here. Worse, this combo is loud, with vibrations felt through the steering wheel. On the bright side, handling is surprisingly decent with sharp steering.
title: Off-Road

make.name: Honda
model.name: HR-V
style.name: EX-L w/Navigation 4dr SUV AWD (1.8L 4cyl CVT)
summary: Front seats are narrow with firm cushions. Decent side bolstering, but non-adjustable lumbar is aggressive. Taller folks noticed lack of adjustability and poor legroom. Door/center armrests have good padding. Rear seats firm but comfy.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: The HR-V delivers one of the best rides in the class, but we still couldn't rate it an "A" in the category, due to its inability to soak up big bumps well. With little power on tap, the CVT works hard to maintain speed, which equates to loud, high-rpm running on sustained climbs.
title: Seating Comfort

make.name: Honda
model.name: HR-V
style.name: EX-L w/Navigation 4dr SUV AWD (1.8L 4cyl CVT)
summary: Thanks to short wheelbases, no vehicle in the subcompact crossover class is cushy. But Honda does well here, with a completely livable ride quality. It does struggle with big bumps, but in general it's less stiff-legged than most rivals.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: The HR-V delivers one of the best rides in the class, but we still couldn't rate it an "A" in the category, due to its inability to soak up big bumps well. With little power on tap, the CVT works hard to maintain speed, which equates to loud, high-rpm running on sustained climbs.
title: Ride Comfort

make.name: Honda
model.name: HR-V
style.name: EX-L w/Navigation 4dr SUV AWD (1.8L 4cyl CVT)
summary: Full-throttle or high-rpm running brings considerable racket into the cabin. Even at idle at a stoplight, there's noticeable engine vibration. Tires were noisier than expected over most surfaces, but wind noise was impressively muted.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: The HR-V delivers one of the best rides in the class, but we still couldn't rate it an "A" in the category, due to its inability to soak up big bumps well. With little power on tap, the CVT works hard to maintain speed, which equates to loud, high-rpm running on sustained climbs.
title: Quietness

make.name: Honda
model.name: HR-V
style.name: EX-L w/Navigation 4dr SUV AWD (1.8L 4cyl CVT)
summary: Touchscreen looks nice even with low-rent nav graphics. Its icons are large, but their function can sometimes be unclear and the lack of infotainment and climate control knobs is a huge minus. High-quality steering wheel controls.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: The interior is simply more useful than any other car in the class, with a nifty rear seat that can fold or swing up and out of the way. Excellent cargo capacity and interior volume, too. Unlike the Mazda CX-3, rear passengers don't feel like front occupants are sitting in their lap.
title: Ergonomics

make.name: Honda
model.name: HR-V
style.name: EX-L w/Navigation 4dr SUV AWD (1.8L 4cyl CVT)
summary: Front seat is near-perfect height for slipping in/out, and roofline is high. Doors are large for this size of vehicle and open quite wide. More difficult to get into rear thanks to sloping roofline. Door opening is small; rear seat is high.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: The interior is simply more useful than any other car in the class, with a nifty rear seat that can fold or swing up and out of the way. Excellent cargo capacity and interior volume, too. Unlike the Mazda CX-3, rear passengers don't feel like front occupants are sitting in their lap.
title: Ingress/Egress

make.name: Honda
model.name: HR-V
style.name: EX-L w/Navigation 4dr SUV AWD (1.8L 4cyl CVT)
summary: Excellent rear seat space for the segment -- average-size adults can actually fit back there. But front seats lack legroom and adjustment for tall folks. Excellent door-side elbow space but high center console restricts driver's right knee.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: The interior is simply more useful than any other car in the class, with a nifty rear seat that can fold or swing up and out of the way. Excellent cargo capacity and interior volume, too. Unlike the Mazda CX-3, rear passengers don't feel like front occupants are sitting in their lap.
title: Space/Room

make.name: Honda
model.name: HR-V
style.name: EX-L w/Navigation 4dr SUV AWD (1.8L 4cyl CVT)
summary: Slim pillars, particularly those up front. Rear pillars are thick but short, side windows are long, making for easier lane changes than most in class. Rearview camera is standard on all trims; LaneWatch blind spot camera standard on EX/EX-L.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: The interior is simply more useful than any other car in the class, with a nifty rear seat that can fold or swing up and out of the way. Excellent cargo capacity and interior volume, too. Unlike the Mazda CX-3, rear passengers don't feel like front occupants are sitting in their lap.
title: Visibility

make.name: Honda
model.name: HR-V
style.name: EX-L w/Navigation 4dr SUV AWD (1.8L 4cyl CVT)
summary: Cargo capacity is beat slightly by the Kia Soul, but still excellent at 23.2 cu-ft, or 55.9 cu-ft with rear seats folded. Unbeatable versatility with completely flat-folding rear seat and cushions that flip up. Sub-par small-item storage.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: The interior is simply more useful than any other car in the class, with a nifty rear seat that can fold or swing up and out of the way. Excellent cargo capacity and interior volume, too. Unlike the Mazda CX-3, rear passengers don't feel like front occupants are sitting in their lap.
title: Cargo/Storage

make.name: Honda
model.name: HR-V
style.name: EX-L w/Navigation 4dr SUV AWD (1.8L 4cyl CVT)
summary: Although the interior looks nice for the most part, some of the trim pieces and the action of a few controls aren't up to Honda's usual high standards, and below the class-leading Mazda CX-3 in terms of presentation.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The HR-V offers strong value, with pricing starting about $1,000 less than most rivals (other than the Kia Soul, which undercuts all) along with plenty of cool features (LaneWatch camera) and excellent fuel mileage, both EPA and real-world. The warranty is mediocre.
title: Build Quality (vs. $)

make.name: Honda
model.name: HR-V
style.name: EX-L w/Navigation 4dr SUV AWD (1.8L 4cyl CVT)
summary: The base HR-V comes with alloy wheels, rearview camera, Bluetooth phone connectivity and Pandora Internet radio. Our EX-L test car came with push-button start, leather seats (heated up front), LaneWatch camera and sunroof. Pretty generous.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The HR-V offers strong value, with pricing starting about $1,000 less than most rivals (other than the Kia Soul, which undercuts all) along with plenty of cool features (LaneWatch camera) and excellent fuel mileage, both EPA and real-world. The warranty is mediocre.
title: Features(vs. $)

make.name: Honda
model.name: HR-V
style.name: EX-L w/Navigation 4dr SUV AWD (1.8L 4cyl CVT)
summary: Competitive pricing for the HR-V LX with FWD and manual transmission begins around $20,000; add nearly a grand for the CVT. Our top-of-the-line AWD EX-L Navi test car came in at $26,720. Superior versatility adds extra value versus rivals.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The HR-V offers strong value, with pricing starting about $1,000 less than most rivals (other than the Kia Soul, which undercuts all) along with plenty of cool features (LaneWatch camera) and excellent fuel mileage, both EPA and real-world. The warranty is mediocre.
title: Cost

make.name: Honda
model.name: HR-V
style.name: EX-L w/Navigation 4dr SUV AWD (1.8L 4cyl CVT)
summary: HR-V AWD tops the class (with the Mazda CX-3) according to its EPA ratings, at 29 mpg combined (27 city/32 highway). It averaged 27.5 in mixed driving, including 31.9 mpg on our evaluation route (the CX-3 managed 31.4 on the same route).
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The HR-V offers strong value, with pricing starting about $1,000 less than most rivals (other than the Kia Soul, which undercuts all) along with plenty of cool features (LaneWatch camera) and excellent fuel mileage, both EPA and real-world. The warranty is mediocre.
title: MPG

make.name: Honda
model.name: HR-V
style.name: EX-L w/Navigation 4dr SUV AWD (1.8L 4cyl CVT)
summary: The Honda HR-V matches the Mazda CX-3 with 3 years/36,000 miles for its basic warranty and 5 years/60,000 miles for drivetrain coverage. But both the Chevy Trax and Fiat 500X offer drivetrain coverage up to 100,000 miles.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The HR-V offers strong value, with pricing starting about $1,000 less than most rivals (other than the Kia Soul, which undercuts all) along with plenty of cool features (LaneWatch camera) and excellent fuel mileage, both EPA and real-world. The warranty is mediocre.
title: Warranty

make.name: Honda
model.name: HR-V
style.name: EX-L w/Navigation 4dr SUV AWD (1.8L 4cyl CVT)
summary: Roadside assistance is good for 3 years/36,000 miles on the Honda HR-V, in contrast to Fiat's 5-year/100,000-mile plan. The Honda does not offer free maintenance, while the Chevy Trax provides 2 years/24,000 miles.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The HR-V offers strong value, with pricing starting about $1,000 less than most rivals (other than the Kia Soul, which undercuts all) along with plenty of cool features (LaneWatch camera) and excellent fuel mileage, both EPA and real-world. The warranty is mediocre.
title: Ownership

make.name: Honda
model.name: HR-V
style.name: EX-L w/Navigation 4dr SUV AWD (1.8L 4cyl CVT)
summary: Minimal sound deadening and a wimpy, hard-working engine combine to hurt the HR-V's overall driving experience. A cushy-for-the-class ride along with spirited handling manners aren't quite enough to make it a truly enjoyable drive.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: The HR-V has a more useful interior than its rivals, but fun-to-drive? Not really. The main culprit is its weak and loud engine mated to a CVT. On the other hand, sharp steering and a well-tuned suspension endow it with fun handling.
title: Driving Experience

make.name: Honda
model.name: HR-V
style.name: EX-L w/Navigation 4dr SUV AWD (1.8L 4cyl CVT)
summary: Honda got many things right with the HR-V, but it lacks most of the driving qualities that make vehicles like the Mazda CX-3 and Nissan Juke so fun-to-drive. Other than adequate handling, there's nothing here to get a driver excited.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: The HR-V has a more useful interior than its rivals, but fun-to-drive? Not really. The main culprit is its weak and loud engine mated to a CVT. On the other hand, sharp steering and a well-tuned suspension endow it with fun handling.
title: Personality

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Good acceleration from the 248-hp 3.5-liter V6. Even though it's equipped with the optional, smooth-shifting 6-speed automatic, the power drops off more than expected between gears.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Natural driving dynamics have always been an Odyssey strong suit. This latest generation feels heavier than ever, but it's still precise and wieldy in spite of its large shadow.
title: Acceleration

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Excellent modulation around town. Relatively soft pedal "jump-in," but not annoyingly so. Easy to execute perfect "limousine stops."
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Natural driving dynamics have always been an Odyssey strong suit. This latest generation feels heavier than ever, but it's still precise and wieldy in spite of its large shadow.
title: Braking

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Light, with just a hint of self-aligning torque. Not brimming with feel. Appropriate for the class of vehicle, though, and fairly precise considering the Odyssey's size.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Natural driving dynamics have always been an Odyssey strong suit. This latest generation feels heavier than ever, but it's still precise and wieldy in spite of its large shadow.
title: Steering

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: This is a large minivan, and it can feel somewhat ponderous at times. It's not sloppy, rather it feels more deliberate than some competitors. Easy to maneuver in tight situations.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Natural driving dynamics have always been an Odyssey strong suit. This latest generation feels heavier than ever, but it's still precise and wieldy in spite of its large shadow.
title: Handling

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: With well-placed and user-friendly controls, a huge windshield, light steering and ultra-supple throttle calibration, the Odyssey is a pleasure to live with despite its size.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Natural driving dynamics have always been an Odyssey strong suit. This latest generation feels heavier than ever, but it's still precise and wieldy in spite of its large shadow.
title: Driveability

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: The Odyssey can tow up to a maximum of 3,500 pounds when properly equipped, which is equal to the Nissan Quest and Toyota Sienna.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Natural driving dynamics have always been an Odyssey strong suit. This latest generation feels heavier than ever, but it's still precise and wieldy in spite of its large shadow.
title: Towing

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Big, wide thrones. Soft leather. The seats are great for long-haul comfort. Not a lot of lateral support, but this isn't a vehicle that will have you seeking backroads anyway.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: Plush seats and good noise isolation make for great comfort on long trips. The ride quality handles big bumps well, but smaller ones aren't as easily smothered-over.
title: Seating Comfort

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: The open-box layout of minivans tends to promote chassis quivers, and you feel them in the Odyssey. The ride is fairly well-controlled despite this, and most of the time it's plenty comfy.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: Plush seats and good noise isolation make for great comfort on long trips. The ride quality handles big bumps well, but smaller ones aren't as easily smothered-over.
title: Ride Comfort

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Good isolation from road and wind noise. Long trips are the Odyssey's forte, and its quiet cabin plays right into this.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: Plush seats and good noise isolation make for great comfort on long trips. The ride quality handles big bumps well, but smaller ones aren't as easily smothered-over.
title: Quietness

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: The center stack presents a vast array of buttons that can initially overwhelm. Navigation graphics look a bit old-school. However, major controls are logically grouped.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Smartly designed cabin accomodates people and cargo with equal effectiveness. Superbly flexible seating layout makes the Odyssey configurable for any task. There's even a vacuum cleaner on board now.
title: Ergonomics

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Low step-in height makes entry and exit simple for passengers of all sizes and ages. The handy sliding second row eases access to the third row.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Smartly designed cabin accomodates people and cargo with equal effectiveness. Superbly flexible seating layout makes the Odyssey configurable for any task. There's even a vacuum cleaner on board now.
title: Ingress/Egress

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: The vast cabin space is efficiently packaged. For everyday family use there's no better vehicle than a minivan, and the Odyssey's seat functionality is among the best.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Smartly designed cabin accomodates people and cargo with equal effectiveness. Superbly flexible seating layout makes the Odyssey configurable for any task. There's even a vacuum cleaner on board now.
title: Space/Room

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Expansive windshield offers panoramic view. The rear pillars are annoyingly thick, but the backup camera makes reversing easier.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Smartly designed cabin accomodates people and cargo with equal effectiveness. Superbly flexible seating layout makes the Odyssey configurable for any task. There's even a vacuum cleaner on board now.
title: Visibility

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Tremendous flexibility in seating arrangement offers room to transport virtually anything. Lots of nooks and bins to store stuff, too.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Smartly designed cabin accomodates people and cargo with equal effectiveness. Superbly flexible seating layout makes the Odyssey configurable for any task. There's even a vacuum cleaner on board now.
title: Cargo/Storage

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Apparent build quality was quite good overall, though a couple of rattles (unusual for a Honda) were observed.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Functionally, the Odyssey is hard to beat. You can load it up with features if you so desire, but this can become a pricey proposition, so choose wisely. It also offers class-leading fuel economy and running costs on par with its rival minivans.
title: Build Quality (vs. $)

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Brimming with features for all passengers. Oddly, keyless ignition isn't available even on this range-topping Touring Elite model. A small but curious omission.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Functionally, the Odyssey is hard to beat. You can load it up with features if you so desire, but this can become a pricey proposition, so choose wisely. It also offers class-leading fuel economy and running costs on par with its rival minivans.
title: Features(vs. $)

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: It's loaded, but it'll cost you. This top-shelf Touring Elite test vehicle came in at over $45 grand. Shop the lower trim levels for similar functionality at a more attractive price.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Functionally, the Odyssey is hard to beat. You can load it up with features if you so desire, but this can become a pricey proposition, so choose wisely. It also offers class-leading fuel economy and running costs on par with its rival minivans.
title: Cost

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: With 22 mpg Combined (19 City/28 Highway), the Odyssey is a tick better than its crosstown rivals, the Nissan Quest and Toyota Sienna.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Functionally, the Odyssey is hard to beat. You can load it up with features if you so desire, but this can become a pricey proposition, so choose wisely. It also offers class-leading fuel economy and running costs on par with its rival minivans.
title: MPG

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: The basic warranty is 3 years/36,000 miles, with the powertrain covered for 5 years/60,000 miles. This is equivalent to the Honda's competition.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Functionally, the Odyssey is hard to beat. You can load it up with features if you so desire, but this can become a pricey proposition, so choose wisely. It also offers class-leading fuel economy and running costs on par with its rival minivans.
title: Warranty

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: The Odyssey should be similar in terms of ownership costs to Nissan and Toyota's minivans. Honda's reputation for quality is near-legendary.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Functionally, the Odyssey is hard to beat. You can load it up with features if you so desire, but this can become a pricey proposition, so choose wisely. It also offers class-leading fuel economy and running costs on par with its rival minivans.
title: Ownership

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: The Odyssey is never in-your-face, it just goes about its business in an accomodating and transparent manner. It may not be exciting, but it's certainly pleasant.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: It's hard to describe any minivan as truly fun to drive. That said, the Odyssey removes most of the unwanted hassles from the everyday driving experience. Yet it's still a surprisingly nimble, smooth-yet-powerful mode of transport.
title: Driving Experience

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: It's a willing partner, especially if your needs involve big miles over pavement. Truly no other vehicle can do as many things with ease as a well-built, highly-engineered minivan.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: It's hard to describe any minivan as truly fun to drive. That said, the Odyssey removes most of the unwanted hassles from the everyday driving experience. Yet it's still a surprisingly nimble, smooth-yet-powerful mode of transport.
title: Personality

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Good acceleration from the 248-hp 3.5-liter V6, with 0-60 mph in 8.0 seconds. Equipped with a smooth-shifting 6-speed automatic, but  power drops more than expected between gears.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Natural driving dynamics have always been an Odyssey strong suit. This latest generation feels heavier than ever, but it's still precise and wieldy in spite of its large shadow.
title: Acceleration

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Excellent modulation around town. Relatively soft pedal "jump-in," but not annoyingly so. Easy to execute perfect "limousine stops." In our 60-0 panic-brake test, the Odyssey stopped in 131 feet.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Natural driving dynamics have always been an Odyssey strong suit. This latest generation feels heavier than ever, but it's still precise and wieldy in spite of its large shadow.
title: Braking

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Light, with just a hint of self-aligning torque. Not brimming with feel. Appropriate for the class of vehicle, though, and fairly precise considering the Odyssey's size.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Natural driving dynamics have always been an Odyssey strong suit. This latest generation feels heavier than ever, but it's still precise and wieldy in spite of its large shadow.
title: Steering

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: This is a large minivan, and it can feel somewhat ponderous at times. It's not sloppy, in fact it feels more deliberate than some competitors. Easy to maneuver in tight situations.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Natural driving dynamics have always been an Odyssey strong suit. This latest generation feels heavier than ever, but it's still precise and wieldy in spite of its large shadow.
title: Handling

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: With well-placed and user-friendly controls, a huge windshield, light steering and ultra-supple throttle calibration, the Odyssey is a pleasure to live with despite its size.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Natural driving dynamics have always been an Odyssey strong suit. This latest generation feels heavier than ever, but it's still precise and wieldy in spite of its large shadow.
title: Driveability

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: The Odyssey can tow up to a maximum of 3,500 pounds when properly equipped, which is equal to the Nissan Quest and Toyota Sienna.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Natural driving dynamics have always been an Odyssey strong suit. This latest generation feels heavier than ever, but it's still precise and wieldy in spite of its large shadow.
title: Towing

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Big, wide thrones. Soft leather. The seats are great for long-haul comfort. Not a lot of lateral support, but this isn't a vehicle that will have you seeking backroads anyway.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: Plush seats and good noise isolation make for great comfort on long trips. The ride quality handles big bumps well, but smaller ones aren't as easily smothered-over.
title: Seating Comfort

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: The open-box layout of minivans tends to promote chassis quivers, and you feel them in the Odyssey. The ride is fairly well-controlled despite this, and most of the time it's plenty comfy.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: Plush seats and good noise isolation make for great comfort on long trips. The ride quality handles big bumps well, but smaller ones aren't as easily smothered-over.
title: Ride Comfort

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Good isolation from road and wind noise. Long trips are the Odyssey's forte, and its quiet cabin plays right along.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: Plush seats and good noise isolation make for great comfort on long trips. The ride quality handles big bumps well, but smaller ones aren't as easily smothered-over.
title: Quietness

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: The center stack presents a vast array of buttons that can initially overwhelm. Navigation graphics look a bit old-school. However, major controls are logically grouped.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Smartly designed cabin accomodates people and cargo with equal effectiveness. Superbly flexible seating layout makes the Odyssey highly configurable. There's even a vacuum cleaner on board in this top trim model.
title: Ergonomics

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Low step-in height makes entry and exit simple for passengers of all sizes and ages. The handy sliding second row eases access to the third row.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Smartly designed cabin accomodates people and cargo with equal effectiveness. Superbly flexible seating layout makes the Odyssey highly configurable. There's even a vacuum cleaner on board in this top trim model.
title: Ingress/Egress

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: The vast cabin space is efficiently packaged. For everyday family use there's no better vehicle than a minivan, and the Odyssey's seat functionality is at the top of the class.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Smartly designed cabin accomodates people and cargo with equal effectiveness. Superbly flexible seating layout makes the Odyssey highly configurable. There's even a vacuum cleaner on board in this top trim model.
title: Space/Room

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Expansive windshield offers panoramic view. The rear pillars are annoyingly thick, but the backup camera eases reversing maneuvers.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Smartly designed cabin accomodates people and cargo with equal effectiveness. Superbly flexible seating layout makes the Odyssey highly configurable. There's even a vacuum cleaner on board in this top trim model.
title: Visibility

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Tremendously flexible seating arrangement offers room to transport virtually anything. Lots of nooks and bins to store stuff, too.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Smartly designed cabin accomodates people and cargo with equal effectiveness. Superbly flexible seating layout makes the Odyssey highly configurable. There's even a vacuum cleaner on board in this top trim model.
title: Cargo/Storage

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Apparent build quality was quite good overall, though a couple of rattles (unusual for a Honda) were observed.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Functionally, the Odyssey is hard to beat. You can load it up with features if you so desire, but this can become a pricey proposition, so choose wisely. It also offers class-leading fuel economy and running costs on par with its rival minivans.
title: Build Quality (vs. $)

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Brimming with features. Power sliding doors and hatch, keyless entry/ignition, navigation, rear-seat entertainment and leather are all included in the Touring Elite model. No other minivan offers a vacuum cleaner.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Functionally, the Odyssey is hard to beat. You can load it up with features if you so desire, but this can become a pricey proposition, so choose wisely. It also offers class-leading fuel economy and running costs on par with its rival minivans.
title: Features(vs. $)

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: It's loaded, but it'll cost you. This top-shelf Touring Elite test vehicle came in at over $45,000. Shop the lower trim levels for similar functionality at a more attractive price.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Functionally, the Odyssey is hard to beat. You can load it up with features if you so desire, but this can become a pricey proposition, so choose wisely. It also offers class-leading fuel economy and running costs on par with its rival minivans.
title: Cost

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: With 22 mpg combined (19 city/28 highway), the Odyssey is a tick better than its crosstown rivals, the Nissan Quest and Toyota Sienna. We measured 20.6 mpg in our own combined driving.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Functionally, the Odyssey is hard to beat. You can load it up with features if you so desire, but this can become a pricey proposition, so choose wisely. It also offers class-leading fuel economy and running costs on par with its rival minivans.
title: MPG

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: The basic warranty is 3 years/36,000 miles, with the powertrain covered for 5 years/60,000 miles. This is equivalent to the Honda's competition.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Functionally, the Odyssey is hard to beat. You can load it up with features if you so desire, but this can become a pricey proposition, so choose wisely. It also offers class-leading fuel economy and running costs on par with its rival minivans.
title: Warranty

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: The Odyssey should be similar in terms of ownership costs to Nissan and Toyota's minivans. Honda's reputation for quality is near-legendary. But, there's no roadside assistance nor free maintenance.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Functionally, the Odyssey is hard to beat. You can load it up with features if you so desire, but this can become a pricey proposition, so choose wisely. It also offers class-leading fuel economy and running costs on par with its rival minivans.
title: Ownership

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: The Odyssey is never in-your-face, it just goes about its business in an accomodating and transparent manner. It may not be exciting, but it's certainly pleasant.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: It's hard to describe any minivan as truly fun to drive. That said, the Odyssey removes most of the unwanted hassles from the everyday driving experience. Yet it's still a surprisingly nimble, smooth-yet-powerful mode of transport.
title: Driving Experience

make.name: Honda
model.name: Odyssey
style.name: Touring Elite 4dr Minivan (3.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: It's a willing partner, especially if your needs involve big miles over pavement. Truly no other vehicle can do as many things with ease as a well-built, highly-engineered minivan.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: It's hard to describe any minivan as truly fun to drive. That said, the Odyssey removes most of the unwanted hassles from the everyday driving experience. Yet it's still a surprisingly nimble, smooth-yet-powerful mode of transport.
title: Personality

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Elantra
style.name: Limited 4dr Sedan (1.8L 4cyl 6A)
summary: The Elantra's 4-cylinder engine becomes thrashy when accelerating hard. Power is weak at low revs, and its 0-60 mph time of 9.7 sec. is slow for the class. The 6-speed automatic is ultra-smooth but can be overly shifty.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: No speed demon, this Elantra, with a 1.8-liter 4-cylinder that makes only 145 horsepower. The lack of power forces the "over-thinking" 6-speed automatic transmission to change gears a lot. Handling is pretty decent, but there are some driveability annoyances.
title: Acceleration

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Elantra
style.name: Limited 4dr Sedan (1.8L 4cyl 6A)
summary: The Elantra exhibits some initial brake jumpiness when hitting the pedal at higher speeds, but the action is linear around town. More nosedive than we'd like, and its panic-stop distance of 126 feet from 60 mph is longer than average.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: No speed demon, this Elantra, with a 1.8-liter 4-cylinder that makes only 145 horsepower. The lack of power forces the "over-thinking" 6-speed automatic transmission to change gears a lot. Handling is pretty decent, but there are some driveability annoyances.
title: Braking

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Elantra
style.name: Limited 4dr Sedan (1.8L 4cyl 6A)
summary: The Sport mode of the driver-selectable steering has a nice heft that enthusiasts will enjoy. Regardless of mode, there isn't a lot of feel, but it's precise enough that you can hustle it down a twisty road with confidence.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: No speed demon, this Elantra, with a 1.8-liter 4-cylinder that makes only 145 horsepower. The lack of power forces the "over-thinking" 6-speed automatic transmission to change gears a lot. Handling is pretty decent, but there are some driveability annoyances.
title: Steering

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Elantra
style.name: Limited 4dr Sedan (1.8L 4cyl 6A)
summary: It steers nicely through turns and is totally controllable, although there's limited grip and power available. The rear suspension isn't great with mid-corner bumps. The Elantra gets the job done, but it's not as fluid as some others.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: No speed demon, this Elantra, with a 1.8-liter 4-cylinder that makes only 145 horsepower. The lack of power forces the "over-thinking" 6-speed automatic transmission to change gears a lot. Handling is pretty decent, but there are some driveability annoyances.
title: Handling

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Elantra
style.name: Limited 4dr Sedan (1.8L 4cyl 6A)
summary: Annoyances like an overly abrupt gas pedal, the transmission's seeming inability to find and hold a gear and a cruise control that massively overshoots the set speed hurt the Elantra's driveability score.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: No speed demon, this Elantra, with a 1.8-liter 4-cylinder that makes only 145 horsepower. The lack of power forces the "over-thinking" 6-speed automatic transmission to change gears a lot. Handling is pretty decent, but there are some driveability annoyances.
title: Driveability

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Elantra
style.name: Limited 4dr Sedan (1.8L 4cyl 6A)
summary: Front seats have firm foam and hard leather. Driver's seat has power lumbar; front passenger seat is manual with no lumbar. Rear seat cushions are more plush, but seatbacks are too upright. Does have fold-down center armrest.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: Despite the Elantra's size, there are more comfortable cars that it competes against. We found the front seats rather hard and the busy ride doesn't help matters. On the other hand, the Elantra is impressively quiet at highway speeds.
title: Seating Comfort

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Elantra
style.name: Limited 4dr Sedan (1.8L 4cyl 6A)
summary: No car in this class has a truly cushy ride, but the Elantra can be surprisingly harsh over bumps and potholes, feeling unrefined compared to several key rivals. The lack of compliance means the car skitters over sharp road imperfections.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: Despite the Elantra's size, there are more comfortable cars that it competes against. We found the front seats rather hard and the busy ride doesn't help matters. On the other hand, the Elantra is impressively quiet at highway speeds.
title: Ride Comfort

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Elantra
style.name: Limited 4dr Sedan (1.8L 4cyl 6A)
summary: Our testing showed the Elantra is quieter at 70 mph and full throttle versus the Honda Civic and Mazda 3. There's still a good amount of road noise, but the engine is barely perceptible at highway speeds thanks to tall gearing.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: Despite the Elantra's size, there are more comfortable cars that it competes against. We found the front seats rather hard and the busy ride doesn't help matters. On the other hand, the Elantra is impressively quiet at highway speeds.
title: Quietness

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Elantra
style.name: Limited 4dr Sedan (1.8L 4cyl 6A)
summary: Driver's seat is power-adjustable but most of our editors couldn't get the seat low enough. Large knobs and buttons work well and feel nice, center stack is stylish. Temp controls easy to deciper quickly. Large, easy-to-read tach and speedo.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: For a car with considerably more EPA interior volume than its key rivals, the Elantra has limited front and rear head room. Blame that stylish roofline. The ergonomics are quite good and storage, both in the cabin and in the gigantic trunk, are superb.
title: Ergonomics

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Elantra
style.name: Limited 4dr Sedan (1.8L 4cyl 6A)
summary: Front doors are large for a small car and open super-wide, making entry/exit a snap. Despite wide-opening doors, it takes some contortioning to get into the rear due to the low roof, small entry space and forward-positioned seatbacks.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: For a car with considerably more EPA interior volume than its key rivals, the Elantra has limited front and rear head room. Blame that stylish roofline. The ergonomics are quite good and storage, both in the cabin and in the gigantic trunk, are superb.
title: Ingress/Egress

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Elantra
style.name: Limited 4dr Sedan (1.8L 4cyl 6A)
summary: Front head room will be tight for anyone close to average size. But good elbow room, and slim center console doesn't interfere with driver's right knee. Sloping roof means rear head room will be tight for nearly everybody.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: For a car with considerably more EPA interior volume than its key rivals, the Elantra has limited front and rear head room. Blame that stylish roofline. The ergonomics are quite good and storage, both in the cabin and in the gigantic trunk, are superb.
title: Space/Room

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Elantra
style.name: Limited 4dr Sedan (1.8L 4cyl 6A)
summary: Windshield pillars are slim but long, problematic for looking through turns. The rest of the pillars are narrow, creating minimal blind spots. Rear window is wide. Large screen for the backup camera has parking lines.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: For a car with considerably more EPA interior volume than its key rivals, the Elantra has limited front and rear head room. Blame that stylish roofline. The ergonomics are quite good and storage, both in the cabin and in the gigantic trunk, are superb.
title: Visibility

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Elantra
style.name: Limited 4dr Sedan (1.8L 4cyl 6A)
summary: Small but useful front bin with closeable lid. Generous armrest bin. Door pockets have a forward slant but can fit CD cases. Rear seats fold; trunk has super-wide opening. Load floor is low and 14.8 cu-ft is huge for the segment.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: For a car with considerably more EPA interior volume than its key rivals, the Elantra has limited front and rear head room. Blame that stylish roofline. The ergonomics are quite good and storage, both in the cabin and in the gigantic trunk, are superb.
title: Cargo/Storage

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Elantra
style.name: Limited 4dr Sedan (1.8L 4cyl 6A)
summary: The Elantra looks the part, until you touch the trim pieces, which are mostly cheap plastic. But, the parts you come in contact with, like audio, temp and window controls, and the steering wheel and shifter, all feel solid.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The Elantra SE sedan starts at $18,010 with a 6-speed manual. Since most folks will opt for the 6-speed automatic transmission, real Elantra pricing begins at $19,010. That's more than the Focus and Mazda 3, less than the Civic. But the Elantra comes packed with standard features.
title: Build Quality (vs. $)

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Elantra
style.name: Limited 4dr Sedan (1.8L 4cyl 6A)
summary: Hyundai is famous for including lots of "stuff." The Limited starts at $22,460 with leather seats (heated front and rear), power driver's seat, 3-mode driver-selectable steering, rearview camera and Hyundai's BlueLink telematics.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The Elantra SE sedan starts at $18,010 with a 6-speed manual. Since most folks will opt for the 6-speed automatic transmission, real Elantra pricing begins at $19,010. That's more than the Focus and Mazda 3, less than the Civic. But the Elantra comes packed with standard features.
title: Features(vs. $)

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Elantra
style.name: Limited 4dr Sedan (1.8L 4cyl 6A)
summary: The Limited with the $2,750 Technology package brings navigation with a 7-inch screen, dual-zone temp control, a 360-watt premium audio system, a power sunroof and push-button start. With optional floormats, as-tested price was $25,335.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The Elantra SE sedan starts at $18,010 with a 6-speed manual. Since most folks will opt for the 6-speed automatic transmission, real Elantra pricing begins at $19,010. That's more than the Focus and Mazda 3, less than the Civic. But the Elantra comes packed with standard features.
title: Cost

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Elantra
style.name: Limited 4dr Sedan (1.8L 4cyl 6A)
summary: The EPA rates the Elantra with the 6-speed automatic transmission at 31 mpg Combined (27 City/37 Highway). We averaged 30.7 mpg overall, including 31.6 mpg on the 116-mile Edmunds evaluation loop. The Mazda 3 and Civic are more efficient.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The Elantra SE sedan starts at $18,010 with a 6-speed manual. Since most folks will opt for the 6-speed automatic transmission, real Elantra pricing begins at $19,010. That's more than the Focus and Mazda 3, less than the Civic. But the Elantra comes packed with standard features.
title: MPG

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Elantra
style.name: Limited 4dr Sedan (1.8L 4cyl 6A)
summary: With a 5-year/60,000-mile basic warranty and 10-year/100,000-mile powertrain coverage, no car other than the Kia Forte comes close. It also has a 7-year/unlimited miles rust warranty.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The Elantra SE sedan starts at $18,010 with a 6-speed manual. Since most folks will opt for the 6-speed automatic transmission, real Elantra pricing begins at $19,010. That's more than the Focus and Mazda 3, less than the Civic. But the Elantra comes packed with standard features.
title: Warranty

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Elantra
style.name: Limited 4dr Sedan (1.8L 4cyl 6A)
summary: Roadside assistance is covered for 5 years/unlimited miles. The Focus also has it for five years, but the miles aren't unlimited. The Elantra does not have a free maintenance program.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The Elantra SE sedan starts at $18,010 with a 6-speed manual. Since most folks will opt for the 6-speed automatic transmission, real Elantra pricing begins at $19,010. That's more than the Focus and Mazda 3, less than the Civic. But the Elantra comes packed with standard features.
title: Ownership

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Elantra
style.name: Limited 4dr Sedan (1.8L 4cyl 6A)
summary: Once you figure out how to "drive around" the touchy gas pedal and keep the transmission from downshifting two gears when you need more power, the Elantra drives decently. It's just a bit unrefined compared to some rivals.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: There's nothing particularly fun about driving the Elantra, although it's a decent companion on twistier bits of road. The suspension's lack of bump compliance hurts it, though. The ability to change the steering effort between three modes is a nice standard feature.
title: Driving Experience

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Elantra
style.name: Limited 4dr Sedan (1.8L 4cyl 6A)
summary: In terms of the actual driving of the Elantra, it doesn't offer much personality. But its styling, inside and out, brings a little something extra to the equation. Possibly only the Mazda 3 has more head-turning looks in this segment.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: There's nothing particularly fun about driving the Elantra, although it's a decent companion on twistier bits of road. The suspension's lack of bump compliance hurts it, though. The ability to change the steering effort between three modes is a nice standard feature.
title: Personality

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Santa Fe Sport
style.name: 2.0T 4dr SUV (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: Initial hesitation if you punch the gas hard leaving a stoplight, but once it gets going the 2.0-liter turbo four-cylinder feels strong, thanks to 264 hp and 269 lb-ft of torque. It hit 60 mph in 7.5 seconds -- midpack for upgraded engines.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Thanks to the 2.0T's turbocharged four-cylinder, merging into fast-moving highway traffic is easy. The six-speed automatic is a smooth shifter and is good about using the engine's ample torque instead of downshifting. Steering has been improved; brake performance was weak.
title: Acceleration

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Santa Fe Sport
style.name: 2.0T 4dr SUV (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: It needed 127 ft. to stop from 60 mph (on the long side for the class) and we experienced some pedal fade. The brakes are easy to modulate for coming to smooth stops, but the pedal travel is long, giving the feeling they are underpowered.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Thanks to the 2.0T's turbocharged four-cylinder, merging into fast-moving highway traffic is easy. The six-speed automatic is a smooth shifter and is good about using the engine's ample torque instead of downshifting. Steering has been improved; brake performance was weak.
title: Braking

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Santa Fe Sport
style.name: 2.0T 4dr SUV (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: A well-tuned steering system thanks to some revisions by Hyundai. Feel is on the lighter side, especially in parking lots and at low speeds, but the effort ramps up nicely through corners and as speeds increase. Feedback has been improved.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Thanks to the 2.0T's turbocharged four-cylinder, merging into fast-moving highway traffic is easy. The six-speed automatic is a smooth shifter and is good about using the engine's ample torque instead of downshifting. Steering has been improved; brake performance was weak.
title: Steering

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Santa Fe Sport
style.name: 2.0T 4dr SUV (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: Not quite as "sporty" as its name implies, but still a decent-handling SUV. Body roll is well controlled and it showed good poise through turns, even if it doesn't have a ton of grip. You can have some fun hustling it through twisty roads.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Thanks to the 2.0T's turbocharged four-cylinder, merging into fast-moving highway traffic is easy. The six-speed automatic is a smooth shifter and is good about using the engine's ample torque instead of downshifting. Steering has been improved; brake performance was weak.
title: Handling

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Santa Fe Sport
style.name: 2.0T 4dr SUV (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: The Santa Fe Sport has an easy-going character, with supple gas pedal movement, light steering and easy-to-modulate brakes. Rear outward views are problematic. Cruise control overshoots by 4 mph, but transmission downshifts to slow speed.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Thanks to the 2.0T's turbocharged four-cylinder, merging into fast-moving highway traffic is easy. The six-speed automatic is a smooth shifter and is good about using the engine's ample torque instead of downshifting. Steering has been improved; brake performance was weak.
title: Driveability

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Santa Fe Sport
style.name: 2.0T 4dr SUV (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: The Santa Fe Sport 2.0T can tow 1,650 pounds, or up to 3,500 lbs. if using trailer brakes. The base Santa Fe Sport with the lower-horsepower four-cylinder is only rated to 2,000 lbs with trailer brakes.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Thanks to the 2.0T's turbocharged four-cylinder, merging into fast-moving highway traffic is easy. The six-speed automatic is a smooth shifter and is good about using the engine's ample torque instead of downshifting. Steering has been improved; brake performance was weak.
title: Towing

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Santa Fe Sport
style.name: 2.0T 4dr SUV (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: The Santa Fe Sport wasn't designed to tackle anything more serious than a dirt road. Front-wheel drive comes standard; all-wheel drive is optional. Its 7.3 inches of ground clearance trails the Subaru Outback by 1.4 inches.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Thanks to the 2.0T's turbocharged four-cylinder, merging into fast-moving highway traffic is easy. The six-speed automatic is a smooth shifter and is good about using the engine's ample torque instead of downshifting. Steering has been improved; brake performance was weak.
title: Off-Road

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Santa Fe Sport
style.name: 2.0T 4dr SUV (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: The front seats are mounted a bit high, but are wide and should suit adults of many sizes. The cushions are firm and the 2.0T's standard leather isn't overly supple. The armrests lack padding, too. Reclining rear seats are more enveloping.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: We found the rear seats a bit more comfortable than the fronts, which are not quite up to all-day road trip duty. We also appreciated the greatly adjustable seatback rake of those rear seats. Ride cushioning was disappointing; interior noise suppression was quite good.
title: Seating Comfort

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Santa Fe Sport
style.name: 2.0T 4dr SUV (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: The ride is on the firm side for the class. The suspension has an unrefined feel to it and big bumps can unsettle the vehicle. Smaller highway pavement ripples cause a bouncy effect, translating to vibrations entering the cabin.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: We found the rear seats a bit more comfortable than the fronts, which are not quite up to all-day road trip duty. We also appreciated the greatly adjustable seatback rake of those rear seats. Ride cushioning was disappointing; interior noise suppression was quite good.
title: Ride Comfort

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Santa Fe Sport
style.name: 2.0T 4dr SUV (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: An impressively quiet vehicle. There's some minor hum from the turbo four-cylinder, but it's a smooth engine and even at full throttle it doesn't get unruly or loud. The tires are near-silent and there's minimal wind noise.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: We found the rear seats a bit more comfortable than the fronts, which are not quite up to all-day road trip duty. We also appreciated the greatly adjustable seatback rake of those rear seats. Ride cushioning was disappointing; interior noise suppression was quite good.
title: Quietness

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Santa Fe Sport
style.name: 2.0T 4dr SUV (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: Easy-to-read instruments. All buttons and knobs are fairly large, well-labeled and have a nice, damped feel to them. Bluetooth phone pairing was quick and easy. Touchscreen has nice-sized icons and is one of the easier interfaces to use.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: A nicely-designed interior. The center stack is interesting to look at, yet its controls are easy to use with big knobs and buttons and a simple touchscreen. Most interior measurements (other than front headroom) best rivals. Rear outward view is poor.
title: Ergonomics

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Santa Fe Sport
style.name: 2.0T 4dr SUV (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: Front doors don't open wide but entryway is tall enough that it's easy to hop in and out. Seat height is near perfect for easy entry/exit. Rear wheelwell doesn't intrude like some vehicles in class, and plenty of foot space for exiting.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: A nicely-designed interior. The center stack is interesting to look at, yet its controls are easy to use with big knobs and buttons and a simple touchscreen. Most interior measurements (other than front headroom) best rivals. Rear outward view is poor.
title: Ingress/Egress

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Santa Fe Sport
style.name: 2.0T 4dr SUV (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: Optional panoramic sunroof reduces front/rear headroom, but most folks should be fine with it. Slim center console means driver's right knee isn't constantly rubbing against it. Excellent rear knee room; good foot space under front seats.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: A nicely-designed interior. The center stack is interesting to look at, yet its controls are easy to use with big knobs and buttons and a simple touchscreen. Most interior measurements (other than front headroom) best rivals. Rear outward view is poor.
title: Space/Room

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Santa Fe Sport
style.name: 2.0T 4dr SUV (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: Slim windshield pillars plus tall side windows give good front/side views. Big blind spots at rear three-quarter due to upward sweeping body and thick rear pillars. Good thing 2.0T model comes with rearview camera and blind spot detection.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: A nicely-designed interior. The center stack is interesting to look at, yet its controls are easy to use with big knobs and buttons and a simple touchscreen. Most interior measurements (other than front headroom) best rivals. Rear outward view is poor.
title: Visibility

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Santa Fe Sport
style.name: 2.0T 4dr SUV (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: Excellent small-item storage with generously-sized door pockets, front bin and two-tiered center armrest bin. Luggage space is 35.4 cu-ft (71.5 with seats folded), which is similar to CR-V and RAV4. Seat-drop levers need a healthy pull.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: A nicely-designed interior. The center stack is interesting to look at, yet its controls are easy to use with big knobs and buttons and a simple touchscreen. Most interior measurements (other than front headroom) best rivals. Rear outward view is poor.
title: Cargo/Storage

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Santa Fe Sport
style.name: 2.0T 4dr SUV (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: Not as many soft-touch materials as some rivals, but interior looks and feels of good quality. Power window switches look cool but the edges can be sharp on fingers. Test car had an odd rattle from rearview mirror area.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: There's value in its size, as the 143.4 cu-ft interior volume bests competitors. Buyers will also appreciate the Sport's excellent crash test scores and long warranty. Base pricing is higher than key rivals but Hyundai scores points with an available engine upgrade. Fuel economy is weak.
title: Build Quality (vs. $)

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Santa Fe Sport
style.name: 2.0T 4dr SUV (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: 2.0T model starts around $32,000, which may seem high, but it comes standard with dual-zone climate control, leather seats, rearview camera, hands-free/auto-open liftgate, rear side sunshades, and blind-spot and cross-traffic warnings.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: There's value in its size, as the 143.4 cu-ft interior volume bests competitors. Buyers will also appreciate the Sport's excellent crash test scores and long warranty. Base pricing is higher than key rivals but Hyundai scores points with an available engine upgrade. Fuel economy is weak.
title: Features(vs. $)

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Santa Fe Sport
style.name: 2.0T 4dr SUV (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: Santa Fe Sport's base price is more than some rivals but it has more space. Plus, some don't offer an engine upgrade. With optional panoramic sunroof, 8-inch navigation and 12-speaker audio system, as-tested 2.0T price was $36,600.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: There's value in its size, as the 143.4 cu-ft interior volume bests competitors. Buyers will also appreciate the Sport's excellent crash test scores and long warranty. Base pricing is higher than key rivals but Hyundai scores points with an available engine upgrade. Fuel economy is weak.
title: Cost

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Santa Fe Sport
style.name: 2.0T 4dr SUV (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: The EPA rates the Santa Fe Sport 2.0T FWD at 22 mpg combined (19 city/27 highway). Those aren't spectacular numbers, but we averaged 21.8 mpg overall and 22.9 mpg on our evaluation route. So at least the ratings are achievable.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: There's value in its size, as the 143.4 cu-ft interior volume bests competitors. Buyers will also appreciate the Sport's excellent crash test scores and long warranty. Base pricing is higher than key rivals but Hyundai scores points with an available engine upgrade. Fuel economy is weak.
title: MPG

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Santa Fe Sport
style.name: 2.0T 4dr SUV (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: Comes with a 5-year/60,000-mile basic warranty and 10-year/100,000-mile drivetrain warranty. Along with Kia's identical coverage, the drivetrain warranty is the best in the business. Rust coverage is for 7 years/unlimited miles.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: There's value in its size, as the 143.4 cu-ft interior volume bests competitors. Buyers will also appreciate the Sport's excellent crash test scores and long warranty. Base pricing is higher than key rivals but Hyundai scores points with an available engine upgrade. Fuel economy is weak.
title: Warranty

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Santa Fe Sport
style.name: 2.0T 4dr SUV (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: Roadside assistance is covered for 5 years/unlimited miles -- better than most competitors. But Hyundai doesn't have a free maintenance program for the Santa Fe Sport, while the Toyota RAV4 has free maintenance for 2 years/25,000 miles.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: There's value in its size, as the 143.4 cu-ft interior volume bests competitors. Buyers will also appreciate the Sport's excellent crash test scores and long warranty. Base pricing is higher than key rivals but Hyundai scores points with an available engine upgrade. Fuel economy is weak.
title: Ownership

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Santa Fe Sport
style.name: 2.0T 4dr SUV (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: The driving experience is decent but certainly not at the top of the class. Occasionally you'll wish the turbo power came on sooner and the ride can be harsh at times. The interior is reasonably comfortable and easy to use.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: This isn't a vehicle we would classify as "fun-to-drive." You won't look for reasons to run extra errands just to go drive it. We do like its handling though, and the smooth turbo engine has nice thrust.
title: Driving Experience

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Santa Fe Sport
style.name: 2.0T 4dr SUV (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: It has three things going for it personality-wise. It has interesting styling, both inside and out. The turbo engine has strong mid-range power. Finally, it handles well enough that you won't purposely avoid twisty roads.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: This isn't a vehicle we would classify as "fun-to-drive." You won't look for reasons to run extra errands just to go drive it. We do like its handling though, and the smooth turbo engine has nice thrust.
title: Personality

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Sonata
style.name: GLS 4dr Sedan (2.4L 4cyl 6A)
summary: Among its peers, the Sonata offers competitive acceleration with its base-level engine at about 8 seconds to 60 mph. The available turbo engine cuts it down to less than 7 seconds.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The Sonata's overall performance is well balanced with a peppy engine, competent handling, good brakes, and effortless drivability.
title: Acceleration

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Sonata
style.name: GLS 4dr Sedan (2.4L 4cyl 6A)
summary: In our 60-0 mph testing, the Sonata's brakes were slightly better than average and impressed us with a firm pedal and good fade resistance.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The Sonata's overall performance is well balanced with a peppy engine, competent handling, good brakes, and effortless drivability.

ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The Sonata's overall performance is well balanced with a peppy engine, competent handling, good brakes, and effortless drivability.

ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The Sonata's overall performance is well balanced with a peppy engine, competent handling, good brakes, and effortless drivability.

summary: Combining all this competent performance results in the kind of car that offers an almost effortless drivability. "Get in and go" without a second thought.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The Sonata's overall performance is well balanced with a peppy engine, competent handling, good brakes, and effortless drivability.

summary: Supportive and well-contoured front seats are not too squishy. Rear-seat accommodations are sizable, and competitive with its peers. Rea headroom might be tight for 6-footers.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: With good ride comfort and interior accommodations that are generously sized (technically a "Large Car"), the Sonata is near the top of its class for overall comfort.

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Sonata
style.name: GLS 4dr Sedan (2.4L 4cyl 6A)
summary: The highway ride is well isolated but not boaty either. Those who opt for the sporty SE trim will like its sharper handling capabilities but not its bumpier ride.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: With good ride comfort and interior accommodations that are generously sized (technically a "Large Car"), the Sonata is near the top of its class for overall comfort.

summary: Crisp clear gauges, well-labeled center stack with large, intuitive buttons and an easy-to-navigate trip computer offer good ergonomics. Optional nav system is equally proficient.

summary: Driving a Sonata is undemanding and it responds with an intuition and confidence the way a family sedan should.

summary: Choosing a Sonata over one of the ubiquitous best-sellers in the competitive class would likely indicate you've done a little more homework.

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Sonata Hybrid
style.name: Limited 4dr Sedan (2.4L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid 6A)
summary: At 8.5 seconds to 60 mph, the Sonata Hybrid is among the quickest mainstream hybrid family sedans. Unlike some rivals, battery charge, or lack thereof, greatly affects acceleration.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: In most categories, the Sonata Hybrid merely matches, rather than surpasses, the competition. One reason for this is that the Sonata Hybrid lacks much cutting-edge engineering. However in some instances it's merely a tuning choice by Hyundai.
title: Acceleration

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Sonata Hybrid
style.name: Limited 4dr Sedan (2.4L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid 6A)
summary: Due to regenerative braking, nearly all hybrids' brakes require driver acclimation. While a few have found ways to provide some semblance of a natural feel, Hyundai hasn't.
ratings.title: Performance
