summary: There are virtually no options available for the Limited model because pretty much everything comes standard. Its features-versus-base-price quotient is highly competitive.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Value was once Hyundai's trump card, but price increases mean this isn't as much of an incentive anymore. Base models are still competitively priced, but upper-level trims face stiff competition. The warranty, however, is second to none.
title: Features(vs. $)

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Sonata Hybrid
style.name: Limited 4dr Sedan (2.4L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid 6A)
summary: There are less-expensive hybrids, but at about $31,000, the Sonata Hybrid Limited presents strong value among midsize sedans, hybrid or otherwise.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Value was once Hyundai's trump card, but price increases mean this isn't as much of an incentive anymore. Base models are still competitively priced, but upper-level trims face stiff competition. The warranty, however, is second to none.
title: Cost

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Sonata Hybrid
style.name: Limited 4dr Sedan (2.4L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid 6A)
summary: Rated by the EPA at 36 city/40 highway/37 mpg combined, the Sonata falls short of the most frugal midsize hybrids by nearly 10 mpg across the board.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Value was once Hyundai's trump card, but price increases mean this isn't as much of an incentive anymore. Base models are still competitively priced, but upper-level trims face stiff competition. The warranty, however, is second to none.
title: MPG

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Sonata Hybrid
style.name: Limited 4dr Sedan (2.4L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid 6A)
summary: One of the best warranties, period. Hyundai provides a 5-year/60,000-mile basic warranty and 10-year/100,000-mile powertrain coverage, even on its hybrids. Lifetime battery guarantee.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Value was once Hyundai's trump card, but price increases mean this isn't as much of an incentive anymore. Base models are still competitively priced, but upper-level trims face stiff competition. The warranty, however, is second to none.
title: Warranty

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Sonata Hybrid
style.name: Limited 4dr Sedan (2.4L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid 6A)
summary: We have witnessed excellent reliability with Hyundai products first-hand at Edmunds. This Sonata comes with roadside assistance and free scheduled maintenance for 5 years/60,000 miles.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Value was once Hyundai's trump card, but price increases mean this isn't as much of an incentive anymore. Base models are still competitively priced, but upper-level trims face stiff competition. The warranty, however, is second to none.
title: Ownership

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Sonata Hybrid
style.name: Limited 4dr Sedan (2.4L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid 6A)
summary: The Hyundai Sonata isn't a sport sedan, but it's also not a completely lifeless economy pod. You could do worse in terms of driver involvement and it remains a pleasant daily driver.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: Converted to hybrid duty, the Sonata loses some of the dynamic appeal of the regular sedan. But partially due to its true automatic transmission, it's still more fun to drive than many in the segment.
title: Driving Experience

make.name: Hyundai
model.name: Sonata Hybrid
style.name: Limited 4dr Sedan (2.4L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid 6A)
summary: We appreciate the Sonata's tasteful exterior and well-equipped and upscale interior. These help give the car a bit more personality than many others in the class.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: Converted to hybrid duty, the Sonata loses some of the dynamic appeal of the regular sedan. But partially due to its true automatic transmission, it's still more fun to drive than many in the segment.
title: Personality

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Hybrid Sport 4dr Sedan (3.5L 6cyl gas/electric hybrid 7A)
summary: The Q50 Hybrid's 0-60 time of 5.3 seconds ties BMW's 3 Series Hybrid and is quicker even than the conventional Q50 (5.5 sec.). In normal driving acceleration is uneven with occasional uncomfortable stumbles and lurches.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The Q50 S Hybrid's 3.5-liter V6 and hybrid electric system combine to produce a healthy 360 hp, besting the Lexus ES 300h (200 hp) and BMW 3 Series ActiveHybrid (335 hp). The Q50 is fast for a luxury hybrid, but disappoints in terms of everyday driveability.
title: Acceleration

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Hybrid Sport 4dr Sedan (3.5L 6cyl gas/electric hybrid 7A)
summary: Brake pedal effort/response is inconsistent, makes it hard to stop smoothly at a light. Panic stops from 60 mph required a class-average 117 feet, but there was an unsettling amount of instability and the pedal went all the way to the floor.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The Q50 S Hybrid's 3.5-liter V6 and hybrid electric system combine to produce a healthy 360 hp, besting the Lexus ES 300h (200 hp) and BMW 3 Series ActiveHybrid (335 hp). The Q50 is fast for a luxury hybrid, but disappoints in terms of everyday driveability.
title: Braking

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Hybrid Sport 4dr Sedan (3.5L 6cyl gas/electric hybrid 7A)
summary: The steer-by-wire system is unintuitive, lacks feedback and feels artificial. Eco mode feels lazy and detatched, while Sport mode makes things worse with far too much resistance. In contrast, the non-hybrid Q50's steering was excellent.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The Q50 S Hybrid's 3.5-liter V6 and hybrid electric system combine to produce a healthy 360 hp, besting the Lexus ES 300h (200 hp) and BMW 3 Series ActiveHybrid (335 hp). The Q50 is fast for a luxury hybrid, but disappoints in terms of everyday driveability.
title: Steering

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Hybrid Sport 4dr Sedan (3.5L 6cyl gas/electric hybrid 7A)
summary: The Q50 Hybrid is surprisingly capable on a twisty, given the lack of trust, feedback and consistency. But it's an unpleasant experience regardless. When the driver gives quick steering inputs it just further highlights the system's delay.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The Q50 S Hybrid's 3.5-liter V6 and hybrid electric system combine to produce a healthy 360 hp, besting the Lexus ES 300h (200 hp) and BMW 3 Series ActiveHybrid (335 hp). The Q50 is fast for a luxury hybrid, but disappoints in terms of everyday driveability.
title: Handling

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Hybrid Sport 4dr Sedan (3.5L 6cyl gas/electric hybrid 7A)
summary: The oddites of the throttle, brake and steering inputs leave you guessing as to how the Q50 will react. It is far from enjoyable under most conditions, with annoying lurches and a disconnected feeling. This is exactly how to not do a hybrid.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The Q50 S Hybrid's 3.5-liter V6 and hybrid electric system combine to produce a healthy 360 hp, besting the Lexus ES 300h (200 hp) and BMW 3 Series ActiveHybrid (335 hp). The Q50 is fast for a luxury hybrid, but disappoints in terms of everyday driveability.
title: Driveability

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Hybrid Sport 4dr Sedan (3.5L 6cyl gas/electric hybrid 7A)
summary: The seats are well-shaped with 8 power adjustments and standard heat, but padding is on the firm side. Taller drivers may find the seat cushions too short. We felt some fatigue and the leather became stifling after just a few hours.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: The combination of a lurching drivetrain and an unyielding suspension mean the the Q50 S Hybrid can cause motion sickness for sensitive passengers. Compounding matters are seats which are merely average in terms of comfort.
title: Seating Comfort

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Hybrid Sport 4dr Sedan (3.5L 6cyl gas/electric hybrid 7A)
summary: Bumps of any size send noticeable jolts into the cabin. The Q50's stiff suspension makes for a busy, shopping cart-like ride over rough pavement. Most drivers and passengers will find it objectionable.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: The combination of a lurching drivetrain and an unyielding suspension mean the the Q50 S Hybrid can cause motion sickness for sensitive passengers. Compounding matters are seats which are merely average in terms of comfort.
title: Ride Comfort

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Hybrid Sport 4dr Sedan (3.5L 6cyl gas/electric hybrid 7A)
summary: Wind and road noises are pleasantly quieted, but road imperfections tend to cause a boomy thud that quickly becomes tiresome. Under moderate to heavy acceleration, engine noise is noticeable, but not unpleasant.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: The combination of a lurching drivetrain and an unyielding suspension mean the the Q50 S Hybrid can cause motion sickness for sensitive passengers. Compounding matters are seats which are merely average in terms of comfort.
title: Quietness

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Hybrid Sport 4dr Sedan (3.5L 6cyl gas/electric hybrid 7A)
summary: Two touchscreens split most controls and take some getting-used-to time. Small on-screen and physical button layout is unintuitive. The glossy lower screen is prone to glare and fingerprints, but both screens are responsive to inputs.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: The Q50's cabin is tastefully modern and built with praiseworthy materials. There's plenty of passenger space, but the hybrid battery reduces trunk capacity. Reliance on touchscreens instead of buttons does create a bit of a learning curve.
title: Ergonomics

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Hybrid Sport 4dr Sedan (3.5L 6cyl gas/electric hybrid 7A)
summary: Getting in and out in tight parking spaces is easy thanks to short sedan doors and a low step-in height.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: The Q50's cabin is tastefully modern and built with praiseworthy materials. There's plenty of passenger space, but the hybrid battery reduces trunk capacity. Reliance on touchscreens instead of buttons does create a bit of a learning curve.
title: Ingress/Egress

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Hybrid Sport 4dr Sedan (3.5L 6cyl gas/electric hybrid 7A)
summary: There's ample headroom and legroom for taller adults in both front and rear seats. The smart design also helps to make the cabin feel even more accommodating.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: The Q50's cabin is tastefully modern and built with praiseworthy materials. There's plenty of passenger space, but the hybrid battery reduces trunk capacity. Reliance on touchscreens instead of buttons does create a bit of a learning curve.
title: Space/Room

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Hybrid Sport 4dr Sedan (3.5L 6cyl gas/electric hybrid 7A)
summary: The forward view is mostly unobstructed, but the tall trunk forces reliance on the standard rearview camera, optional around-view camera and parking sensors when backing into a space.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: The Q50's cabin is tastefully modern and built with praiseworthy materials. There's plenty of passenger space, but the hybrid battery reduces trunk capacity. Reliance on touchscreens instead of buttons does create a bit of a learning curve.
title: Visibility

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Hybrid Sport 4dr Sedan (3.5L 6cyl gas/electric hybrid 7A)
summary: Hybrid batteries shrink trunk capacity down to 9.4 cu-ft, much smaller than rivals, but you can still squeeze a golf bag or two back there. Interior storage cubbies/bins are adequate, but not generous.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: The Q50's cabin is tastefully modern and built with praiseworthy materials. There's plenty of passenger space, but the hybrid battery reduces trunk capacity. Reliance on touchscreens instead of buttons does create a bit of a learning curve.
title: Cargo/Storage

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Hybrid Sport 4dr Sedan (3.5L 6cyl gas/electric hybrid 7A)
summary: The Q50 is as well built as other luxury sedans with excellent materials and solid construction. It's very unlikely anyone would find much to complain about in this regard.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: With the Deluxe Technology package and navigation, this Q50 S Hybrid costs $53,655. That's about $3,000 more than a similarly equipped Lexus ES 300h, but $9,000 less than a BMW ActiveHybrid 3. All-wheel-drive is a unique option for $2,000.
title: Build Quality (vs. $)

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Hybrid Sport 4dr Sedan (3.5L 6cyl gas/electric hybrid 7A)
summary: Even in stock form, the Q50 S is generously equipped. Most of the options are grouped in large bundles, but the price is reasonable for what you get.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: With the Deluxe Technology package and navigation, this Q50 S Hybrid costs $53,655. That's about $3,000 more than a similarly equipped Lexus ES 300h, but $9,000 less than a BMW ActiveHybrid 3. All-wheel-drive is a unique option for $2,000.
title: Features(vs. $)

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Hybrid Sport 4dr Sedan (3.5L 6cyl gas/electric hybrid 7A)
summary: With a lack of sportiness, we would be inclined to consider a regular Q50 Hybrid over the Q50 S Hybrid and save $2,400. Even then, it would take more than six years to recoup the hybrid cost versus a gas-only Q50.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: With the Deluxe Technology package and navigation, this Q50 S Hybrid costs $53,655. That's about $3,000 more than a similarly equipped Lexus ES 300h, but $9,000 less than a BMW ActiveHybrid 3. All-wheel-drive is a unique option for $2,000.
title: Cost

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Hybrid Sport 4dr Sedan (3.5L 6cyl gas/electric hybrid 7A)
summary: EPA estimates of 30 mpg Combined (28 City/34 Highway) place the Q50 Hybrid between the 40-mpg Lexus ES 300h and the 23-mpg BMW ActiveHybrid 3. We averaged 31.1 mpg on our highway-heavy evaluation loop and 26.0 mpg overall.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: With the Deluxe Technology package and navigation, this Q50 S Hybrid costs $53,655. That's about $3,000 more than a similarly equipped Lexus ES 300h, but $9,000 less than a BMW ActiveHybrid 3. All-wheel-drive is a unique option for $2,000.
title: MPG

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Hybrid Sport 4dr Sedan (3.5L 6cyl gas/electric hybrid 7A)
summary: Infiniti's 4-year/60,000-mile basic warranty beats rivals by 10,000 miles and its 6-year/70,000-mile drivetrain coverage matches Lexus. BMW's ends at 4 years/50,000 miles.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: With the Deluxe Technology package and navigation, this Q50 S Hybrid costs $53,655. That's about $3,000 more than a similarly equipped Lexus ES 300h, but $9,000 less than a BMW ActiveHybrid 3. All-wheel-drive is a unique option for $2,000.
title: Warranty

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Hybrid Sport 4dr Sedan (3.5L 6cyl gas/electric hybrid 7A)
summary: 4 years/60,000 miles of roadside assistance is included but scheduled maintenance is not. Lexus covers the first two scheduled maintenances and BMW's maintenance is free for 4 years/50,000 miles.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: With the Deluxe Technology package and navigation, this Q50 S Hybrid costs $53,655. That's about $3,000 more than a similarly equipped Lexus ES 300h, but $9,000 less than a BMW ActiveHybrid 3. All-wheel-drive is a unique option for $2,000.
title: Ownership

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Hybrid Sport 4dr Sedan (3.5L 6cyl gas/electric hybrid 7A)
summary: We can forgive hybrids for some of their idiosyncrasies, but the Q50's are hard to ignore. Lurches under braking and acceleration will have passengers questioning your driving ability.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: The 2014 Infiniti Q50 S Hybrid is not fun to drive by any measure. As iconsistent and unpredictable as its driving manners are, it's merely tolerable in a daily commute. We were surprised how unimpressive the Hybrid is compared to the conventional Q50.
title: Driving Experience

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Hybrid Sport 4dr Sedan (3.5L 6cyl gas/electric hybrid 7A)
summary: The Q50 S Hybrid is an agreeable midsize luxury sedan ruined by a poorly executed hybrid drivetrain. Combined fuel economy estimates are 7-mpg better than the standard Q50, but the sacrifices required don't justify choosing the Hybrid.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: The 2014 Infiniti Q50 S Hybrid is not fun to drive by any measure. As iconsistent and unpredictable as its driving manners are, it's merely tolerable in a daily commute. We were surprised how unimpressive the Hybrid is compared to the conventional Q50.
title: Personality

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Sport 4dr Sedan (3.7L 6cyl 7A)
summary: The 328-horsepower V6 accelerates the Q50 strongly, and the 7-speed automatic shifts quickly and downshifts willingly. It's now quieter than ever, too. A standout powertrain in its class.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Dynamically a highly competent car that, in this Sport guise with summer tires, is finally able to demonstrate its true capability. Sharper, grippy-er and, of course, powerful. Drives smaller than it is, and that's a compliment.
title: Acceleration

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Sport 4dr Sedan (3.7L 6cyl 7A)
summary: Easy to modulate, consistent stops; good feel at pedal. Panic-stopping distance is exactly average for summer tire-equipped cars in this class.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Dynamically a highly competent car that, in this Sport guise with summer tires, is finally able to demonstrate its true capability. Sharper, grippy-er and, of course, powerful. Drives smaller than it is, and that's a compliment.
title: Braking

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Sport 4dr Sedan (3.7L 6cyl 7A)
summary: Quick, precise and builds effort well. It is a bit on the light-effort side. Natural feel from this car's steering rack. Test car not equipped with the steer-by-wire option.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Dynamically a highly competent car that, in this Sport guise with summer tires, is finally able to demonstrate its true capability. Sharper, grippy-er and, of course, powerful. Drives smaller than it is, and that's a compliment.
title: Steering

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Sport 4dr Sedan (3.7L 6cyl 7A)
summary: The Q50 Sport's summer tires and suspension tuning have revealed this chassis as a formidable sport sedan. Sharp, capable. Inspires confidence. High levels of grip and composure.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Dynamically a highly competent car that, in this Sport guise with summer tires, is finally able to demonstrate its true capability. Sharper, grippy-er and, of course, powerful. Drives smaller than it is, and that's a compliment.
title: Handling

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Sport 4dr Sedan (3.7L 6cyl 7A)
summary: A very pleasant and intuitive car with a willing and capable powertrain. Good manners in typical driving circumstances and a natural demeanor.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Dynamically a highly competent car that, in this Sport guise with summer tires, is finally able to demonstrate its true capability. Sharper, grippy-er and, of course, powerful. Drives smaller than it is, and that's a compliment.
title: Driveability

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Sport 4dr Sedan (3.7L 6cyl 7A)
summary: The seats in the Q50S are more comfortable and more supportive than the base seats. The bolstering is more prominent but not obtrusive. There's also an adjustable thigh bolster.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: The Sport variant rides better and is equipped with better seats than the non-S. It's comfortable and generally quieter than the G37, though road noise is still noticeable.
title: Seating Comfort

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Sport 4dr Sedan (3.7L 6cyl 7A)
summary: More compliant than the run-flat tire equipped base Q50. The ride in the Q50 S is calmer, absorbing pavement imperfections more adeptly. Firm yet compliant.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: The Sport variant rides better and is equipped with better seats than the non-S. It's comfortable and generally quieter than the G37, though road noise is still noticeable.
title: Ride Comfort

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Sport 4dr Sedan (3.7L 6cyl 7A)
summary: Good isolation from wind noise. Road noise is noticeable. Engine noise is better muted than in previous G37 iterations.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: The Sport variant rides better and is equipped with better seats than the non-S. It's comfortable and generally quieter than the G37, though road noise is still noticeable.
title: Quietness

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Sport 4dr Sedan (3.7L 6cyl 7A)
summary: Dual touchscreen nests most controls. It is sensitive to the touch and has logical screen flow, though is still subject to glare and fingerprints. No knobs for HVAC, only buttons.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Beautifully presented cabin looks and feels great. Conventional controls fall easily to hand. Touchscreen has usual drawbacks. A pleasant and spacious place in which to spend time.
title: Ergonomics

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Sport 4dr Sedan (3.7L 6cyl 7A)
summary: Its low step-in height and accomodating seats facilitate easy entrances. Doors swing open with surprising ease.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Beautifully presented cabin looks and feels great. Conventional controls fall easily to hand. Touchscreen has usual drawbacks. A pleasant and spacious place in which to spend time.

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Sport 4dr Sedan (3.7L 6cyl 7A)
summary: Airy cabin and contoured dashboard provide a usefully large space. Six-footers can occupy the backseat with headroom to spare.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Beautifully presented cabin looks and feels great. Conventional controls fall easily to hand. Touchscreen has usual drawbacks. A pleasant and spacious place in which to spend time.

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Sport 4dr Sedan (3.7L 6cyl 7A)
summary: Expansive view through the windshield. The rising beltline and relatively high rear decklid shrinks the view over your shoulder and out the rear window.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Beautifully presented cabin looks and feels great. Conventional controls fall easily to hand. Touchscreen has usual drawbacks. A pleasant and spacious place in which to spend time.

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Sport 4dr Sedan (3.7L 6cyl 7A)
summary: Ample cargo volume with a wide aperture. Swallows a good amount of gear. Note: the conventional spare tire option reduces cargo volume somewhat vs the normal car.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Beautifully presented cabin looks and feels great. Conventional controls fall easily to hand. Touchscreen has usual drawbacks. A pleasant and spacious place in which to spend time.

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Sport 4dr Sedan (3.7L 6cyl 7A)
summary: No issues to speak of, and perceived build quality (gaps and color matches) is on par with others in this highly competitive segment.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The Q50 brings tangible improvements to an already excellent car in virtually every area. Comfort, space, refinement and efficiency have all stepped forward, and the powertrain is terrific.

model.name: Q50
style.name: Sport 4dr Sedan (3.7L 6cyl 7A)
summary: Very pleasant car in which to spend time. This variant of the Q50 (Sport model with the non-active steering) appears to the be Goldilocks version of the Q50: It's just right.

summary: The Q50 Hybrid is surprisingly capable on a twisty, given the lack of trust, feedback and consistency. But it's an unpleasant experience regardless. When the driver gives quick steering inputs it just further highlights the system's delay.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The Q50 S Hybrid's 3.5-liter V6 and hybrid electric system combine to produce a healthy 360 hp, besting the Lexus ES 300h (200 hp) and BMW 3 Series ActiveHybrid (335 hp). The Q50 is fast for a luxury hybrid, but disappoints in terms of everyday driveability.
title: Handling

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Hybrid Sport 4dr Sedan (3.5L 6cyl gas/electric hybrid 7A)
summary: The oddites of the throttle, brake and steering inputs leave you guessing as to how the Q50 will react. It is far from enjoyable under most conditions, with annoying lurches and a disconnected feeling. This is exactly how to not do a hybrid.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The Q50 S Hybrid's 3.5-liter V6 and hybrid electric system combine to produce a healthy 360 hp, besting the Lexus ES 300h (200 hp) and BMW 3 Series ActiveHybrid (335 hp). The Q50 is fast for a luxury hybrid, but disappoints in terms of everyday driveability.
title: Driveability

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Hybrid Sport 4dr Sedan (3.5L 6cyl gas/electric hybrid 7A)
summary: The seats are well-shaped with 8 power adjustments and standard heat, but padding is on the firm side. Taller drivers may find the seat cushions too short. We felt some fatigue and the leather became stifling after just a few hours.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: The combination of a lurching drivetrain and an unyielding suspension mean the the Q50 S Hybrid can cause motion sickness for sensitive passengers. Compounding matters are seats which are merely average in terms of comfort.
title: Seating Comfort

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Hybrid Sport 4dr Sedan (3.5L 6cyl gas/electric hybrid 7A)
summary: Bumps of any size send noticeable jolts into the cabin. The Q50's stiff suspension makes for a busy, shopping cart-like ride over rough pavement. Most drivers and passengers will find it objectionable.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: The combination of a lurching drivetrain and an unyielding suspension mean the the Q50 S Hybrid can cause motion sickness for sensitive passengers. Compounding matters are seats which are merely average in terms of comfort.
title: Ride Comfort

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Hybrid Sport 4dr Sedan (3.5L 6cyl gas/electric hybrid 7A)
summary: Wind and road noises are pleasantly quieted, but road imperfections tend to cause a boomy thud that quickly becomes tiresome. Under moderate to heavy acceleration, engine noise is noticeable, but not unpleasant.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: The combination of a lurching drivetrain and an unyielding suspension mean the the Q50 S Hybrid can cause motion sickness for sensitive passengers. Compounding matters are seats which are merely average in terms of comfort.
title: Quietness

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Hybrid Sport 4dr Sedan (3.5L 6cyl gas/electric hybrid 7A)
summary: Two touchscreens split most controls and take some getting-used-to time. Small on-screen and physical button layout is unintuitive. The glossy lower screen is prone to glare and fingerprints, but both screens are responsive to inputs.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: The Q50's cabin is tastefully modern and built with praiseworthy materials. There's plenty of passenger space, but the hybrid battery reduces trunk capacity. Reliance on touchscreens instead of buttons does create a bit of a learning curve.
title: Ergonomics

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Hybrid Sport 4dr Sedan (3.5L 6cyl gas/electric hybrid 7A)
summary: Getting in and out in tight parking spaces is easy thanks to short sedan doors and a low step-in height.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: The Q50's cabin is tastefully modern and built with praiseworthy materials. There's plenty of passenger space, but the hybrid battery reduces trunk capacity. Reliance on touchscreens instead of buttons does create a bit of a learning curve.
title: Ingress/Egress

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Hybrid Sport 4dr Sedan (3.5L 6cyl gas/electric hybrid 7A)
summary: There's ample headroom and legroom for taller adults in both front and rear seats. The smart design also helps to make the cabin feel even more accommodating.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: The Q50's cabin is tastefully modern and built with praiseworthy materials. There's plenty of passenger space, but the hybrid battery reduces trunk capacity. Reliance on touchscreens instead of buttons does create a bit of a learning curve.
title: Space/Room

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Hybrid Sport 4dr Sedan (3.5L 6cyl gas/electric hybrid 7A)
summary: The forward view is mostly unobstructed, but the tall trunk forces reliance on the standard rearview camera, optional around-view camera and parking sensors when backing into a space.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: The Q50's cabin is tastefully modern and built with praiseworthy materials. There's plenty of passenger space, but the hybrid battery reduces trunk capacity. Reliance on touchscreens instead of buttons does create a bit of a learning curve.
title: Visibility

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Hybrid Sport 4dr Sedan (3.5L 6cyl gas/electric hybrid 7A)
summary: Hybrid batteries shrink trunk capacity down to 9.4 cu-ft, much smaller than rivals, but you can still squeeze a golf bag or two back there. Interior storage cubbies/bins are adequate, but not generous.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: The Q50's cabin is tastefully modern and built with praiseworthy materials. There's plenty of passenger space, but the hybrid battery reduces trunk capacity. Reliance on touchscreens instead of buttons does create a bit of a learning curve.
title: Cargo/Storage

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Hybrid Sport 4dr Sedan (3.5L 6cyl gas/electric hybrid 7A)
summary: The Q50 is as well built as other luxury sedans with excellent materials and solid construction. It's very unlikely anyone would find much to complain about in this regard.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: With the Deluxe Technology package and navigation, this Q50 S Hybrid costs $53,655. That's about $3,000 more than a similarly equipped Lexus ES 300h, but $9,000 less than a BMW ActiveHybrid 3. All-wheel-drive is a unique option for $2,000.
title: Build Quality (vs. $)

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Hybrid Sport 4dr Sedan (3.5L 6cyl gas/electric hybrid 7A)
summary: Even in stock form, the Q50 S is generously equipped. Most of the options are grouped in large bundles, but the price is reasonable for what you get.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: With the Deluxe Technology package and navigation, this Q50 S Hybrid costs $53,655. That's about $3,000 more than a similarly equipped Lexus ES 300h, but $9,000 less than a BMW ActiveHybrid 3. All-wheel-drive is a unique option for $2,000.
title: Features(vs. $)

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Hybrid Sport 4dr Sedan (3.5L 6cyl gas/electric hybrid 7A)
summary: With a lack of sportiness, we would be inclined to consider a regular Q50 Hybrid over the Q50 S Hybrid and save $2,400. Even then, it would take more than six years to recoup the hybrid cost versus a gas-only Q50.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: With the Deluxe Technology package and navigation, this Q50 S Hybrid costs $53,655. That's about $3,000 more than a similarly equipped Lexus ES 300h, but $9,000 less than a BMW ActiveHybrid 3. All-wheel-drive is a unique option for $2,000.
title: Cost

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Hybrid Sport 4dr Sedan (3.5L 6cyl gas/electric hybrid 7A)
summary: EPA estimates of 30 mpg Combined (28 City/34 Highway) place the Q50 Hybrid between the 40-mpg Lexus ES 300h and the 23-mpg BMW ActiveHybrid 3. We averaged 31.1 mpg on our highway-heavy evaluation loop and 26.0 mpg overall.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: With the Deluxe Technology package and navigation, this Q50 S Hybrid costs $53,655. That's about $3,000 more than a similarly equipped Lexus ES 300h, but $9,000 less than a BMW ActiveHybrid 3. All-wheel-drive is a unique option for $2,000.
title: MPG

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Hybrid Sport 4dr Sedan (3.5L 6cyl gas/electric hybrid 7A)
summary: Infiniti's 4-year/60,000-mile basic warranty beats rivals by 10,000 miles and its 6-year/70,000-mile drivetrain coverage matches Lexus. BMW's ends at 4 years/50,000 miles.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: With the Deluxe Technology package and navigation, this Q50 S Hybrid costs $53,655. That's about $3,000 more than a similarly equipped Lexus ES 300h, but $9,000 less than a BMW ActiveHybrid 3. All-wheel-drive is a unique option for $2,000.
title: Warranty

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Hybrid Sport 4dr Sedan (3.5L 6cyl gas/electric hybrid 7A)
summary: 4 years/60,000 miles of roadside assistance is included but scheduled maintenance is not. Lexus covers the first two scheduled maintenances and BMW's maintenance is free for 4 years/50,000 miles.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: With the Deluxe Technology package and navigation, this Q50 S Hybrid costs $53,655. That's about $3,000 more than a similarly equipped Lexus ES 300h, but $9,000 less than a BMW ActiveHybrid 3. All-wheel-drive is a unique option for $2,000.
title: Ownership

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Hybrid Sport 4dr Sedan (3.5L 6cyl gas/electric hybrid 7A)
summary: We can forgive hybrids for some of their idiosyncrasies, but the Q50's are hard to ignore. Lurches under braking and acceleration will have passengers questioning your driving ability.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: The 2014 Infiniti Q50 S Hybrid is not fun to drive by any measure. As iconsistent and unpredictable as its driving manners are, it's merely tolerable in a daily commute. We were surprised how unimpressive the Hybrid is compared to the conventional Q50.
title: Driving Experience

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Hybrid Sport 4dr Sedan (3.5L 6cyl gas/electric hybrid 7A)
summary: The Q50 S Hybrid is an agreeable midsize luxury sedan ruined by a poorly executed hybrid drivetrain. Combined fuel economy estimates are 7-mpg better than the standard Q50, but the sacrifices required don't justify choosing the Hybrid.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: The 2014 Infiniti Q50 S Hybrid is not fun to drive by any measure. As iconsistent and unpredictable as its driving manners are, it's merely tolerable in a daily commute. We were surprised how unimpressive the Hybrid is compared to the conventional Q50.
title: Personality

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Sport 4dr Sedan (3.7L 6cyl 7A)
summary: The 328-horsepower V6 accelerates the Q50 strongly, and the 7-speed automatic shifts quickly and downshifts willingly. It's now quieter than ever, too. A standout powertrain in its class.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Dynamically a highly competent car that, in this Sport guise with summer tires, is finally able to demonstrate its true capability. Sharper, grippy-er and, of course, powerful. Drives smaller than it is, and that's a compliment.
title: Acceleration

make.name: Infiniti
model.name: Q50
style.name: Sport 4dr Sedan (3.7L 6cyl 7A)
summary: Easy to modulate, consistent stops; good feel at pedal. Panic-stopping distance is exactly average for summer tire-equipped cars in this class.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Dynamically a highly competent car that, in this Sport guise with summer tires, is finally able to demonstrate its true capability. Sharper, grippy-er and, of course, powerful. Drives smaller than it is, and that's a compliment.

model.name: Q50
style.name: Sport 4dr Sedan (3.7L 6cyl 7A)
summary: Quick, precise and builds effort well. It is a bit on the light-effort side. Natural feel from this car's steering rack. Test car not equipped with the steer-by-wire option.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Dynamically a highly competent car that, in this Sport guise with summer tires, is finally able to demonstrate its true capability. Sharper, grippy-er and, of course, powerful. Drives smaller than it is, and that's a compliment.

summary: The Q50 Sport's summer tires and suspension tuning have revealed this chassis as a formidable sport sedan. Sharp, capable. Inspires confidence. High levels of grip and composure.

summary: More compliant than the run-flat tire equipped base Q50. The ride in the Q50 S is calmer, absorbing pavement imperfections more adeptly. Firm yet compliant.

ratings.summary: Beautifully presented cabin looks and feels great. Conventional controls fall easily to hand. Touchscreen has usual drawbacks. A pleasant and spacious place in which to spend time.

summary: Very pleasant car in which to spend time. This variant of the Q50 (Sport model with the non-active steering) appears to the be Goldilocks version of the Q50: It's just right.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive

model.name: Q50
style.name: Sport 4dr Sedan (3.7L 6cyl 7A)
summary: An enthusiastic chassis is unlocked when you select the Sport variant, and in terms of its prowess the car still feels like a G37 despite the slightly larger size. This is, again, a good thing.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: The Q50 is fun to drive by virtue of its alert, strong powertrain and sharp steering. Handling is noticeably better in the Q50S than the non-S.

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Cherokee
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: The optional 3.2-liter V6 accelerates the Trailhawk to 60 mph in about 8 seconds flat, a decent performance in this class, especially considering the off-highway potential.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The Trailhawk gives up a little in ultimate handling and acceleration in return for off-road capability that's a cut above any other crossover. It's still nicely balanced. Those who don't go off-road can get the Latitude or Limited versions.
title: Acceleration

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Cherokee
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: Nicely firm and responsive brake pedal in daily use. The Trailhawk's knobby off-road tires result in a slightly long 131-foot panic stop from 60 mph; regular Cherokees should do better.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The Trailhawk gives up a little in ultimate handling and acceleration in return for off-road capability that's a cut above any other crossover. It's still nicely balanced. Those who don't go off-road can get the Latitude or Limited versions.
title: Braking

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Cherokee
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: Responds predictably and isn't over-sensitive. Driver gets a good impression of what's going on down where the rubber meets the road, but there's zero kickback in rocky off-road terrain.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The Trailhawk gives up a little in ultimate handling and acceleration in return for off-road capability that's a cut above any other crossover. It's still nicely balanced. Those who don't go off-road can get the Latitude or Limited versions.
title: Steering

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Cherokee
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: The Trailhawk's off-road tires limit ultimate on-road grip, but it retains good balance and coordination. And body roll isn't excessive, either, despite the high-riding stance.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The Trailhawk gives up a little in ultimate handling and acceleration in return for off-road capability that's a cut above any other crossover. It's still nicely balanced. Those who don't go off-road can get the Latitude or Limited versions.
title: Handling

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Cherokee
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: The Cherokee's 9-speed transmission (yes, you read that right) serves up smooth upshifts and ready downshifts. Initial throttle response is subdued, making for easy low-speed control.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The Trailhawk gives up a little in ultimate handling and acceleration in return for off-road capability that's a cut above any other crossover. It's still nicely balanced. Those who don't go off-road can get the Latitude or Limited versions.
title: Driveability

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Cherokee
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: With the $495 tow package it can tow 4,500 lbs, the most in the small crossover class. Trailhawk (or Latitude/Limited with 2-spd transfer case option) can also be flat-towed behind a motorhome.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The Trailhawk gives up a little in ultimate handling and acceleration in return for off-road capability that's a cut above any other crossover. It's still nicely balanced. Those who don't go off-road can get the Latitude or Limited versions.
title: Towing

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Cherokee
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: Among crossovers, the Trailhawk has no equal. Articulation is average, but its knobby tires, generous clearance, low-range gearing and rear locker are unmatched in this class. Also, full-size spare tire!
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The Trailhawk gives up a little in ultimate handling and acceleration in return for off-road capability that's a cut above any other crossover. It's still nicely balanced. Those who don't go off-road can get the Latitude or Limited versions.
title: Off-Road

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Cherokee
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: Easy to find a comfortable driving position, and the front seats proved supportive and comfortable throughout an all-day off-road trip. Our backseat passenger was equally impressed.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: Despite appearances, the extra beefiness of the Trailhawk doesn't translate into extra harshness. It remains a comfortable and quiet machine you could happily drive every day.
title: Seating Comfort

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Cherokee
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: The suspension is tuned slightly toward the soft side to promote off-road flexibility, but it's well-damped, too. The combination makes for a smooth and pleasant ride on and off the pavement.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: Despite appearances, the extra beefiness of the Trailhawk doesn't translate into extra harshness. It remains a comfortable and quiet machine you could happily drive every day.

style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: The optional 3.2-liter V6 is quiet and unobtrusive, unless you mash the throttle. The Trailhawk's bigger off-road tires are quieter than expected, but there is occasional faint tread noise.
ratings.title: Comfort

ratings.summary: The 2014 Cherokee Trailhawk does a lot of things right. There's plenty of room, it's easy to climb in and out of, and the controls are mostly self-explanatory. You won't find yourself thumbing through the owner's manual that much.
