model.name: Cherokee
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: Rear cargo space is good-sized but not class-leading, probably because there's a full-size spare tire under the floor. Rear seats fold flat for more room.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: The 2014 Cherokee Trailhawk does a lot of things right. There's plenty of room, it's easy to climb in and out of, and the controls are mostly self-explanatory. You won't find yourself thumbing through the owner's manual that much.
title: Cargo/Storage

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Cherokee
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: Looks well-built inside and out, but a couple of the interior trim pieces are simpy average. Still, nothing here is likely to disappoint.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Yes, it's pricier than a Mazda CX-5 or Honda CR-V on the face of it, but the 2014 Jeep Cherokee has more off-road potential and more high-end options. The Trailhawk V6 is unique in this segment, but it also has a unique appetitie for gasoline.
title: Build Quality (vs. $)

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Cherokee
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: Our fairly-loaded Trailhawk cost about $36,000, but the competition has no similar off-road drivetrain, V6 engine option, brawny tires or 9-speed transmission.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Yes, it's pricier than a Mazda CX-5 or Honda CR-V on the face of it, but the 2014 Jeep Cherokee has more off-road potential and more high-end options. The Trailhawk V6 is unique in this segment, but it also has a unique appetitie for gasoline.
title: Features(vs. $)

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Cherokee
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: Cherokee pricing and equipment starts off similar to the competition, at a little over $23,000, but unique options such as adaptive cruise, ventilated leather seats and the big V6 jack the price up.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Yes, it's pricier than a Mazda CX-5 or Honda CR-V on the face of it, but the 2014 Jeep Cherokee has more off-road potential and more high-end options. The Trailhawk V6 is unique in this segment, but it also has a unique appetitie for gasoline.
title: Cost

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Cherokee
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: The Trailhawk V6 is the thirstiest version of the Cherokee at 20 mpg Combined (18 City/25 Highway). The 2.4-liter Limited 4x4 is good for 24 mpg Combined, which is far more competitive.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Yes, it's pricier than a Mazda CX-5 or Honda CR-V on the face of it, but the 2014 Jeep Cherokee has more off-road potential and more high-end options. The Trailhawk V6 is unique in this segment, but it also has a unique appetitie for gasoline.
title: MPG

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Cherokee
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: The basic warranty is a fairly basic 3 yrs/36,000 miles, but the powertrain is covered for 5 yrs/100,000 miles, which is great considering the new engine and transmission.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Yes, it's pricier than a Mazda CX-5 or Honda CR-V on the face of it, but the 2014 Jeep Cherokee has more off-road potential and more high-end options. The Trailhawk V6 is unique in this segment, but it also has a unique appetitie for gasoline.
title: Warranty

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Cherokee
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: Roadside assistance up to and including towing is provided for 5 yrs/100,000 miles. There is no free scheduled maintenance program.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Yes, it's pricier than a Mazda CX-5 or Honda CR-V on the face of it, but the 2014 Jeep Cherokee has more off-road potential and more high-end options. The Trailhawk V6 is unique in this segment, but it also has a unique appetitie for gasoline.
title: Ownership

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Cherokee
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: It's not a true rock-crawler like the Cherokee of old, but it is the most capable of the new breed of compact crossovers. It has a go-anywhere feel that other CUVs lack.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: The Trailhawk feels nicely planted on the pavement. And we spent all day exploring under-maintained fire roads in the Trailhawk, and it did an admirable job. It didn't beat us up in the process, which made the trip that much more fun.
title: Driving Experience

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Cherokee
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: The Cherokee's unique front end styling earns it a lot of looks, most of them approving. The Trailhawk treatment gives it a veneer of toughness that's much more than a veneer.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: The Trailhawk feels nicely planted on the pavement. And we spent all day exploring under-maintained fire roads in the Trailhawk, and it did an admirable job. It didn't beat us up in the process, which made the trip that much more fun.
title: Personality

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Compass
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 6A)
summary: The 6-sp automatic helps the wheezy 2.4-liter 172-hp 4-cylinder get the Compass to 60 mph in 9.4 sec, similar to the Honda CR-V. But in most settings it feels underwhelming and the automatic is overly "shifty."
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The adoption of a new transmission improves the Compass' acceleration to 60 mph by almost one second, which is impressive, though still far from quick. The Compass steers well enough, but it has surprisingly low limits.
title: Acceleration

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Compass
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 6A)
summary: Significant nosedive with some instability during our panic-stop test, yet still a reasonable 60-0 distance of 121 feet. Around town the pedal action was linear and the brakes felt powerful enough.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The adoption of a new transmission improves the Compass' acceleration to 60 mph by almost one second, which is impressive, though still far from quick. The Compass steers well enough, but it has surprisingly low limits.
title: Braking

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Compass
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 6A)
summary: Natural weighting, not too light or too heavy, turns in nicely for corners. But your hands never feel overly connected to the front tires, thanks to the syrupy sensation of the hydraulic assist.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The adoption of a new transmission improves the Compass' acceleration to 60 mph by almost one second, which is impressive, though still far from quick. The Compass steers well enough, but it has surprisingly low limits.
title: Steering

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Compass
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 6A)
summary: The tires squeal early and the stability control cuts in often when driving at a moderately enthusiastic pace on backroads. The suspension system isn't exactly fantastic at handling mid-corner bumps.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The adoption of a new transmission improves the Compass' acceleration to 60 mph by almost one second, which is impressive, though still far from quick. The Compass steers well enough, but it has surprisingly low limits.
title: Handling

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Compass
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 6A)
summary: The Compass needed to downshift from 6th gear to 4th to maintain 70 mph up our sustained grade. There are some problematic rear three-quarter views. Gas pedal and brakes operate smoothly.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The adoption of a new transmission improves the Compass' acceleration to 60 mph by almost one second, which is impressive, though still far from quick. The Compass steers well enough, but it has surprisingly low limits.
title: Driveability

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Compass
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 6A)
summary: With the Trailer Tow Prep group, the Compass can tow a maximum of 2,000 pounds. That's better than the Ford Escape and Honda CR-V, equal to the Kia Sportage.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The adoption of a new transmission improves the Compass' acceleration to 60 mph by almost one second, which is impressive, though still far from quick. The Compass steers well enough, but it has surprisingly low limits.
title: Towing

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Compass
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 6A)
summary: When not equipped with the available low range and some other extra-cost off-road options, the Compass is only marginally better in the dirt than your average crossover SUV.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The adoption of a new transmission improves the Compass' acceleration to 60 mph by almost one second, which is impressive, though still far from quick. The Compass steers well enough, but it has surprisingly low limits.
title: Off-Road

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Compass
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 6A)
summary: The Limited's leather front seats are comfy, though the bolstered seatbacks could prove narrow for some. Good armrest placement. Rear seatbacks recline, have plenty of padding, but no fold-down center armrest.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: Seat comfort is a Compass strong suit, with all-day-capable seats front and rear. Unfortunately the ride is harsher than you'd expect, and the 4-cylinder engine is loud and buzzy.
title: Seating Comfort

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Compass
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 6A)
summary: Initially the Compass exhibits a soft ride. But once you start hitting actual bumps it gets bouncy and the shocks fail to smooth out the harshness. Suspension is noisy in operation. Not a good city vehicle.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: Seat comfort is a Compass strong suit, with all-day-capable seats front and rear. Unfortunately the ride is harsher than you'd expect, and the 4-cylinder engine is loud and buzzy.
title: Ride Comfort

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Compass
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 6A)
summary: Boomy inside at freeway speeds. Droney 4-cylinder gets loud above 3,000 rpm, vibrations come through steering wheel at 5,000 rpm. High degree of tire noise, some wind whistling at base of front windows.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: Seat comfort is a Compass strong suit, with all-day-capable seats front and rear. Unfortunately the ride is harsher than you'd expect, and the 4-cylinder engine is loud and buzzy.
title: Quietness

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Compass
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 6A)
summary: Too many steps to pair phone, and system wouldn't read our iPod. Plain-looking gauges, small center stack screen, but heat/air knobs nice and large. Low-rent nav graphics. Steering wheel controls work well.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Some improved interior materials here, particularly on the Limited model tested. But while most controls are easy to use, they still look/feel kinda cheap. Lengthy phone pairing, tight rear entryway will prove problematic for bigger folks.
title: Ergonomics

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Compass
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 6A)
summary: Perfect front step-in height and no worries about hitting head on roof. Rear doors don't open wide at all, tiny entryway. Tall rear side sills force you to lift feet up to get out.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Some improved interior materials here, particularly on the Limited model tested. But while most controls are easy to use, they still look/feel kinda cheap. Lengthy phone pairing, tight rear entryway will prove problematic for bigger folks.
title: Ingress/Egress

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Compass
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 6A)
summary: Good door-side elbow room, decent headroom despite sunroof. Fairly slim center console doesn't hamper driver's right knee much. Excellent rear headroom, though door-side elbow room compromised by wheelwell.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Some improved interior materials here, particularly on the Limited model tested. But while most controls are easy to use, they still look/feel kinda cheap. Lengthy phone pairing, tight rear entryway will prove problematic for bigger folks.
title: Space/Room

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Compass
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 6A)
summary: Thick and long windshield pillars hurt ability to look through turns. Multiple posts make for challenging lane changes. Rearview camera with parking lines comes standard on Limited, but screen is small, no sonar.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Some improved interior materials here, particularly on the Limited model tested. But while most controls are easy to use, they still look/feel kinda cheap. Lengthy phone pairing, tight rear entryway will prove problematic for bigger folks.
title: Visibility

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Compass
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 6A)
summary: No front bin, tiny door pockets, deep center bin is too rearward. The 22.7 cu-ft trunk is small for segment, but rear seats fold easily and front passenger seat folds flat. Hatch opens nice and high.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Some improved interior materials here, particularly on the Limited model tested. But while most controls are easy to use, they still look/feel kinda cheap. Lengthy phone pairing, tight rear entryway will prove problematic for bigger folks.
title: Cargo/Storage

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Compass
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 6A)
summary: Improved materials for 2014. This top-level trim has nice stitching and leather work but still plenty of hard-touch surfaces. The noisy suspension is disconcerting. The driver's seatback lever feels cheap as do interior buttons.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The Compass starts at $19,590, but keep in mind that's with the smaller 2.0-liter 4-cyl and a 5-speed manual transmission. Interior materials were improved for 2014, but it still has an air of cheapness. Fuel economy is below average.
title: Build Quality (vs. $)

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Compass
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 6A)
summary: The top Compass Limited 4x4 starts at $28,790, with a backup camera, heated front seats, fold-flat front passenger seat, a leather steering wheel and satellite radio. Bluetooth and a USB port cost extra.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The Compass starts at $19,590, but keep in mind that's with the smaller 2.0-liter 4-cyl and a 5-speed manual transmission. Interior materials were improved for 2014, but it still has an air of cheapness. Fuel economy is below average.
title: Features(vs. $)

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Compass
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 6A)
summary: Our Compass Limited tester had options like the $1,295 Sun/Sound group with two flip-down hatch speakers that work well. Other options included Bluetooth and navigation, for an as-tested price of $31,370.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The Compass starts at $19,590, but keep in mind that's with the smaller 2.0-liter 4-cyl and a 5-speed manual transmission. Interior materials were improved for 2014, but it still has an air of cheapness. Fuel economy is below average.
title: Cost

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Compass
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 6A)
summary: The EPA rates the Compass at 23 mpg Combined (21 City/27 Highway), below-average numbers for the segment. We averaged 22.0 mpg overall and 24.6 mpg on our 116-mile evaluation loop.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The Compass starts at $19,590, but keep in mind that's with the smaller 2.0-liter 4-cyl and a 5-speed manual transmission. Interior materials were improved for 2014, but it still has an air of cheapness. Fuel economy is below average.
title: MPG

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Compass
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 6A)
summary: The Compass' 3-year/36,000-mile basic warranty is average for the class, but the 5-yr/100,000-mi drivetrain coverage is better than most, other than the Kia Sportage's 10-yr/100,000-mi plan.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The Compass starts at $19,590, but keep in mind that's with the smaller 2.0-liter 4-cyl and a 5-speed manual transmission. Interior materials were improved for 2014, but it still has an air of cheapness. Fuel economy is below average.
title: Warranty

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Compass
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 6A)
summary: A 5-year/100,000-mile roadside assistance plan tops the major competitors, including the Kia Sportage. The Jeep doesn't offer a free maintenance plan, but neither do its main rivals.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The Compass starts at $19,590, but keep in mind that's with the smaller 2.0-liter 4-cyl and a 5-speed manual transmission. Interior materials were improved for 2014, but it still has an air of cheapness. Fuel economy is below average.
title: Ownership

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Compass
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 6A)
summary: There's too much engine noise and suspension harshness. Rivals like the Honda CR-V, Ford Escape, Kia Sportage and Subaru XV Crosstrek will offer better experiences for most people.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: Without true off-road capabilities, there's little about the Compass that screams "fun-to-drive." It doesn't even hint at it. On-road limits are low and the weak and wheezy four-cylinder does nothing to get you excited. Ever.
title: Driving Experience

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Compass
style.name: Limited 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 6A)
summary: The funky styling of the Compass isn't doing it any favors. We appreciate the fold-down hatch speakers and the rear pop-out flashlight, but really the Compass needs to be a better-driving vehicle to be competitive.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: Without true off-road capabilities, there's little about the Compass that screams "fun-to-drive." It doesn't even hint at it. On-road limits are low and the weak and wheezy four-cylinder does nothing to get you excited. Ever.
title: Personality

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Grand Cherokee
style.name: Summit 4dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 8A)
summary: The EcoDiesel 3.0-liter V6 is all about torque, a full 420 lb-ft worth. With 0-60 mph in 7.7 seconds, it's quicker than the V6 gasoline GC. The 8-speed automatic is smooth, though the shifts are slow.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The new EcoDiesel V6 is the way to go if you're serious about fuel mileage, towing and off-roading. Plus, it's actually quicker than the gasoline V6 version. While off-road grip is sensational, on-road handling is mediocre at best. The top-level Summit model tested here is the only GC that's not Trail Rated.
title: Acceleration

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Grand Cherokee
style.name: Summit 4dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 8A)
summary: The Grand Cherokee nosedives and squirms during full panic stops, with a best distance from 60 mph of 121 feet, which is average. Although we noticed some fade in testing, around town the brakes provided decent power.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The new EcoDiesel V6 is the way to go if you're serious about fuel mileage, towing and off-roading. Plus, it's actually quicker than the gasoline V6 version. While off-road grip is sensational, on-road handling is mediocre at best. The top-level Summit model tested here is the only GC that's not Trail Rated.
title: Braking

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Grand Cherokee
style.name: Summit 4dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 8A)
summary: The GC's steering has a light effort, which should suit most people. Unfortunately it also doesn't have much in the way of feel, so you never really know what the front tires are up to on road or off.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The new EcoDiesel V6 is the way to go if you're serious about fuel mileage, towing and off-roading. Plus, it's actually quicker than the gasoline V6 version. While off-road grip is sensational, on-road handling is mediocre at best. The top-level Summit model tested here is the only GC that's not Trail Rated.
title: Steering

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Grand Cherokee
style.name: Summit 4dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 8A)
summary: Whether at the test track or on backroads, the GC feels lethargic and heavy. It has little roll control, meaning it leans considerably through corners. The stability control intervenes early and often.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The new EcoDiesel V6 is the way to go if you're serious about fuel mileage, towing and off-roading. Plus, it's actually quicker than the gasoline V6 version. While off-road grip is sensational, on-road handling is mediocre at best. The top-level Summit model tested here is the only GC that's not Trail Rated.
title: Handling

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Grand Cherokee
style.name: Summit 4dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 8A)
summary: The 8-speed automatic shifts seamlessly, though there's some jerkiness in stop-and-go traffic, and the engine requires more revs than you expect to get going. So much torque it easily holds one gear up long grades.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The new EcoDiesel V6 is the way to go if you're serious about fuel mileage, towing and off-roading. Plus, it's actually quicker than the gasoline V6 version. While off-road grip is sensational, on-road handling is mediocre at best. The top-level Summit model tested here is the only GC that's not Trail Rated.
title: Driveability

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Grand Cherokee
style.name: Summit 4dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 8A)
summary: The EcoDiesel and Hemi V8 4x4s have the same tow rating: 7,200 pounds. Two-wheel drive models can tow 7,400, while gasoline V6 models can tow 6,200 pounds.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The new EcoDiesel V6 is the way to go if you're serious about fuel mileage, towing and off-roading. Plus, it's actually quicker than the gasoline V6 version. While off-road grip is sensational, on-road handling is mediocre at best. The top-level Summit model tested here is the only GC that's not Trail Rated.
title: Towing

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Grand Cherokee
style.name: Summit 4dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 8A)
summary: Oddly, this Summit model, with its low front fascia, isn't even Trail Rated, despite Quadra-Drive II and height-adjustable air suspension. Still, it's ultra capable at scurrying up steep off-road trails.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The new EcoDiesel V6 is the way to go if you're serious about fuel mileage, towing and off-roading. Plus, it's actually quicker than the gasoline V6 version. While off-road grip is sensational, on-road handling is mediocre at best. The top-level Summit model tested here is the only GC that's not Trail Rated.
title: Off-Road

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Grand Cherokee
style.name: Summit 4dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 8A)
summary: The front seats are wide, overstuffed with padding, yet surprisingy firm. Adjustable lumbar and heating/cooling up front. Well-padded armrests. Rear reclining seatbacks have easy-access lever. Middle seat is livable.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: The Grand Cherokee has excellent sound deadening plus supportive seats and plenty of room to stretch out. Although we expected good things from the air suspension, it suffers in the city and is largely incapable of soaking up smaller bumps.
title: Seating Comfort

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Grand Cherokee
style.name: Summit 4dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 8A)
summary: Oddly, the Summit's air suspension struggles to soak up smaller pavement ripples, allowing significant vibration into the cabin. Definitely not the best urban vehicle. Big bumps, on the other hand, are absorbed with ease.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: The Grand Cherokee has excellent sound deadening plus supportive seats and plenty of room to stretch out. Although we expected good things from the air suspension, it suffers in the city and is largely incapable of soaking up smaller bumps.
title: Ride Comfort

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Grand Cherokee
style.name: Summit 4dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 8A)
summary: Diesel clatter makes it louder at idle than rival gas engines, but the EcoDiesel is considerably quieter at full-throttle, partially because it doesn't rev as high. Dual-pane front glass, nearly zero wind noise.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: The Grand Cherokee has excellent sound deadening plus supportive seats and plenty of room to stretch out. Although we expected good things from the air suspension, it suffers in the city and is largely incapable of soaking up smaller bumps.
title: Quietness

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Grand Cherokee
style.name: Summit 4dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 8A)
summary: Great new steering wheel. Solid, substantial controls. Large, grippy knobs for stereo volume/tuning/fan speed. But some climate control functions require 3-4 button pushes through the touchscreen. Ridiculous.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Jeep made some improvements to the GC's interior for 2014. The Uconnect infotainment system, materials and controls are at the top of the class, though the touchscreen forces too many steps for certain functions.
title: Ergonomics

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Grand Cherokee
style.name: Summit 4dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 8A)
summary: Wide-opening front doors. Step-in height is higher than average, but air suspension can be lowered when parked. Rear doors also open wide, though opening is compromised by rear wheelwell and wide rocker panels.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Jeep made some improvements to the GC's interior for 2014. The Uconnect infotainment system, materials and controls are at the top of the class, though the touchscreen forces too many steps for certain functions.
title: Ingress/Egress

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Grand Cherokee
style.name: Summit 4dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 8A)
summary: Despite the high seating position, there's still generous headroom up front. Good elbow room, too, and center console leaves room for driver's right knee. Excellent rear foot- and knee room, plenty of headroom.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Jeep made some improvements to the GC's interior for 2014. The Uconnect infotainment system, materials and controls are at the top of the class, though the touchscreen forces too many steps for certain functions.
title: Space/Room

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Grand Cherokee
style.name: Summit 4dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 8A)
summary: The windshield pillars are fairly long and thick, hampering views on curvy roads. Most other pillars are narrow, and the tall side windows aid lane changes. Standard rearview camera and front/rear parking sonar.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Jeep made some improvements to the GC's interior for 2014. The Uconnect infotainment system, materials and controls are at the top of the class, though the touchscreen forces too many steps for certain functions.
title: Visibility

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Grand Cherokee
style.name: Summit 4dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 8A)
summary: Front bin has little space and cheap-feeling door. Door pockets are too narrow for most hands. Good anti-tip cupholders. Rear seats have one-touch fold-down. Trunk houses full-size spare, still offers 36.3 cu-ft.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Jeep made some improvements to the GC's interior for 2014. The Uconnect infotainment system, materials and controls are at the top of the class, though the touchscreen forces too many steps for certain functions.
title: Cargo/Storage

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Grand Cherokee
style.name: Summit 4dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 8A)
summary: Other than the front bin's flimsy door, the materials in this top-level GC Summit are fantastic. Tight yet supple leather, cool-looking open-pore wood trim, leather/wood steering wheel and a beautiful suede headliner.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Although it may come as a shock that you can outfit a Jeep to $57,190, there are a ton of safety and luxury features here. This is a well-built truck, and the diesel's fuel mileage will pay for itself versus the Hemi V8 in a couple years.
title: Build Quality (vs. $)

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Grand Cherokee
style.name: Summit 4dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 8A)
summary: The Grand Cherokee Summit 4x4 comes chock full of luxury/tech features, including a backup camera, blind spot detection, forward collision warning and vented seats. But then, it better for $52,190.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Although it may come as a shock that you can outfit a Jeep to $57,190, there are a ton of safety and luxury features here. This is a well-built truck, and the diesel's fuel mileage will pay for itself versus the Hemi V8 in a couple years.
title: Features(vs. $)

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Grand Cherokee
style.name: Summit 4dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 8A)
summary: The $5,000 EcoDiesel option includes the top-level Quadra-Drive II 4wd system, an electronic limited-slip rear differential and vented rear brakes. It's worth it for the fuel mileage, tow capability and off-roading.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Although it may come as a shock that you can outfit a Jeep to $57,190, there are a ton of safety and luxury features here. This is a well-built truck, and the diesel's fuel mileage will pay for itself versus the Hemi V8 in a couple years.
title: Cost

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Grand Cherokee
style.name: Summit 4dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 8A)
summary: The EPA rates the GC EcoDiesel at 24 mpg Combined (21 City/28 Highway). We averaged a so-so 22.3 mpg in varied driving, but an impressive 27.4 mpg on our 116-mile evaluation loop.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Although it may come as a shock that you can outfit a Jeep to $57,190, there are a ton of safety and luxury features here. This is a well-built truck, and the diesel's fuel mileage will pay for itself versus the Hemi V8 in a couple years.
title: MPG

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Grand Cherokee
style.name: Summit 4dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 8A)
summary: The Grand Cherokee's 3-year/36,000-mile basic warranty matches rivals, but the drivetrain warranty is good for 5 years or 100,000 miles, versus most competitor's 60,000-mile plans.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Although it may come as a shock that you can outfit a Jeep to $57,190, there are a ton of safety and luxury features here. This is a well-built truck, and the diesel's fuel mileage will pay for itself versus the Hemi V8 in a couple years.
title: Warranty

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Grand Cherokee
style.name: Summit 4dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 8A)
summary: The 5-year/100,000-mile roadside assistance again tops most rivals mileage-wise. But Toyota and its 4Runner offer free maintenance for 2 years/25,000 miles.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Although it may come as a shock that you can outfit a Jeep to $57,190, there are a ton of safety and luxury features here. This is a well-built truck, and the diesel's fuel mileage will pay for itself versus the Hemi V8 in a couple years.
title: Ownership

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Grand Cherokee
style.name: Summit 4dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 8A)
summary: Some low-speed lurchiness from the transmission/throttle and a stiffer-than-expected ride mar what is otherwise quite a nice, low-key and exceptionally quiet driving environment. This is an easy vehicle to drive.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: In off-road or snowy conditions, we could see the Grand Cherokee being fun. Most of the time it's simply a solid, competent-feeling SUV. Especially with the turbodiesel, which is happy scooting around town or idling all day in the dirt.
title: Driving Experience

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Grand Cherokee
style.name: Summit 4dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 8A)
summary: The clattering turbodiesel and the Grand Cherokee's rock-crawling potential give this SUV some personality. And with 420 lb-ft of torque and low gearing thanks to the new 8-speed automatic, this thing is pretty quick.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: In off-road or snowy conditions, we could see the Grand Cherokee being fun. Most of the time it's simply a solid, competent-feeling SUV. Especially with the turbodiesel, which is happy scooting around town or idling all day in the dirt.
title: Personality

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Renegade
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: Accelerates from zero-to-60-mph in a lackluster 9.4 seconds, which is par for the course in the emerging sub-compact SUV segment, and not half bad for an off-road oriented one. Feels fairly eager around town thanks to generous low-end torque.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Its 2.4-liter, 180-hp engine is more powerful than its competition, but acceleration is merely average because the nine-speed transmission is programmed to seek higher gears sooner than drivers might prefer. Braking is reassuring and handling is nimble, and it's uniquely capable in the dirt.
title: Acceleration

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Renegade
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: Trailhawk's knobbier, dirt-friendly off-road tires extend 60-to-zero panic stop distance out to 128 feet, a more average performance than the Lattitude. Pedal feels just as firm and reassuring, and there's no squirm or pull to one side.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Its 2.4-liter, 180-hp engine is more powerful than its competition, but acceleration is merely average because the nine-speed transmission is programmed to seek higher gears sooner than drivers might prefer. Braking is reassuring and handling is nimble, and it's uniquely capable in the dirt.
title: Braking

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Renegade
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: Nicely-weighted steering delivers a solid sense of straight-ahead when cruising the highway, and effort and feel build up nicely as you turn the wheel. Crisp steering response embues this little Jeep with a nimble, playful feel.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Its 2.4-liter, 180-hp engine is more powerful than its competition, but acceleration is merely average because the nine-speed transmission is programmed to seek higher gears sooner than drivers might prefer. Braking is reassuring and handling is nimble, and it's uniquely capable in the dirt.
title: Steering

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Renegade
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: Traverses mountain roads with good balance and composure. But you can sense that it stands a bit taller as you carve through turns, and the off-road tires aren't built to grip like mad. Still, a reassuring competence shines through.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Its 2.4-liter, 180-hp engine is more powerful than its competition, but acceleration is merely average because the nine-speed transmission is programmed to seek higher gears sooner than drivers might prefer. Braking is reassuring and handling is nimble, and it's uniquely capable in the dirt.
title: Handling

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Renegade
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: Nine-speed automatic quickly seeks out high gears to save fuel, but then winds up shifting down mutliple gears for even moderate acceleration. Noticably odd behavior that can be frustrating to more aggressive drivers.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Its 2.4-liter, 180-hp engine is more powerful than its competition, but acceleration is merely average because the nine-speed transmission is programmed to seek higher gears sooner than drivers might prefer. Braking is reassuring and handling is nimble, and it's uniquely capable in the dirt.
title: Driveability

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Renegade
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: Trailhawk's 2.4-liter engine can tow 2,000 pounds, a useful amount in such a small vehicle. But unlike its big brother the Jeep Cherokee Trailhawk, four-down towing of a Renegade Trailhawk behind a motorhome is not permitted. Unfortunate.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Its 2.4-liter, 180-hp engine is more powerful than its competition, but acceleration is merely average because the nine-speed transmission is programmed to seek higher gears sooner than drivers might prefer. Braking is reassuring and handling is nimble, and it's uniquely capable in the dirt.
title: Towing

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Renegade
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: Trail-rated Trailhawk has much more clearance underneath, better approach and departure angles and prominent tow hooks. First-gear hold feature and hill descent control enhance crawling capability. Has no peers in the sub-compact SUV world.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Its 2.4-liter, 180-hp engine is more powerful than its competition, but acceleration is merely average because the nine-speed transmission is programmed to seek higher gears sooner than drivers might prefer. Braking is reassuring and handling is nimble, and it's uniquely capable in the dirt.
title: Off-Road

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Renegade
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: Trialhawk leather seats have a good basic shape, offer abundant power adjustments and come with effective seat heaters. Surface more taut than cloth seats of a Lattitude, but still conforms nicely. Backseat a bit flat and doesn't recline.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: The Trailhawk treatment results in a Renegade that doesn't quite match the Lattitude for suppleness and polish, but it's not what we'd call unpleasant. To the surprise of no one, the off-road bits result in a more nervous ride and a higher level of background noise from the tires.
title: Seating Comfort

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Renegade
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: Trailhawk's raised suspension and more agressive tires make it feel up on tiptoes. Swallows large bumps effectively, but there's some jostling over the small stuff. None of this feels out of place considering the Trailhawk mission statement.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: The Trailhawk treatment results in a Renegade that doesn't quite match the Lattitude for suppleness and polish, but it's not what we'd call unpleasant. To the surprise of no one, the off-road bits result in a more nervous ride and a higher level of background noise from the tires.
title: Ride Comfort

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Renegade
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: Not the car for those that prefer silence. The engine tends to growl, there are resonant vibrations here and there, the Trailhawk tires emit extra thrum and it has the wind noise you'd expect from a brick-shaped vehicle with big mirrors.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: The Trailhawk treatment results in a Renegade that doesn't quite match the Lattitude for suppleness and polish, but it's not what we'd call unpleasant. To the surprise of no one, the off-road bits result in a more nervous ride and a higher level of background noise from the tires.
title: Quietness

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Renegade
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: Touchscreen is a smaller version of the same superior interface found in pricier Jeeps. It's easy to figure out and use, and nicely juts out, making it easy to reach. The climate controls are also big, simple and easy to reach.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: It doesn't take much to fill up the tiny cargo area if four will ride together, but things open up considerably with the backseat folded. Aside from this one shortcoming, this a very useful interior, with logical controls, plently of people space and good access through all four doors.
title: Ergonomics

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Renegade
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: Not-too-high, not-too-low seat height should be spot-on for those who struggle to get in and out of cars. Rear doors are narrow, but squared off, limiting the chances of clonking your head. They also open to nearly 90 degrees.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: It doesn't take much to fill up the tiny cargo area if four will ride together, but things open up considerably with the backseat folded. Aside from this one shortcoming, this a very useful interior, with logical controls, plently of people space and good access through all four doors.
title: Ingress/Egress

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Renegade
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: Headroom is excellent, and generous seat adjustment enables superior front legroom. Backseat legroom is largely dependent on front seat position, which is typical for the segment. Tall parents might struggle to fit a rear-facing child seat.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: It doesn't take much to fill up the tiny cargo area if four will ride together, but things open up considerably with the backseat folded. Aside from this one shortcoming, this a very useful interior, with logical controls, plently of people space and good access through all four doors.
title: Space/Room

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Renegade
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: Upright windshield results in broad view ahead, but some odd forward blind spots. Big mirrors and rearview camera are appreciated as are squarelike dimensions when parking. Lane departure and blind spot warning are optional.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: It doesn't take much to fill up the tiny cargo area if four will ride together, but things open up considerably with the backseat folded. Aside from this one shortcoming, this a very useful interior, with logical controls, plently of people space and good access through all four doors.
title: Visibility

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Renegade
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: Suitably large with backseat folded, but it gets quite tight with backseat in use. Roof-mounted box a must if four will go on a road trip. OK small item storage, including armest bin, forward uncovered smartphone bin, big grippy cupholders.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: It doesn't take much to fill up the tiny cargo area if four will ride together, but things open up considerably with the backseat folded. Aside from this one shortcoming, this a very useful interior, with logical controls, plently of people space and good access through all four doors.
title: Cargo/Storage

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Renegade
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: Renegade interior trim upgrades and exterior styling details make it feel nicer than other versions of the Renegade, but then it costs more, too. Call it a wash. Basic interior plastics and switchgear feel about right for the price.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The Renegade Trailhawk value equation comes down to 4x4 potential. If that's what you're after, it's a good deal that has no peers -- even if fuel economy is lackluster. Less-expensive competition with better mpg is easy to find if you don't need the Trailhawk's unique capbilities.
title: Build Quality (vs. $)

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Renegade
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: Rearview camera, Selec-Terrain dial, satellite radio, Bluetooth phone/audio come standard as well as all of the Trailhawk gear. Options include climate control, power leather seats, navigation, heated seats and wheel, blind spot warning.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The Renegade Trailhawk value equation comes down to 4x4 potential. If that's what you're after, it's a good deal that has no peers -- even if fuel economy is lackluster. Less-expensive competition with better mpg is easy to find if you don't need the Trailhawk's unique capbilities.
title: Features(vs. $)

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Renegade
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: A Trailhawk starts at $26,990, and our fairly loaded example with options cost $31,465. Loaded examples of small crossovers without off-road potential include the Honda HR-V ($26,720 EX-L Navi AWD) and Mazda CX-3 ($27,760 Grand Touring AWD).
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The Renegade Trailhawk value equation comes down to 4x4 potential. If that's what you're after, it's a good deal that has no peers -- even if fuel economy is lackluster. Less-expensive competition with better mpg is easy to find if you don't need the Trailhawk's unique capbilities.
title: Cost

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Renegade
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: A Renegade Trailhawk is rated at 24 mpg combined (21 city/29 highway) like other Renegade 4x4s with the 2.4-liter engine. We saw 25.8 mpg on the Edmunds evaluation loop but are currently averaging 20.2 mpg after 5,412 mostly-urban miles.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The Renegade Trailhawk value equation comes down to 4x4 potential. If that's what you're after, it's a good deal that has no peers -- even if fuel economy is lackluster. Less-expensive competition with better mpg is easy to find if you don't need the Trailhawk's unique capbilities.
title: MPG

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Renegade
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: The basic warranty is a fairly basic 3 years/36,000 miles (the Fiat 500X offers an extra year), but the powertrain is covered for 5 years/100,000 miles, which is welcome given Jeep's spotty reliability reputation.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The Renegade Trailhawk value equation comes down to 4x4 potential. If that's what you're after, it's a good deal that has no peers -- even if fuel economy is lackluster. Less-expensive competition with better mpg is easy to find if you don't need the Trailhawk's unique capbilities.
title: Warranty

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Renegade
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: Roadside assistance is provided for a rather lengthy 5 years/100,000 miles. There is no free scheduled maintenance program, but that's not unusual at this price point.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The Renegade Trailhawk value equation comes down to 4x4 potential. If that's what you're after, it's a good deal that has no peers -- even if fuel economy is lackluster. Less-expensive competition with better mpg is easy to find if you don't need the Trailhawk's unique capbilities.
title: Ownership

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Renegade
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: It's no Wrangler, but the Renegade Trailhawk delivers a Jeep experience to sub-compact crossover customers that they won't find it elsewhere in the segment. The flip-side of its off-road chops is a busier ride than its more pavement-bound peers.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: There's a kind of fun available here that comes from nimble on-road handling, smile-inducing styling and a decent amount of off-road competence that'll allow you to venture places you couldn't take a car or mainstream crossover SUV. Trailhawk-ness is indeed more than just a badge.
title: Driving Experience

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Renegade
style.name: Trailhawk 4dr SUV 4WD (2.4L 4cyl 9A)
summary: The sporty Renegade Trailhawk looks different enough to generate comments ranging from "cute" to "cool," which seems about right for a diminutive Jeep with off-road detailing and equipment that's more than just an appearance package.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: There's a kind of fun available here that comes from nimble on-road handling, smile-inducing styling and a decent amount of off-road competence that'll allow you to venture places you couldn't take a car or mainstream crossover SUV. Trailhawk-ness is indeed more than just a badge.
title: Personality

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Wrangler
style.name: Sport 2dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 6M)
summary: Acceleration from 0-to-60 mph took 6.9 seconds, which translates to plenty of guts to merge onto the freeway without fear. The 3.6-liter V6 builds revs slowly but deliberately on account of the inertial mass of those big tires.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: This is a tricky one. The Jeep is optimized for off-road performance. Highway civility is secondary, so it's a below-average performer on the pavement. But when the road ends there is no other production SUV that can keep up. And somehow its weaknesses are part of its charm.
title: Acceleration

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Wrangler
style.name: Sport 2dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 6M)
summary: Pedal stroke is long, progressive and excellent for low-speed maneuvers off-road. Ours needed 133 feet to stop from 60 mph because of the open-lug tread design of the off-road tires. That's actually about average for a pickup or SUV.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: This is a tricky one. The Jeep is optimized for off-road performance. Highway civility is secondary, so it's a below-average performer on the pavement. But when the road ends there is no other production SUV that can keep up. And somehow its weaknesses are part of its charm.
title: Braking

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Wrangler
style.name: Sport 2dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 6M)
summary: Steering is direct but requires attention because the short-wheelbase two-door moves around and requires slight but frequent adjustments. Four-door should feel far more relaxed. A slow ratio makes for busy hands on tight mountain roads.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: This is a tricky one. The Jeep is optimized for off-road performance. Highway civility is secondary, so it's a below-average performer on the pavement. But when the road ends there is no other production SUV that can keep up. And somehow its weaknesses are part of its charm.
title: Steering

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Wrangler
style.name: Sport 2dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 6M)
summary: Off-road tires offer little lateral grip and its soft suspension makes for lots of body roll. On the street, where it will spend the most time, this Jeep is no balerina. In the unpaved expanses, the tires and suspension work wonders.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: This is a tricky one. The Jeep is optimized for off-road performance. Highway civility is secondary, so it's a below-average performer on the pavement. But when the road ends there is no other production SUV that can keep up. And somehow its weaknesses are part of its charm.
title: Handling

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Wrangler
style.name: Sport 2dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 6M)
summary: The six-speed manaul's gear lever is long and tends to buzz and shake on rough roads, and the throw of the clutch pedal is long. It's fairly easy to shift, but this is probably not the vehicle to use to teach someone how to drive stick.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: This is a tricky one. The Jeep is optimized for off-road performance. Highway civility is secondary, so it's a below-average performer on the pavement. But when the road ends there is no other production SUV that can keep up. And somehow its weaknesses are part of its charm.
title: Driveability

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Wrangler
style.name: Sport 2dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 6M)
summary: Wrangler is one of the most capable stock vehicles available. The Willys version is a Sport trim with upgrades: 3.73 axles, limited-slip rear diff, rock rails and suspension upgrades. It's a half step between Sport and Rubicon.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: This is a tricky one. The Jeep is optimized for off-road performance. Highway civility is secondary, so it's a below-average performer on the pavement. But when the road ends there is no other production SUV that can keep up. And somehow its weaknesses are part of its charm.
title: Off-Road

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Wrangler
style.name: Sport 2dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 6M)
summary: Three hours in the saddle was enough to leave an undesirable impression on our buns and backs. These base cloth seats would benefit from additional lumbar support. Tiny backseat accommodates children and adults you don't like.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: Let's face it: comfort is not what the Wrangler is all about. It's OK compared to a truck, and it's more refined than the previous generation Wrangler. But compared to most other SUVs it is louder, rides busier, has a smaller interior and has less comfortable seats.
title: Seating Comfort

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Wrangler
style.name: Sport 2dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 6M)
summary: A realively soft suspension does not always equate to a soft ride. The Wrangler's solid-axle front and rear suspension is great off-road, but it can be busy and bouncy on the pavement. Surprisingly good at absrobing harsh impacts, though.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: Let's face it: comfort is not what the Wrangler is all about. It's OK compared to a truck, and it's more refined than the previous generation Wrangler. But compared to most other SUVs it is louder, rides busier, has a smaller interior and has less comfortable seats.
title: Ride Comfort

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Wrangler
style.name: Sport 2dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 6M)
summary: This soft-top Wrangler is quieter than any before it, which doesn't say much. Noise is ever-present, be it from tires, wind or fellow motorists. Both radio and conversation require high volume. Get the optional hard top if this bothers you.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: Let's face it: comfort is not what the Wrangler is all about. It's OK compared to a truck, and it's more refined than the previous generation Wrangler. But compared to most other SUVs it is louder, rides busier, has a smaller interior and has less comfortable seats.
title: Quietness

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Wrangler
style.name: Sport 2dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 6M)
summary: Small cabins are an ergonomic slam-dunk. Here everything is easy to reach, and the controls are simple to work. Instrumentation has all the information you need and nothing you don't. This is a straightforward machine with few surprises.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: A small cabin puts all controls comfortably within reach of the driver. But these proportions are also a disadvantage. Footwell space and hip room are limited. The tall stance hampers accessibility. Lockable storage with the top down is minimal. But visibility is generally excellent.
title: Ergonomics

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Wrangler
style.name: Sport 2dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 6M)
summary: Two feet of step-in height will have six-footers standing on tiptoes to climb inside. The doors are lightweight and open wide, but the roll bar hampers backseat access. Thick door seals require a door slam when the top is zipped up tight.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: A small cabin puts all controls comfortably within reach of the driver. But these proportions are also a disadvantage. Footwell space and hip room are limited. The tall stance hampers accessibility. Lockable storage with the top down is minimal. But visibility is generally excellent.
title: Ingress/Egress

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Wrangler
style.name: Sport 2dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 6M)
summary: There's plenty of space for people of all shapes and sizes up front, but it's an upright seating position with little surplus footwell room for tall folk to stretch their legs. The kids will love the rear bench, but no one else will.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: A small cabin puts all controls comfortably within reach of the driver. But these proportions are also a disadvantage. Footwell space and hip room are limited. The tall stance hampers accessibility. Lockable storage with the top down is minimal. But visibility is generally excellent.
title: Space/Room

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Wrangler
style.name: Sport 2dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 6M)
summary: High seating position and small proportions make for a good view, even though the roll bar and spare tire are in the way a bit. Expansive view with the top down, or you can keep the top up for shade and zip off the rear and side windows.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: A small cabin puts all controls comfortably within reach of the driver. But these proportions are also a disadvantage. Footwell space and hip room are limited. The tall stance hampers accessibility. Lockable storage with the top down is minimal. But visibility is generally excellent.
title: Visibility

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Wrangler
style.name: Sport 2dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 6M)
summary: Interior storage includes a small, lockable center console. Even smaller is the glove box, which struggles to contain the owner's manual. There are 12.8 cubic feet of storage behind the second row, and the rear seat comes out.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: A small cabin puts all controls comfortably within reach of the driver. But these proportions are also a disadvantage. Footwell space and hip room are limited. The tall stance hampers accessibility. Lockable storage with the top down is minimal. But visibility is generally excellent.
title: Cargo/Storage

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Wrangler
style.name: Sport 2dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 6M)
summary: Working alone and with practice it takes several minutes, not seconds, to raise or lower the soft top. Folded top mucks up the cargo area some, too. Windows must be stored elsewhere, and the plastic will get cloudy and scratched over time.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: A small cabin puts all controls comfortably within reach of the driver. But these proportions are also a disadvantage. Footwell space and hip room are limited. The tall stance hampers accessibility. Lockable storage with the top down is minimal. But visibility is generally excellent.
title: Convertible Top

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Wrangler
style.name: Sport 2dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 6M)
summary: Our test vehicle exhibited no detectable build quality issues of note. Panel gaps and paint quality were up to snuff. It's hard to call out any squeaks or rattles as build quality issues, as the Wrangler is generally noisy on a good day.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Long list of stand-alone options a plus, but the Willy's package alone gets you a nicely-equipped Jeep. Roadside assistance is a nice touch and the powertrain warranty is fantastic. Jeeps typically hold their value well when it's time to sell, and the Willys may have extra appeal.

ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: This is a tricky one. The Jeep is optimized for off-road performance. Highway civility is secondary, so it's a below-average performer on the pavement. But when the road ends there is no other production SUV that can keep up. And somehow its weaknesses are part of its charm.
title: Acceleration

style.name: Sport 2dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 6M)
summary: Pedal stroke is long, progressive and excellent for low-speed maneuvers off-road. Ours needed 133 feet to stop from 60 mph because of the open-lug tread design of the off-road tires. That's actually about average for a pickup or SUV.
ratings.title: Performance

ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: A compact cabin puts all controls comfortably within reach of the driver. But these proportions are also a disadvantage. Footwell space and hiproom are limited. The tall stance hampers accessibility. Lockable storage with the top down is minimal. But visibility is generally excellent.
title: Roominess

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Wrangler
style.name: Unlimited 75th Anniversary 4dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 6M)
summary: High seating position, a boxy greenhouse, and large windows make for a good 360-degree visibility, even though the roll bar and spare tire are in the way a bit. You can roll the top down or keep the top up for shade and zip off the rear and side windows.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: A compact cabin puts all controls comfortably within reach of the driver. But these proportions are also a disadvantage. Footwell space and hiproom are limited. The tall stance hampers accessibility. Lockable storage with the top down is minimal. But visibility is generally excellent.
title: Visibility

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Wrangler
style.name: Unlimited 75th Anniversary 4dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 6M)
summary: Working alone and with practice, it takes several minutes, not seconds, to raise or lower the soft top. The folded top mucks up the cargo area some, too. Windows must be stored elsewhere, and the plastic will get cloudy and scratched over time.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: A compact cabin puts all controls comfortably within reach of the driver. But these proportions are also a disadvantage. Footwell space and hiproom are limited. The tall stance hampers accessibility. Lockable storage with the top down is minimal. But visibility is generally excellent.
title: Convertible Top

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Wrangler
style.name: Unlimited 75th Anniversary 4dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 6M)
summary: The nine-speaker premium Alpine audio system produces great sound, but the navigation interface looks as if it's more than a decade old. It's more likely to be useful to find your general location off-road than it ever will be navigating city streets.
ratings.title: Technology
ratings.summary: There's nothing technologically advanced in the Wrangler as far as electronics are concerned. The infotainment system is about as basic as it gets, and the USB phone connection was often spotty. No driving aids, such as blind-spot monitoring or even a rearview camera, are offered.
title: Audio & Navigation

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Wrangler
style.name: Unlimited 75th Anniversary 4dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 6M)
summary: The Bluetooth phone connection works as it should and streams music in addition to placing calls. We experienced frequent issues with the USB connection not working or playing back correctly. It feels like a last-generation system because it is.
ratings.title: Technology
ratings.summary: There's nothing technologically advanced in the Wrangler as far as electronics are concerned. The infotainment system is about as basic as it gets, and the USB phone connection was often spotty. No driving aids, such as blind-spot monitoring or even a rearview camera, are offered.
title: Device Integration

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Wrangler
style.name: Unlimited 75th Anniversary 4dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 6M)
summary: Voice control executes commands with respect to phone and radio selection, but there's no navigation function. Bluetooth pairing through voice prompts works well and can be done on the move.
ratings.title: Technology
ratings.summary: There's nothing technologically advanced in the Wrangler as far as electronics are concerned. The infotainment system is about as basic as it gets, and the USB phone connection was often spotty. No driving aids, such as blind-spot monitoring or even a rearview camera, are offered.
title: Voice Controls

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Wrangler
style.name: Unlimited 75th Anniversary 4dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 6M)
summary: You'll find 12.8 (two-door) or 31.5 (four-door) cubic feet of storage behind the second row, and the rear seat either comes out (two-door) or folds forward while spring-loaded headrests cleverly retract. The SUVs that line up best with the Wrangler offer more space.
ratings.title: Utility
ratings.summary: Stuck between the compact and midsize SUV segments, the Wrangler is a hard vehicle to place. Since its closest off-road competition sits a class size up, the Wrangler falls a tad behind in the utility category. A lack of cargo space and towing capacity are the main shortfalls.
title: Cargo Space

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Wrangler
style.name: Unlimited 75th Anniversary 4dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 6M)
summary: Not a ton of storage options; there's a small, lockable center console. Even smaller is the glove box, which struggles to contain the owner's manual. A couple cupholders up front and in back and elastic webbing for door pockets round it out.
ratings.title: Utility
ratings.summary: Stuck between the compact and midsize SUV segments, the Wrangler is a hard vehicle to place. Since its closest off-road competition sits a class size up, the Wrangler falls a tad behind in the utility category. A lack of cargo space and towing capacity are the main shortfalls.
title: Small Item Storage

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Wrangler
style.name: Unlimited 75th Anniversary 4dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 6M)
summary: Two pair of LATCH anchors, two overhead tethers. Anchors on the right, behind the front passenger, are a little hard to access, buried between the seat bottom and backrest. The driver's side is more exposed and easier to get to.
ratings.title: Utility
ratings.summary: Stuck between the compact and midsize SUV segments, the Wrangler is a hard vehicle to place. Since its closest off-road competition sits a class size up, the Wrangler falls a tad behind in the utility category. A lack of cargo space and towing capacity are the main shortfalls.
title: Car Seat Accommodation

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Wrangler
style.name: Unlimited 75th Anniversary 4dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 6M)
summary: With a maximum tow capacity of 3,500 pounds, the Wrangler isn't designed for pulling heavy loads. Slightly larger but less off-road-capable competitors will offer higher limits.
ratings.title: Utility
ratings.summary: Stuck between the compact and midsize SUV segments, the Wrangler is a hard vehicle to place. Since its closest off-road competition sits a class size up, the Wrangler falls a tad behind in the utility category. A lack of cargo space and towing capacity are the main shortfalls.
title: Towing

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Wrangler
style.name: Unlimited 75th Anniversary 4dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 6M)
summary: Our test vehicles exhibited no detectable build quality issues of note. Panel gaps and paint quality were up to snuff. It's hard to call out any squeaks or rattles as build quality issues because the Wrangler is generally noisy on a good day.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: There are a ton of trims that range from $24K to $42K and a long list of stand-alone options, which provides good flexibility. Roadside assistance is a nice touch, the powertrain warranty is fantastic, and Jeep Wranglers typically hold their value well when it's time to sell.
title: Build Quality

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Wrangler
style.name: Unlimited 75th Anniversary 4dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 6M)
summary: The interior may feel basic because the bulk of the cost is in the hardware. A Willys Wheeler is $4,000 less than a similarly optioned Rubicon, and a good deal for those who want the look and a good level of performance but don't need specialized off-road hardware.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: There are a ton of trims that range from $24K to $42K and a long list of stand-alone options, which provides good flexibility. Roadside assistance is a nice touch, the powertrain warranty is fantastic, and Jeep Wranglers typically hold their value well when it's time to sell.
title: Cost

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Wrangler
style.name: Unlimited 75th Anniversary 4dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 6M)
summary: The EPA estimate for the six-speed Wrangler is 18 mpg combined (17 city/21 highway) and 1 fewer highway mpg with the five-speed auto. We averaged 16.9 mpg after roughly 500 miles of mixed driving, and this included a 21.5-mpg lap of our 118-mile Edmunds ratings route.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: There are a ton of trims that range from $24K to $42K and a long list of stand-alone options, which provides good flexibility. Roadside assistance is a nice touch, the powertrain warranty is fantastic, and Jeep Wranglers typically hold their value well when it's time to sell.
title: MPG

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Wrangler
style.name: Unlimited 75th Anniversary 4dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 6M)
summary: The 3-year/36,000-mile basic warranty isn't anything to write home about, but the 5-year/100,000-mile powertrain warranty is pretty outstanding.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: There are a ton of trims that range from $24K to $42K and a long list of stand-alone options, which provides good flexibility. Roadside assistance is a nice touch, the powertrain warranty is fantastic, and Jeep Wranglers typically hold their value well when it's time to sell.
title: Warranty

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Wrangler
style.name: Unlimited 75th Anniversary 4dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 6M)
summary: You get 5-year/100,000-mile roadside assistance coverage, which is pretty sweet. And when you sell it (if you sell it), the resale value tends to be strong because there's always someone looking for a used Wrangler.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: There are a ton of trims that range from $24K to $42K and a long list of stand-alone options, which provides good flexibility. Roadside assistance is a nice touch, the powertrain warranty is fantastic, and Jeep Wranglers typically hold their value well when it's time to sell.
title: Ownership

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Wrangler
style.name: Unlimited 75th Anniversary 4dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 6M)
summary: Remove the top and toss in the gear, the friends and head to that favorite getaway. Beach, lake, river or mountains, it doesn't matter. The Wrangler will get you there ... anywhere.
ratings.title: Wild Card
ratings.summary: The Wrangler is a unique machine that can get into difficult places and challenge the driver like no other vehicle can. It's also a unique convertible with oodles of personality that's just as fun to drive on paved roads around town. And what other car has doors that come off?
title: Fun-to-Drive

make.name: Jeep
model.name: Wrangler
style.name: Unlimited 75th Anniversary 4dr SUV 4WD (3.6L 6cyl 6M)
summary: Personality is something the Wrangler has in abundance. Itâ€™s a sun-loving convertible that doesn't care what terrain you throw at it. And, you know that cool, members-only wave the motorcycle riders have? Wrangler owners have one, too. Can you say icon?
ratings.title: Wild Card
ratings.summary: The Wrangler is a unique machine that can get into difficult places and challenge the driver like no other vehicle can. It's also a unique convertible with oodles of personality that's just as fun to drive on paved roads around town. And what other car has doors that come off?
title: Personality

make.name: Kia
model.name: Optima
style.name: EX Hybrid 4dr Sedan (2.4L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid 6A)
summary: At barely under 9 seconds to 60 mph, our Optima Hybrid EX is just off the pace of the quickest hybrid sedans. Unlike some others, battery charge affects acceleration greatly.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: In each performance category, the Optima Hybrid falls short of the competition. Some of these mediocre feats are due to a lack of cutting-edge engineering, while others are simply tuning choices.
title: Acceleration

make.name: Kia
model.name: Optima
style.name: EX Hybrid 4dr Sedan (2.4L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid 6A)
summary: Due to electricity-generating braking systems, nearly all hybrids' brakes require some acclimation. But several competitors provide a more natural feel than this Optima.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: In each performance category, the Optima Hybrid falls short of the competition. Some of these mediocre feats are due to a lack of cutting-edge engineering, while others are simply tuning choices.
title: Braking

make.name: Kia
model.name: Optima
style.name: EX Hybrid 4dr Sedan (2.4L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid 6A)
summary: Electric-assist steering is an unavoidable hybrid reality, and again, other carmakers have better, more realistic feedback. Precision and response, however, are quite good.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: In each performance category, the Optima Hybrid falls short of the competition. Some of these mediocre feats are due to a lack of cutting-edge engineering, while others are simply tuning choices.
title: Steering

make.name: Kia
model.name: Optima
style.name: EX Hybrid 4dr Sedan (2.4L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid 6A)
summary: All-season low rolling-resistance tires aren't meant to provide thrilling handling, and they don't. A quick-reacting and effective stability control system quells any skidding.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: In each performance category, the Optima Hybrid falls short of the competition. Some of these mediocre feats are due to a lack of cutting-edge engineering, while others are simply tuning choices.
title: Handling

make.name: Kia
model.name: Optima
style.name: EX Hybrid 4dr Sedan (2.4L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid 6A)
summary: Given this traditional 6-speed automatic with discreet gears, acceleration and passing feel normal. But steering and braking remain undesirably evident for their unorthodox feel.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: In each performance category, the Optima Hybrid falls short of the competition. Some of these mediocre feats are due to a lack of cutting-edge engineering, while others are simply tuning choices.
title: Driveability

make.name: Kia
model.name: Optima
style.name: EX Hybrid 4dr Sedan (2.4L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid 6A)
summary: The EX trim has standard heated leather front and rear seats. Driver and front passenger enjoy ventilated seats, too. Decent legroom aids comfort on long trips.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: With its enviable list of standard comfort and convenience features, the Kia Optima Hybrid EX is better than average. Dynamically, it is competitive in terms of ride and quietness.
title: Seating Comfort

make.name: Kia
model.name: Optima
style.name: EX Hybrid 4dr Sedan (2.4L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid 6A)
summary: We've grown accustomed to the brittle ride many hybrids exhibit. But that doesn't mean we like it. To that extent, the Optima Hybrid's ride is of average plushness for the class.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: With its enviable list of standard comfort and convenience features, the Kia Optima Hybrid EX is better than average. Dynamically, it is competitive in terms of ride and quietness.
title: Ride Comfort

make.name: Kia
model.name: Optima
style.name: EX Hybrid 4dr Sedan (2.4L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid 6A)
summary: Many hybrids are loud and some sound plain awful under full acceleration. The Optima Hybrid is neither, and is reasonably hushed at freeway cruising speeds, too.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: With its enviable list of standard comfort and convenience features, the Kia Optima Hybrid EX is better than average. Dynamically, it is competitive in terms of ride and quietness.

model.name: Optima
style.name: EX Hybrid 4dr Sedan (2.4L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid 6A)
summary: All the ergonomics one could ask for: keyless entry/ignition, dual-zone climate control, touchscreen/voice-controlled infotainment, Bluetooth and iPod connectivity. User-friendly.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: The Optima Hybrid EX shines when it comes to its interior, where a modern yet user-friendly design combines with generous accommodations.

model.name: Optima

summary: We found the Optima slightly easier to get in and out of than most hybrids in its class.

ratings.summary: The Optima Hybrid EX shines when it comes to its interior, where a modern yet user-friendly design combines with generous accommodations.

summary: While not the largest in the segment, the Optima gives ample room and a reasonably airy cabin. The standard sunroof does cut headroom. Legroom is good front and rear.

ratings.summary: The Optima Hybrid EX shines when it comes to its interior, where a modern yet user-friendly design combines with generous accommodations.

ratings.summary: The Optima Hybrid EX shines when it comes to its interior, where a modern yet user-friendly design combines with generous accommodations.

summary: Since its trunk drops from the standard Optima's 15.4 cubic-feet to just 10.8, the EX Hybrid's cargo volume is more the size of a compact sedan than a midsize.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: The Optima Hybrid EX shines when it comes to its interior, where a modern yet user-friendly design combines with generous accommodations.

summary: The Kia Optima is a well-built machine that can go nearly head-to-head with any midsize hybrid or economy sedan in terms of quality.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Value was once Kia's trump card, but price increases have diminished a key selling point for this Korean manufacturer. Base models are still competitively priced, but models such as this upper trim level EX now face stiff competition.

summary: The Kia Optima Hybrid EX is not a sport sedan, nor is it a completely lifeless economy pod. You could do worse in terms of driver involvement and it's a pleasant daily driver.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: With this conversion to hybrid duty, the Optima loses some of its dynamic appeal. But it makes up for it with sharp styling and feature-rich value. And it's more fun to drive than several key rivals.

summary: The Optima model range begins at about $21K, but can easily climb to over $30K. If you want the best engine, interior, handling, etc., expect to pay for it.
