ratings.summary: Value was once Kia's trump card, but price increases have made this less of an incentive for the Korean manufacturer. Base models are still competitively priced, but upper trim levels like the SX Limited face stiff competition.
title: Cost

make.name: Kia
model.name: Optima
style.name: SX 4dr Sedan (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: The EPA rates the Optima SX at 22 city/34 highway/26 mpg combined, but we struggled to meet these estimates with our test car.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Value was once Kia's trump card, but price increases have made this less of an incentive for the Korean manufacturer. Base models are still competitively priced, but upper trim levels like the SX Limited face stiff competition.
title: MPG

make.name: Kia
model.name: Optima
style.name: SX 4dr Sedan (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: One of the industry's best warranties, period. Kia provides a 5-year/60,000-mile basic warranty and 10-year/100,000-mile powertrain coverage.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Value was once Kia's trump card, but price increases have made this less of an incentive for the Korean manufacturer. Base models are still competitively priced, but upper trim levels like the SX Limited face stiff competition.
title: Warranty

make.name: Kia
model.name: Optima
style.name: SX 4dr Sedan (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: We spent a trouble-free year with a Kia Optima here at Edmunds. It comes with roadside assistance for 5 years/60,000 miles, but no free maintenance.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: Value was once Kia's trump card, but price increases have made this less of an incentive for the Korean manufacturer. Base models are still competitively priced, but upper trim levels like the SX Limited face stiff competition.
title: Ownership

make.name: Kia
model.name: Optima
style.name: SX 4dr Sedan (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: While the Optima is a far cry from the penalty box it once was, the sporty demeanor is only skin deep. It remains a pleasant daily driver regardless.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: Judged by its flashy styling and performance stats, we expected a bit more driving fun than the Optima SX Limited ultimately provided us.
title: Driving Experience

make.name: Kia
model.name: Optima
style.name: SX 4dr Sedan (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 6A)
summary: We appreciate the SX Limited's sporty exterior, and well-equipped and tasteful interior. These help give the car a bit more personality than most others in the class.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: Judged by its flashy styling and performance stats, we expected a bit more driving fun than the Optima SX Limited ultimately provided us.
title: Personality

make.name: Kia
model.name: Rio
style.name: SX 4dr Sedan (1.6L 4cyl 6A)
summary: By the numbers the Rio is above average in its ability to accelerate. It does have abrupt initial throttle tip-in, probably to make it feel sprightlier than it is.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Good acceleration, though the handling and steering could be better. Enthusiasts will look elsewhere for their entry level transportation.
title: Acceleration

model.name: Rio
style.name: SX 4dr Sedan (1.6L 4cyl 6A)
summary: Pedal feel is on the softer side but has a natural bite and progression.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Good acceleration, though the handling and steering could be better. Enthusiasts will look elsewhere for their entry level transportation.
title: Braking

model.name: Rio
style.name: SX 4dr Sedan (1.6L 4cyl 6A)
summary: The steering is quick and somewhat precise, but too numb and too light. Feels artificial at low speeds.

ratings.summary: Good acceleration, though the handling and steering could be better. Enthusiasts will look elsewhere for their entry level transportation.

make.name: Kia
model.name: Rio
style.name: SX 4dr Sedan (1.6L 4cyl 6A)
summary: While the Rio is competent, there's not much for enthusiasts here. Low speed handling exhibits significant yaw delay.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Good acceleration, though the handling and steering could be better. Enthusiasts will look elsewhere for their entry level transportation.

make.name: Kia
model.name: Rio

summary: The Rio's lackluster ride, handling and steering probably won't scare away buyers. Its power delivery is adequate.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Good acceleration, though the handling and steering could be better. Enthusiasts will look elsewhere for their entry level transportation.
title: Driveability

make.name: Kia
model.name: Rio
style.name: SX 4dr Sedan (1.6L 4cyl 6A)
summary: Driver seat feels overstuffed and overinflated, and there is little lateral support. It is shaped to adopt a relaxed, spread-out driving position.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: Ride and refinement isn't as strong as in other cars in its class, but it's still a step up from the previous generation of entry level compact cars. The segment is a moving target, however, and the Rio finds itself one step behind here.
title: Seating Comfort

make.name: Kia
model.name: Rio
style.name: SX 4dr Sedan (1.6L 4cyl 6A)
summary: The Rio has a busy ride, which grows tiresome the longer you are in the car. It feels underdamped and harsh on broken or cracked pavement or seams.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: Ride and refinement isn't as strong as in other cars in its class, but it's still a step up from the previous generation of entry level compact cars. The segment is a moving target, however, and the Rio finds itself one step behind here.
title: Ride Comfort

make.name: Kia
model.name: Rio
style.name: SX 4dr Sedan (1.6L 4cyl 6A)
summary: Usually road noise becomes more prominent with vehicle speed, but somehow the Rio exhibits plenty of road noise at any speed. Wind noise is also prominent.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: Ride and refinement isn't as strong as in other cars in its class, but it's still a step up from the previous generation of entry level compact cars. The segment is a moving target, however, and the Rio finds itself one step behind here.

make.name: Kia
model.name: Rio
style.name: SX 4dr Sedan (1.6L 4cyl 6A)
summary: Three-knob climate controls and chunky buttons are easy to use. Generally an easy-to-use cabin, though some will find the multimedia screen a bit fiddly.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Easy to use and easy to live with. The Rio gives the impression of roominess despite its dimensions. Lots of features to boot.
title: Ergonomics

make.name: Kia
model.name: Rio
style.name: SX 4dr Sedan (1.6L 4cyl 6A)
summary: Low threshold, a lightweight door and unintrusive seat make for easy getaways. Though this is a compact car, the roofline is not so low as to be in the way.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Easy to use and easy to live with. The Rio gives the impression of roominess despite its dimensions. Lots of features to boot.

summary: Compact in name only, the Rio manages to feel more spacious and airy than its label suggests.

summary: Large windshield and low cowl affords a good view forward. Small triangle windows at the base of the A-pillars do little to improve the view, but they do allow more light in.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Easy to use and easy to live with. The Rio gives the impression of roominess despite its dimensions. Lots of features to boot.

summary: Appears to be well-screwed together. Hard, dark plastics cover many surfaces, but the lack of distracting brightwork is a relief.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: A lot of features are available, though they could push the Rio's base price to a point where you might consider other vehicles. Kia's strong warranty is as compelling as ever.

summary: The Rio is brimming with useful features like keyless entry and ignition, navigation, iPod hookup, heated seats and an astonishingly clear backup camera.

ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: It's not fun or especially pleasing to drive. That said, it's not a penalty box. The Rio, especially in the SX trim we tested, is more than just basic transportation.

summary: The Rio's looks, features and space are its strong points, not the driving experience.

make.name: Land Rover
model.name: Range Rover Evoque
style.name: Pure 4dr SUV AWD (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 9A)
summary: The addition of a smooth-shifting 9-speed automatic transmission has made the 240-hp turbo 4-cylinder slightly quicker to 60 mph (7.2 sec). Disappointingly, the noticeable lack of power from a stop and surging power remain as flaws.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: With confident steering, handling, braking and uncommon off-road ability, the only real demerit the Evoque earns is related to its lackluster drivetrain. Modest acceleration, surging turbo power delivery and poor transmission logic plague the driveability of an otherwise good performer.
title: Acceleration

make.name: Land Rover
model.name: Range Rover Evoque
style.name: Pure 4dr SUV AWD (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 9A)
summary: The medium-firm brake pedal is easy to predict in traffic and panic situations alike. On stops from 60 mph in our testing, the Evoque and its all-season tires stopped in a segment-average 121 feet with good stability and little nosedive.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: With confident steering, handling, braking and uncommon off-road ability, the only real demerit the Evoque earns is related to its lackluster drivetrain. Modest acceleration, surging turbo power delivery and poor transmission logic plague the driveability of an otherwise good performer.
title: Braking

make.name: Land Rover
model.name: Range Rover Evoque
style.name: Pure 4dr SUV AWD (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 9A)
summary: One of the Evoque's better qualities is its direct and precise steering. It's a pleasure to point the SUV around corners, but those same quick responses can make the Evoque feel a little nervous at speed on a straight highway.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: With confident steering, handling, braking and uncommon off-road ability, the only real demerit the Evoque earns is related to its lackluster drivetrain. Modest acceleration, surging turbo power delivery and poor transmission logic plague the driveability of an otherwise good performer.
title: Steering

make.name: Land Rover
model.name: Range Rover Evoque
style.name: Pure 4dr SUV AWD (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 9A)
summary: Combined with good steering, the Evoque is a surprisingly capable handler, with better grip, agility and composure than most compact SUVs. It's equally happy in steady corners or quick switchbacks. The stability control system is lenient.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: With confident steering, handling, braking and uncommon off-road ability, the only real demerit the Evoque earns is related to its lackluster drivetrain. Modest acceleration, surging turbo power delivery and poor transmission logic plague the driveability of an otherwise good performer.
title: Handling

make.name: Land Rover
model.name: Range Rover Evoque
style.name: Pure 4dr SUV AWD (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 9A)
summary: The new transmission is often caught on its heels in Drive, extra pressure on the gas pedal causing a big pause, a downshift and then surging acceleration. Auto stop/start isn't smooth. Cruise control can't maintain downhill speed.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: With confident steering, handling, braking and uncommon off-road ability, the only real demerit the Evoque earns is related to its lackluster drivetrain. Modest acceleration, surging turbo power delivery and poor transmission logic plague the driveability of an otherwise good performer.
title: Driveability

make.name: Land Rover
model.name: Range Rover Evoque
style.name: Pure 4dr SUV AWD (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 9A)
summary: Up to 3,500 lbs when properly equipped, but this is about average for the segment. The Evoque also has electronic trailer-stability assist and hill-start assist which reduce some towing anxiety.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: With confident steering, handling, braking and uncommon off-road ability, the only real demerit the Evoque earns is related to its lackluster drivetrain. Modest acceleration, surging turbo power delivery and poor transmission logic plague the driveability of an otherwise good performer.
title: Towing

make.name: Land Rover
model.name: Range Rover Evoque
style.name: Pure 4dr SUV AWD (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 9A)
summary: Top of its class off-road, and the Evoque can tackle much rougher terrain than you'd guess. Smart, selectable Terrain Response modes (mud/snow/sand), hill-descent program and specialized hardware maintain Range Rover standards.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: With confident steering, handling, braking and uncommon off-road ability, the only real demerit the Evoque earns is related to its lackluster drivetrain. Modest acceleration, surging turbo power delivery and poor transmission logic plague the driveability of an otherwise good performer.
title: Off-Road

make.name: Land Rover
model.name: Range Rover Evoque
style.name: Pure 4dr SUV AWD (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 9A)
summary: Front seats have narrow bottoms and won't fit some, but offer above average support and comfort. Rear seats are similarly firm, narrow and supportive. Standard: dual-zone climate w/rear vents. Optional: heated leather front/rear seats.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: If you're the right size, the firm seats will offer good support and comfort. Dual-zone automatic climate control with rear vents and opt. heated front/rear seats are appreciated. Ride is sporty and well managed, but the engine noise during hard acceleration is noticeable.
title: Seating Comfort

make.name: Land Rover
model.name: Range Rover Evoque
style.name: Pure 4dr SUV AWD (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 9A)
summary: The Evoque's standard, non-adjustable sport suspension offers a firm but only occasionally busy ride. As such, it adeptly walks that fine line between composed and sporty, dare we say BMW-like. Optional: adaptive dampers.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: If you're the right size, the firm seats will offer good support and comfort. Dual-zone automatic climate control with rear vents and opt. heated front/rear seats are appreciated. Ride is sporty and well managed, but the engine noise during hard acceleration is noticeable.
title: Ride Comfort

make.name: Land Rover
model.name: Range Rover Evoque
style.name: Pure 4dr SUV AWD (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 9A)
summary: Good isolation from wind and road noise, but the rather raspy four-cylinder engine note is evident during acceleration, and not in a way we like.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: If you're the right size, the firm seats will offer good support and comfort. Dual-zone automatic climate control with rear vents and opt. heated front/rear seats are appreciated. Ride is sporty and well managed, but the engine noise during hard acceleration is noticeable.
title: Quietness

make.name: Land Rover
model.name: Range Rover Evoque
style.name: Pure 4dr SUV AWD (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 9A)
summary: Only a couple years in, and the Evoque's infotainment system looks/feels/performs aged. Slow/unresponsive touchscreen requires too many attempts. Otherwise, rotary gear selector and suitably large, well-labeled buttons and switches abound.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Despite its compact dimensions, the Evoque offers generous space for passengers, yet it lacks the cargo capacity of its competitors. It also has limited small-item storage. Outward vision is challenging, but a standard rearview camera and parking sensors help mitigate that liability.
title: Ergonomics

make.name: Land Rover
model.name: Range Rover Evoque
style.name: Pure 4dr SUV AWD (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 9A)
summary: A low seating position for an SUV makes access easy up front. Unlike the two-door Coupe version of the Evoque, access to the four-door's similarly low rear seat is a snap, possibly explaining the lack of roof-mounted grab handles.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Despite its compact dimensions, the Evoque offers generous space for passengers, yet it lacks the cargo capacity of its competitors. It also has limited small-item storage. Outward vision is challenging, but a standard rearview camera and parking sensors help mitigate that liability.
title: Ingress/Egress

make.name: Land Rover
model.name: Range Rover Evoque
style.name: Pure 4dr SUV AWD (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 9A)
summary: Despite a low roofline and narrow windows, it doesn't feel claustrophobic. Head, shoulder and legroom are good up front. Lots of rear headroom, only adequate legroom. Fixed, panoramic roof (optional) helps improve perceived open space.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Despite its compact dimensions, the Evoque offers generous space for passengers, yet it lacks the cargo capacity of its competitors. It also has limited small-item storage. Outward vision is challenging, but a standard rearview camera and parking sensors help mitigate that liability.
title: Space/Room

make.name: Land Rover
model.name: Range Rover Evoque
style.name: Pure 4dr SUV AWD (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 9A)
summary: Forget about visibility via the rear window, you'll have to rely on the standard rearview camera and parking sensors. Surround cameras, blind-spot monitoring, adaptive cruise and forward collision warning systems are optional.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Despite its compact dimensions, the Evoque offers generous space for passengers, yet it lacks the cargo capacity of its competitors. It also has limited small-item storage. Outward vision is challenging, but a standard rearview camera and parking sensors help mitigate that liability.
title: Visibility

make.name: Land Rover
model.name: Range Rover Evoque
style.name: Pure 4dr SUV AWD (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 9A)
summary: A compact SUV, the Evoque is merely adequate here: glovebox has a giant door but small volume, diminutive center bin, small door pockets. Cargo space is cramped compared to rivals: 20 to 51 cu-ft with rear seats raised/lowered.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Despite its compact dimensions, the Evoque offers generous space for passengers, yet it lacks the cargo capacity of its competitors. It also has limited small-item storage. Outward vision is challenging, but a standard rearview camera and parking sensors help mitigate that liability.
title: Cargo/Storage

make.name: Land Rover
model.name: Range Rover Evoque
style.name: Pure 4dr SUV AWD (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 9A)
summary: In terms of overall quality, the Evoque delivers solidity and refinement that meet or beat expectations among luxury-branded SUVs in this price range. Attention to materials and fit and finish are obvious. The chic design is unique.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The Evoque's high build quality and competitive features are overshadowed by its comparatively high $41,995 price and mediocre warranty terms. Adding a few options like a cold-weather package, navigation and the Pure Plus pkg raised the price to $48,520, which is a lot for a compact SUV.
title: Build Quality (vs. $)

make.name: Land Rover
model.name: Range Rover Evoque
style.name: Pure 4dr SUV AWD (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 9A)
summary: At $41,995, the Evoque Pure has typical standard features for its price (Bluetooth, touchscreen, dual-zone climate, push-button start, auto headlamps and wipers) plus unexpected ones (multi-mode 4x4, rearview camera, parking sensors).
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The Evoque's high build quality and competitive features are overshadowed by its comparatively high $41,995 price and mediocre warranty terms. Adding a few options like a cold-weather package, navigation and the Pure Plus pkg raised the price to $48,520, which is a lot for a compact SUV.

model.name: Range Rover Evoque
style.name: Pure 4dr SUV AWD (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 9A)
summary: The Evoque's cost is higher than direct competitors from Audi and BMW, but lower than Porsche. Some of this is due to its unique 4x4 capability, the rest is just brand cache. There should be an optional engine upgrade.
ratings.title: Value

Adding a few options like a cold-weather package, navigation and the Pure Plus pkg raised the price to $48,520, which is a lot for a compact SUV.

model.name: Range Rover Evoque

summary: With EPA estimates at 24 mpg Combined (21 City/30 Highway), we achieved an admirable 25 mpg on our varied evaluation loop. These figures are competitive, or slightly better, than its compact, luxury SUV peers with all-wheel drive.

ratings.summary: The Evoque's high build quality and competitive features are overshadowed by its comparatively high $41,995 price and mediocre warranty terms. Adding a few options like a cold-weather package, navigation and the Pure Plus pkg raised the price to $48,520, which is a lot for a compact SUV.

model.name: Range Rover Evoque
style.name: Pure 4dr SUV AWD (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 9A)
summary: Both the basic and drivetrain warranties last for 4 years/50,000 miles, just like competing luxury SUVs. There is also a 6-year/unlimited-miles corrosion warranty. Competitive, but not benchmark.

title: Ownership

make.name: Land Rover
model.name: Range Rover Evoque
style.name: Pure 4dr SUV AWD (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 9A)
summary: Thanks to the sporty feeling behind the wheel, you might never guess the Evoque maintains Range Rover's off-road reputation. You'll experience strong dynamic responses (except from the engine), good manners and a sophisticated ride.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: If you avoid Drive tranny mode and select S, or better yet, use the manual-shift paddles for improved driveline responses, the sportiness built into the Evoque's chassis makes it uncharacteristically thrilling to drive. That it looks so sophisticated and chic adds to its flavor.
title: Driving Experience

make.name: Land Rover
model.name: Range Rover Evoque
style.name: Pure 4dr SUV AWD (2.0L 4cyl Turbo 9A)
summary: There's no denying the Evoque looks unlike any other compact SUV, due to the sleek roof, wide stance and Range Rover heritage cues. It manages to stand out effectively (in a good way), even on the trendy East/West coasts.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: If you avoid Drive tranny mode and select S, or better yet, use the manual-shift paddles for improved driveline responses, the sportiness built into the Evoque's chassis makes it uncharacteristically thrilling to drive. That it looks so sophisticated and chic adds to its flavor.
title: Personality

make.name: Land Rover
model.name: Range Rover Sport
style.name: Supercharged 4dr SUV 4WD w/Prod. End 12/31 (5.0L 8cyl S/C 8A)
summary: The 510-hp supercharged 5.0-liter V8 gets the Sport to 60 mph in 4.6 seconds, rivaling the pricier Porsche Cayenne Turbo. The 8-speed automatic shifts quickly. The diesel needs 7.9 seconds to hit 60 mph and takes some time for power to build.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The Range Rover Sport Supercharged is impressive. It accelerates with purpose and its backroad cornering ability defies logic, although our instrumented handling numbers proved only so-so. The RR Sport is also a superbly capable off-roader. The diesel TD6 is considerably slower and less responsive.
title: Acceleration

make.name: Land Rover
model.name: Range Rover Sport
style.name: Supercharged 4dr SUV 4WD w/Prod. End 12/31 (5.0L 8cyl S/C 8A)
summary: Needing 124 feet to stop from 60 mph, the Range Rover Sport's braking performance is acceptable for the class. The pedal does soften slightly after repeated hard use, though.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The Range Rover Sport Supercharged is impressive. model.name: Range Rover Sport
style.name: Supercharged 4dr SUV 4WD w/Prod. End 12/31 (5.0L 8cyl S/C 8A)
summary: Although it's hard to trust something this big, the RR Sport tackles backroads with the utmost confidence and speed. It's still not as agile as the considerably lighter Porsche Cayenne Turbo.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The Range Rover Sport Supercharged is impressive. It accelerates with purpose and its backroad cornering ability defies logic, although our instrumented handling numbers proved only so-so. The RR Sport is also a superbly capable off-roader. The diesel TD6 is considerably slower and less responsive.
title: Handling

make.name: Land Rover
model.name: Range Rover Sport
style.name: Supercharged 4dr SUV 4WD w/Prod. End 12/31 (5.0L 8cyl S/C 8A)
summary: Easy to drive, even in tight spots. Forward collision warning is too sensitive, but can be shut off and stays off. Auto start/stop and optional adaptive cruise control function perfectly.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The Range Rover Sport Supercharged is impressive. It accelerates with purpose and its backroad cornering ability defies logic, although our instrumented handling numbers proved only so-so. The RR Sport is also a superbly capable off-roader. The diesel TD6 is considerably slower and less responsive.
title: Driveability

make.name: Land Rover
model.name: Range Rover Sport
style.name: Supercharged 4dr SUV 4WD w/Prod. End 12/31 (5.0L 8cyl S/C 8A)
summary: Towing capacity tops out at 7,716 pounds, which is comparable to other luxury SUVs. Trailer stability control is standard.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The Range Rover Sport Supercharged is impressive. It accelerates with purpose and its backroad cornering ability defies logic, although our instrumented handling numbers proved only so-so. The RR Sport is also a superbly capable off-roader. The diesel TD6 is considerably slower and less responsive.
title: Towing

make.name: Land Rover
model.name: Range Rover Sport
style.name: Supercharged 4dr SUV 4WD w/Prod. End 12/31 (5.0L 8cyl S/C 8A)
summary: Tackling steep rocky grades is made effortless thanks to the sophisticated Terrain Response system and two-speed transfer case. But wheel articulation is far better on the non-Sport Range Rover.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The Range Rover Sport Supercharged is impressive. It accelerates with purpose and its backroad cornering ability defies logic, although our instrumented handling numbers proved only so-so. The RR Sport is also a superbly capable off-roader. The diesel TD6 is considerably slower and less responsive.
title: Off-Road

make.name: Land Rover
model.name: Range Rover Sport
style.name: Supercharged 4dr SUV 4WD w/Prod. End 12/31 (5.0L 8cyl S/C 8A)
summary: Optional 16-way adjustable front seats (heating/cooling for all passengers) have ample padding and support, endowing the Range Rover with a comfort level competitive with luxury sedans.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: The Range Rover Sport exemplifies luxurious comfort. Four adults can easily log hundreds of miles and arrive as fresh and unfatigued as when they departed.
title: Seating Comfort

make.name: Land Rover
model.name: Range Rover Sport
style.name: Supercharged 4dr SUV 4WD w/Prod. End 12/31 (5.0L 8cyl S/C 8A)
summary: With Terrain Response set to Auto, the ride is pleasantly cushioned and readily smooths out bumps in the road. Imperfections are felt, but are never intrusive in this mode.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: The Range Rover Sport exemplifies luxurious comfort. Four adults can easily log hundreds of miles and arrive as fresh and unfatigued as when they departed.
title: Ride Comfort

make.name: Land Rover
model.name: Range Rover Sport
style.name: Supercharged 4dr SUV 4WD w/Prod. End 12/31 (5.0L 8cyl S/C 8A)
summary: Wind and road noise are insulated enough to be barely detectable, far better than the Cayenne. Engine growl is really only heard when driving with exhuberance, and even then, it sounds great.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: The Range Rover Sport exemplifies luxurious comfort. Four adults can easily log hundreds of miles and arrive as fresh and unfatigued as when they departed.
title: Quietness

make.name: Land Rover
model.name: Range Rover Sport
style.name: Supercharged 4dr SUV 4WD w/Prod. End 12/31 (5.0L 8cyl S/C 8A)
summary: All controls are within reach and logically placed. The infotainment interface looks a bit outdated and requires digging through menus to perform simple functions.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: A thoroughly modern design, excellent materials and meticulous craftsmanship make the Range Rover Sport's cabin one of the best in the segment. The infotainment interface is slightly behinds the times, but still works acceptably.
title: Ergonomics

make.name: Land Rover
model.name: Range Rover Sport
style.name: Supercharged 4dr SUV 4WD w/Prod. End 12/31 (5.0L 8cyl S/C 8A)
summary: The standard air suspension can be lowered three inches to permit easier loading. Big door openings with few impediments further improve access, but the large doors make tight parking spaces tough.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: A thoroughly modern design, excellent materials and meticulous craftsmanship make the Range Rover Sport's cabin one of the best in the segment. The infotainment interface is slightly behinds the times, but still works acceptably.
title: Ingress/Egress

make.name: Land Rover
model.name: Range Rover Sport
style.name: Supercharged 4dr SUV 4WD w/Prod. End 12/31 (5.0L 8cyl S/C 8A)
summary: There is no shortage of head and legroom up front, or in the rear outboard seats for adults. The rear middle seat is suitable for smaller passengers only.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: A thoroughly modern design, excellent materials and meticulous craftsmanship make the Range Rover Sport's cabin one of the best in the segment. The infotainment interface is slightly behinds the times, but still works acceptably.
title: Space/Room

make.name: Land Rover
model.name: Range Rover Sport
style.name: Supercharged 4dr SUV 4WD w/Prod. End 12/31 (5.0L 8cyl S/C 8A)
summary: Forward visibility is excellent, though the windshield heating elements can distract some drivers. Rear visibility is poor, but the standard rearview camera takes away some guesswork.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: A thoroughly modern design, excellent materials and meticulous craftsmanship make the Range Rover Sport's cabin one of the best in the segment. The infotainment interface is slightly behinds the times, but still works acceptably.

make.name: Land Rover
model.name: Range Rover Sport
style.name: Supercharged 4dr SUV 4WD w/Prod. End 12/31 (5.0L 8cyl S/C 8A)
summary: Interior storage is plentiful and the optional cooler box works well. Cargo capacity behind the rear seats is on par with the Porsche Cayenne at 27.7 cu-ft, as is the maximum of 62.2 cu-ft.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: A thoroughly modern design, excellent materials and meticulous craftsmanship make the Range Rover Sport's cabin one of the best in the segment. The infotainment interface is slightly behinds the times, but still works acceptably.
title: Cargo/Storage

make.name: Land Rover
model.name: Range Rover Sport
style.name: Supercharged 4dr SUV 4WD w/Prod. End 12/31 (5.0L 8cyl S/C 8A)
summary: Interior materials are top-notch and will satisfy discerning tastes. Tight fitment of elements further enhances the experience; even during heavier offroading no creaks or squeaks were heard.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: With a base price around $80,000 and an as-tested price of $94,000, the Range Rover Sport Supercharged is priced well beyond most budgets and gets notably poor fuel economy. The $72,000 TD6 diesel is a bit more accessible, and is far more efficient. Either are more affordable than the Lexus LX 570 or Porsche Cayenne Turbo.
title: Build Quality (vs. $)

make.name: Land Rover
model.name: Range Rover Sport
style.name: Supercharged 4dr SUV 4WD w/Prod. End 12/31 (5.0L 8cyl S/C 8A)
summary: The Sport is equally good off- and on-road and isn't as costly as some of its less versatile rivals. The generous feature content adds to the Sport's appeal.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: With a base price around $80,000 and an as-tested price of $94,000, the Range Rover Sport Supercharged is priced well beyond most budgets and gets notably poor fuel economy. The $72,000 TD6 diesel is a bit more accessible, and is far more efficient. Either are more affordable than the Lexus LX 570 or Porsche Cayenne Turbo.

make.name: Land Rover
model.name: Range Rover Sport
style.name: Supercharged 4dr SUV 4WD w/Prod. End 12/31 (5.0L 8cyl S/C 8A)
summary: Among luxury vehicles, the Land Rover's options either meet or beat competitors in terms of pricing. It's also worth mentioning that the non-diesel V6-powered Sport model starts at only $65,000.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: With a base price around $80,000 and an as-tested price of $94,000, the Range Rover Sport Supercharged is priced well beyond most budgets and gets notably poor fuel economy. The $72,000 TD6 diesel is a bit more accessible, and is far more efficient. Either are more affordable than the Lexus LX 570 or Porsche Cayenne Turbo.
title: Cost

make.name: Land Rover
model.name: Range Rover Sport
style.name: Supercharged 4dr SUV 4WD w/Prod. End 12/31 (5.0L 8cyl S/C 8A)
summary: EPA estimates of 16 mpg combined (14 city/19 hwy) are are average for the class. Our highway-heavy evaluation loop returned 17.2 mpg and we averaged only 12.4 mpg overall. The diesel is estimated at 25 mpg combined (22/29), confirmed by our 24.8-mpg average.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: With a base price around $80,000 and an as-tested price of $94,000, the Range Rover Sport Supercharged is priced well beyond most budgets and gets notably poor fuel economy. The $72,000 TD6 diesel is a bit more accessible, and is far more efficient. Either are more affordable than the Lexus LX 570 or Porsche Cayenne Turbo.
title: MPG

make.name: Land Rover
model.name: Range Rover Sport
style.name: Supercharged 4dr SUV 4WD w/Prod. End 12/31 (5.0L 8cyl S/C 8A)
summary: Land Rover's 4-year/50,000-mile basic and powertrain warranties are similar to other luxury SUVs, although Lexus covers the powertrain for 6 years/70,000 miles.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: With a base price around $80,000 and an as-tested price of $94,000, the Range Rover Sport Supercharged is priced well beyond most budgets and gets notably poor fuel economy. The $72,000 TD6 diesel is a bit more accessible, and is far more efficient. Either are more affordable than the Lexus LX 570 or Porsche Cayenne Turbo.

make.name: Land Rover
model.name: Range Rover Sport
style.name: Supercharged 4dr SUV 4WD w/Prod. End 12/31 (5.0L 8cyl S/C 8A)
summary: Only the first scheduled maintenance is complimentary. Lexus includes the first year and Porsche offers a pre-paid maintenance program. Roadside assistance is covered for 4 years/50,000 miles.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: With a base price around $80,000 and an as-tested price of $94,000, the Range Rover Sport Supercharged is priced well beyond most budgets and gets notably poor fuel economy. The $72,000 TD6 diesel is a bit more accessible, and is far more efficient. Either are more affordable than the Lexus LX 570 or Porsche Cayenne Turbo.
title: Ownership

make.name: Land Rover
model.name: Range Rover Sport
style.name: Supercharged 4dr SUV 4WD w/Prod. End 12/31 (5.0L 8cyl S/C 8A)
summary: The Range Rover Sport feels solid and reassuring in every condition. Its high performance capabilities will impress drivers of any stripe, but it remains well mannered for mundane daily commuting.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: Exceptionally high on-road limits give the Range Rover Sport Supercharged a wildly entertaining spirit. Combine that with its proven ability to conquer the wilderness and there's nothing else quite like it. The diesel TD6 is noticeably less engaging, but that's the price you pay for fuel efficiency.
title: Driving Experience

make.name: Land Rover
model.name: Range Rover Sport
style.name: Supercharged 4dr SUV 4WD w/Prod. End 12/31 (5.0L 8cyl S/C 8A)
summary: "Sporty" and "rugged" define this Range Rover, but so does "luxurious sophistication." It'll be the classiest car in the woods. And perhaps even at the valet stand.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: Exceptionally high on-road limits give the Range Rover Sport Supercharged a wildly entertaining spirit. Combine that with its proven ability to conquer the wilderness and there's nothing else quite like it. The diesel TD6 is noticeably less engaging, but that's the price you pay for fuel efficiency.
title: Personality

make.name: Lexus
model.name: CT 200h
style.name: 4dr Hatchback (1.8L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: Not any faster than a Prius -- it took 10.5 seconds for our CT200h to get up to 60 mph. The power delivery is fine for daily use, as long as you aren't expecting the F-Sport badge to represent extra quickness; there isn't any.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The F-Sport badge doesn't bring any additional acceleration compared to the base CT200h or the Prius; the powertrain is identical with a total output of 134 hp. The CT's low slung chassis and improved suspension do make this a much more stable and engaging handler than a Prius.
title: Acceleration

make.name: Lexus
model.name: CT 200h
style.name: 4dr Hatchback (1.8L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: Brakes do an admirable job of slowing the CT200h in traffic; pedal feel is fairly authentic even when magnetic braking is dominant. So-so panic-stop distance of 125 feet likely stems from fuel-saving low rolling resistance tires.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The F-Sport badge doesn't bring any additional acceleration compared to the base CT200h or the Prius; the powertrain is identical with a total output of 134 hp. The CT's low slung chassis and improved suspension do make this a much more stable and engaging handler than a Prius.
title: Braking

make.name: Lexus
model.name: CT 200h
style.name: 4dr Hatchback (1.8L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: There's a sporty heft to the steering that feels great when cornering, but it's not quite light and delicate enough in the middle when going straight. Minor complaint. Fits the F-Sport image well enough.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The F-Sport badge doesn't bring any additional acceleration compared to the base CT200h or the Prius; the powertrain is identical with a total output of 134 hp. The CT's low slung chassis and improved suspension do make this a much more stable and engaging handler than a Prius.
title: Steering

make.name: Lexus
model.name: CT 200h
style.name: 4dr Hatchback (1.8L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: A lower center of gravity and sophisticated multilink rear suspension make the CT200h feel much more nimble and "planted" than its Prius cousin. The extra weight of the hybrid system is only noticeable in the tightest corners.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The F-Sport badge doesn't bring any additional acceleration compared to the base CT200h or the Prius; the powertrain is identical with a total output of 134 hp. The CT's low slung chassis and improved suspension do make this a much more stable and engaging handler than a Prius.
title: Handling

make.name: Lexus
model.name: CT 200h
style.name: 4dr Hatchback (1.8L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: Smooth and supple because of the seamless no-shift characteristics of the electronic CVT (continuously variable transmission). Throttle pedal sensitivity is adjustable via a rotary knob, allows you to choose from eco/norm/sport.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: The F-Sport badge doesn't bring any additional acceleration compared to the base CT200h or the Prius; the powertrain is identical with a total output of 134 hp. The CT's low slung chassis and improved suspension do make this a much more stable and engaging handler than a Prius.
title: Driveability

make.name: Lexus
model.name: CT 200h
style.name: 4dr Hatchback (1.8L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: Front leather seats offer lots of adjustments and have decent padding, but the lower cushion might feel a bit short and narrow to taller drivers. Backseat padding is soft and comfortably shaped.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: The CT200h imparts a luxury feel in terms of seat comfort and noise suppression. It rides smoothly most of the time, too, especially on overtly rough surfaces. But subtle road imperfections can sneak through and produce a busy ride. The F-Sport package may be the culprit here.
title: Seating Comfort

make.name: Lexus
model.name: CT 200h
style.name: 4dr Hatchback (1.8L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: Pretty smooth ride over rough and broken pavement with little aftertaste. Doesn't float or wallow, either. But it's less composed over small bumps and ripples that tend to produce a busy feel with a side order of head toss.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: The CT200h imparts a luxury feel in terms of seat comfort and noise suppression. It rides smoothly most of the time, too, especially on overtly rough surfaces. But subtle road imperfections can sneak through and produce a busy ride. The F-Sport package may be the culprit here.
title: Ride Comfort

make.name: Lexus
model.name: CT 200h
style.name: 4dr Hatchback (1.8L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: The CT200h is generally quiet, with subdued road and wind noise. At times the engine revs higher than expected due to the hybrid CVT transmission, but there are also silent periods of electric-only operation at low speeds.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: The CT200h imparts a luxury feel in terms of seat comfort and noise suppression. It rides smoothly most of the time, too, especially on overtly rough surfaces. But subtle road imperfections can sneak through and produce a busy ride. The F-Sport package may be the culprit here.
title: Quietness

make.name: Lexus
model.name: CT 200h
style.name: 4dr Hatchback (1.8L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: Good driving position and most controls are self-explanatory and easy to reach and use. But that annoying joystick is a clumsy way to navigate on-screen menus. And we're not fans of the shifter and its separate "Park" button.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: The CT200h experience seems directed toward the lone commuter, though space for passengers is reasonable so long as none are very tall. Driving position and controls are simple and straightforward except for the optional navigation system's clunky joystick setup.
title: Ergonomics

make.name: Lexus
model.name: CT 200h
style.name: 4dr Hatchback (1.8L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: Easy to enter and exit the front through a generous door opening. It's less optimal in back because the doors are smaller and the corner of the battery box is right where your heels want to be when you get in or out.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: The CT200h experience seems directed toward the lone commuter, though space for passengers is reasonable so long as none are very tall. Driving position and controls are simple and straightforward except for the optional navigation system's clunky joystick setup.
title: Ingress/Egress

make.name: Lexus
model.name: CT 200h
style.name: 4dr Hatchback (1.8L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: Tall drivers have plenty of head and leg room, but the passenger seat doesn't offer as much maximum headroom. The backseat won't fit folks over six feet, and a tall driver turns the rear seat behind into a kids-only proposition.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: The CT200h experience seems directed toward the lone commuter, though space for passengers is reasonable so long as none are very tall. Driving position and controls are simple and straightforward except for the optional navigation system's clunky joystick setup.
title: Space/Room

make.name: Lexus
model.name: CT 200h
style.name: 4dr Hatchback (1.8L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: Over-the-hood visibility is pinched by an oddly tall cowl below the windshield. Large outside mirrors attempt to counter prominent rear three-quarter blind spots. Rear window is small, too. You'll want the optional backup camera.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: The CT200h experience seems directed toward the lone commuter, though space for passengers is reasonable so long as none are very tall. Driving position and controls are simple and straightforward except for the optional navigation system's clunky joystick setup.
title: Visibility

make.name: Lexus
model.name: CT 200h
style.name: 4dr Hatchback (1.8L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: Cargo space trails the cavernous Prius, but 14.3 cubic-feet is a typical trunk. Seats fold flat for 30 cu.-ft. Nicely trimmed cargo hold has underfloor nook for storing unused cargo cover. Big front cupholders but small front door pockets.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: The CT200h experience seems directed toward the lone commuter, though space for passengers is reasonable so long as none are very tall. Driving position and controls are simple and straightforward except for the optional navigation system's clunky joystick setup.
title: Cargo/Storage

make.name: Lexus
model.name: CT 200h
style.name: 4dr Hatchback (1.8L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: Excellent inside and out, the CT200h F-Sport displays a higher degree of fit and finish than any Prius. As a Lexus, it's built to an appropriately higher standard in terms of materials, panel gaps and paint quality.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The Lexus CT200h F-Sport is a solidly built hybrid that combines fuel efficiency with a sporty personality. The standard model has most everything you need. But the optional navigation system is appallingly expensive and comes with a questionable joystick control interface.
title: Build Quality (vs. $)

make.name: Lexus
model.name: CT 200h
style.name: 4dr Hatchback (1.8L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: Good news: std sunroof, dual-zone climate control, pushbutton start, 10-way pwr driver seat, telescopic wheel, nice stereo. Bad news: opt navigation system costs $3,490 and real cost is higher because of required partner options.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The Lexus CT200h F-Sport is a solidly built hybrid that combines fuel efficiency with a sporty personality. The standard model has most everything you need. But the optional navigation system is appallingly expensive and comes with a questionable joystick control interface.
title: Features(vs. $)

make.name: Lexus
model.name: CT 200h
style.name: 4dr Hatchback (1.8L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: The CT200h starts at $32,960 with a good amount of standard equipment, but the price quickly jumps is you add options, which tend to have prerequisites. Our F-Sport 200h with Navigation was priced at $40,275.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The Lexus CT200h F-Sport is a solidly built hybrid that combines fuel efficiency with a sporty personality. The standard model has most everything you need. But the optional navigation system is appallingly expensive and comes with a questionable joystick control interface.
title: Cost

make.name: Lexus
model.name: CT 200h
style.name: 4dr Hatchback (1.8L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: The EPA rates the CT200h at 42 mpg Combined (43 City/40 Highway) but we easily beat this on our test loop (47.9 mpg) and when commuting (44.1 mpg). Get frisky with the throttle in Sport mode, however, and you won't get there.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The Lexus CT200h F-Sport is a solidly built hybrid that combines fuel efficiency with a sporty personality. The standard model has most everything you need. But the optional navigation system is appallingly expensive and comes with a questionable joystick control interface.
title: MPG

make.name: Lexus
model.name: CT 200h
style.name: 4dr Hatchback (1.8L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: Powertrain components are covered for 7 years/70,000 miles, but hybrid components are covered for 8 years/100,000 miles. The basic warranty, which applies to most everything else, lasts for 4 years/50,000 miles.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The Lexus CT200h F-Sport is a solidly built hybrid that combines fuel efficiency with a sporty personality. The standard model has most everything you need. But the optional navigation system is appallingly expensive and comes with a questionable joystick control interface.
title: Warranty

make.name: Lexus
model.name: CT 200h
style.name: 4dr Hatchback (1.8L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: Roadside assistance is provided for 4 years with no mileage restriction. Free scheduled maintenance covers no more than the first tire rotation at 5,000 miles and the first synthetic oil change at 10,000 miles.
ratings.title: Value
ratings.summary: The Lexus CT200h F-Sport is a solidly built hybrid that combines fuel efficiency with a sporty personality. The standard model has most everything you need. But the optional navigation system is appallingly expensive and comes with a questionable joystick control interface.
title: Ownership

make.name: Lexus
model.name: CT 200h
style.name: 4dr Hatchback (1.8L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: No faster than a Prius, the CT200h instead delivers with a more rewarding driving experience and greater luxury. It's also anonymous for those who want their hybrid fuel savings without a tree-hugger label.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: The CT200h isn't speedy, so there's no need to look here if that's your definition of fun. However it is quite nimble and entertaining on curvy mountain roads. It's the sort of small "momentum" car we like, but in a high-mpg hybrid form that's even thriftier in the city.
title: Driving Experience

make.name: Lexus
model.name: CT 200h
style.name: 4dr Hatchback (1.8L 4cyl gas/electric hybrid CVT)
summary: A Prius stands out on the road. Everyone knows what it is and what it represents. The Lexus CT200h is nearly as green but does not call attention to itself as such. Instead, our red F-Sport comes across as a small, sporty Lexus.
ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: The CT200h isn't speedy, so there's no need to look here if that's your definition of fun. However it is quite nimble and entertaining on curvy mountain roads. It's the sort of small "momentum" car we like, but in a high-mpg hybrid form that's even thriftier in the city.
title: Personality

make.name: Lexus
model.name: IS 250
style.name: 4dr Sedan (2.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: The 2014 IS's 2.5-liter engine provides adequate acceleration, but the engine feels reluctant to rev. Active sound enhancement makes this V6 sound better than it performs.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Lexus may have taken the crown away from the 3-Series for best steering in the sport sedan segment, but a weak motor and low grip keep the IS250 from being anywhere near a class leader.
title: Acceleration

make.name: Lexus
model.name: IS 250
style.name: 4dr Sedan (2.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Firm pedal with linear effectiveness. Panic-stop distances are comparable for the class.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Lexus may have taken the crown away from the 3-Series for best steering in the sport sedan segment, but a weak motor and low grip keep the IS250 from being anywhere near a class leader.
title: Braking

make.name: Lexus
model.name: IS 250
style.name: 4dr Sedan (2.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Lexus has transformed the IS into a machine that is highly responsive and incredibly communicative. Perhaps the best steering in the sport sedan segment.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Lexus may have taken the crown away from the 3-Series for best steering in the sport sedan segment, but a weak motor and low grip keep the IS250 from being anywhere near a class leader.
title: Steering

make.name: Lexus
model.name: IS 250
style.name: 4dr Sedan (2.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: The IS250 F Sport is hampered by its stock tire option. Understeer arrives very early.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Lexus may have taken the crown away from the 3-Series for best steering in the sport sedan segment, but a weak motor and low grip keep the IS250 from being anywhere near a class leader.
title: Handling

make.name: Lexus
model.name: IS 250
style.name: 4dr Sedan (2.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: The Lexus IS250 F Sport is far more likeable as a daily-driver than a sport sedan. Everything works exceptionally well until you try to push it and have fun.
ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Lexus may have taken the crown away from the 3-Series for best steering in the sport sedan segment, but a weak motor and low grip keep the IS250 from being anywhere near a class leader.
title: Driveability

make.name: Lexus
model.name: IS 250
style.name: 4dr Sedan (2.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: Once again, the IS250 F Sport sides with the comfort set. The seat is plush and comfortable for hours. Bolstering isn't terribly effective during hard driving.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: Hampered by the F Sport suspension tuning, this version of the IS250 rides like a sports car but lacks the benefits.
title: Seating Comfort

make.name: Lexus
model.name: IS 250
style.name: 4dr Sedan (2.5L 6cyl 6A)
summary: The F Sport's firm suspension roughs up the IS250's ride quality. Impacts are harsh, and the rear end can get bouncy.
ratings.title: Comfort

summary: Lexus' Remote Touch Interface is difficult to use when the car is moving and requires looking away from the road for too long. Even early iDrive was more usable.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: An eclectic mix of very good and very awkward keep the 2014 Lexus IS firmly in the middle of the pack when everything is put together.

ratings.title: Fun To Drive
ratings.summary: Thanks to highly precise steering, the IS250 F Sport is very rewarding to drive up to a point. A rough ride, low power and minimal grip hurt its sporting pretensions.

summary: With a new one-piece front fascia the 2014 IS250 F Sport draws a lot of looks -- both good and bad. No one will accuse Lexus of aiming for the middle on this design.

summary: With better-than-average acceleration in our tests, the 155-horsepower 2.0-liter 4-cylinder engine is one of the best in the segment. The 6-speed automatic transmission is smooth and quick.

ratings.summary: Acceleration, steering, and handling are front of the class, but that doesn't cause it to suffer in everyday driveability, where it's also one of the best.

make.name: Mazda

ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Acceleration, steering, and handling are front of the class, but that doesn't cause it to suffer in everyday driveability, where it's also one of the best.

ratings.summary: Acceleration, steering, and handling are front of the class, but that doesn't cause it to suffer in everyday driveability, where it's also one of the best.

ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Acceleration, steering, and handling are front of the class, but that doesn't cause it to suffer in everyday driveability, where it's also one of the best.

ratings.title: Performance
ratings.summary: Acceleration, steering, and handling are front of the class, but that doesn't cause it to suffer in everyday driveability, where it's also one of the best.

make.name: Mazda
style.name: i Touring 4dr Sedan (2.0L 4cyl 6A)
summary: Well-contoured/bolstered sport seats hold you in place while providing good comfort on long drives. The corduroy-like seat material looks odd, isn't as soft as the cloth in a Honda Civic.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: Comfortable and controlled ride plus a quiet cabin add up to better-than-average comfort. The front seats are comfortable, but the rear seat area is tight. The seat material is a strange kind of slightly coarse corduroy.
title: Seating Comfort

make.name: Mazda
style.name: i Touring 4dr Sedan (2.0L 4cyl 6A)
summary: One of the biggest improvements to the all-new Mazda 3 is the ride comfort. It's isolated and stable without being soft and floaty. A great compromise.
ratings.title: Comfort
ratings.summary: Comfortable and controlled ride plus a quiet cabin add up to better-than-average comfort. The front seats are comfortable, but the rear seat area is tight. The seat material is a strange kind of slightly coarse corduroy.

ratings.summary: Comfortable and controlled ride plus a quiet cabin add up to better-than-average comfort. The front seats are comfortable, but the rear seat area is tight. The seat material is a strange kind of slightly coarse corduroy.

make.name: Mazda

summary: Ergonomics are outstanding with all controls easily usable while driving. Buttons are large and clear with the generously-sized touchscreen and rotary knob offering advanced controls.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Huge strides with this redesign elevate the Mazda 3 above the status quo on the inside. Finally those looking for a great-driving economy compact won't have to sacrifce in other areas.
title: Ergonomics

make.name: Mazda
style.name: i Touring 4dr Sedan (2.0L 4cyl 6A)
summary: Large, light doors open wide. Even rear seat entry/exit is good, which is hard to find in this class.
ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Huge strides with this redesign elevate the Mazda 3 above the status quo on the inside. Finally those looking for a great-driving economy compact won't have to sacrifce in other areas.

ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Huge strides with this redesign elevate the Mazda 3 above the status quo on the inside. Finally those looking for a great-driving economy compact won't have to sacrifce in other areas.

ratings.title: Interior
ratings.summary: Huge strides with this redesign elevate the Mazda 3 above the status quo on the inside. Finally those looking for a great-driving economy compact won't have to sacrifce in other areas.

ratings.summary: The Mazda 3's decent fuel economy and sub-18K starting price mark only the beginning of this car's value proposition.

ratings.summary: The Mazda 3's decent fuel economy and sub-18K starting price mark only the beginning of this car's value proposition.

ratings.summary: The Mazda 3's decent fuel economy and sub-18K starting price mark only the beginning of this car's value proposition.
